The *Shiwen* lists the character "怳" (*huang*), and the versions by Lu Xisheng, Huang Maocai, Chen Jingyuan, and Cao Daochong write "惚怳" (*huhuang*), while the Daozang *Heshang* edition writes "忽怳" (*huhuang*). In essence, "怳" (*huang*) and "恍" (*huang*) are the same character. Xi Tong states: "'忽怳' (*huhuang*) may also be reversed as '怳忽' (*huanghu*), sharing the same meaning as '仿佛' (*faint and indistinct*)." Jiang Xichang states: "'惚恍' (*huhuang*) may also appear as '芴芒' (*wumang*) or '惚怳' (*huhuang*), all of which are reduplicative binomes and mutually interchangeable. Such binomes prioritize sound, and as long as the sounds are similar, they may be borrowed for one another. '恍惚' (*huanghu*) is thus equivalent to '仿佛' (*faint and indistinct*)... Yet Laozi deliberately inverts '恍惚' (*huanghu*) to '惚恍' (*huhuang*) because '象' (*image*) and '恍' (*huang*) rhyme." One cannot glimpse its head when approaching, nor see its rear when following.

Ma Xianzhi notes: In various editions, the character "之" (*zhi*) appears above the two "不" (*bu*) characters, but the *Yu zhu* edition, Dunhuang *Bing* manuscript, and British Library manuscripts all omit it. The *Guangming* edition and *Shitoku* edition reverse the two phrases, matching the *Wen Xuan*’s "Toudasi Beiwen." Wu Yun states: "The two characters '其后' (*its rear*) appear above '迎之' (*approaching it*), suggesting the two phrases are inverted."

Grasp the ancient Dao to speak of the present’s existence.
Yan Kejun states: "以语今之有" (*to speak of the present’s existence*)—various editions write "御" (*to govern*). Ma Xianzhi notes: The *Suwen*’s "Qi Jiaobian Dalun" (Chapter 69) states: "I have heard that those who speak well of Heaven must respond to man; those who speak well of the ancient must be verified in the present; those who speak well of qi must manifest in things." This chapter of the *Laozi* is precisely one that speaks well of qi. And "grasp the ancient Dao to speak of the present’s existence" is to speak of the ancient and be verified in the present. Grasping the ancient to speak of the present reveals that the Grand Scribe was one skilled in the art of history. Liu Shipei states: "有" (*existence*) is a loan character for "域" (*realm*). "有" (*you*) is interchangeable with "或" (*huo*), and "或" is the ancient form of "域" (*realm*). The *Book of Songs*’ "Liezhu" in the *Odes of Shang* reads: "奄有九有" (*encompassing the nine realms*), with the *Mao Commentary* stating: "九域 (*nine realms*) refers to the nine provinces." Elsewhere, "正域彼四方" (*rectifying the realm of the four directions*), the *Mao Commentary* states: "域 (*realm*) means 有 (*existence*)." The *Guoyu*’s "Chu Yu" reads: "共工氏之伯九有也" (*Gonggong’s hegemony over the nine realms*), with Wei Zhao’s note: "有 (*you*) means 域 (*realm*)." Here, the character "有" is the same as in "九有." "有" means "域," and "域" is the same "域" as in Chapter 25’s "域中有四大" (*within the realm are the Four Greats*). "御今之有" (*governing the present’s existence*) thus means governing the present’s realm, the world, and the state. The *Book of Rites*’ "Zhongyong" reads: "生乎今之世，反古之道" (*born in the present age, one reverts to the ancient Dao*). This text’s "今之有" (*present’s existence*) is roughly equivalent to that "今之世" (*present age*).

To know the ancient beginning is called the foundation of the Dao.
Yan Kejun states: "以知古始" (*to know the ancient beginning*)—the *Yu zhu* edition and Wang Bi’s edition write "能知" (*can know*). Ma Xianzhi notes: All *Heshang Gong* editions, the *Guangming* edition, and the *Jingfu* edition write "以知" (*to know*). Wu Yun states: "以知" (*to know*)—Fu Yi’s edition writes "能知" (*can know*), matching this stone inscription. Ma Xianzhi notes: Fu Yi’s edition differs from the sutra pillar; Wu’s collation is incorrect. Yan Kejun states: "是谓道已" (*this is called the Dao’s foundation*)—the *Yu zhu* edition and *Heshang Gong* write "道纪" (*Dao’s discipline*), and upon careful examination, Wang Bi’s commentary also uses "已" (*foundation*). Ma Xianzhi notes: Writing "纪" (*discipline*) is correct. The character "已" (*foundation*) lacks meaning. The *Xiao Erya*’s "Guangyan" states: "纪 (*discipline*) means 基 (*foundation*)." "纪" is borrowed for "基" (*foundation*), so "道纪" (*Dao’s discipline*) means "道基" (*Dao’s foundation*).

**[Phonology]**
This chapter’s rhyme scheme, according to Jiang Yong’s reading:
- *Yi* (夷), *xi* (希), *wei* (微), *jie* (诘), *yi* (一), *mei* (昧), *wu* (物) rhyme (脂 *zhi* department, *mei* pronounced *mi*);
- *zhuang* (状), *xiang* (象), *huang* (恍) rhyme (阳 *yang* department, *huang* in departing tone);
- *shou* (首), *hou* (后) rhyme (幽 *you* and 侯 *hou* departments in harmony);
- *you* (有), *shi* (始), *ji* (纪) rhyme (之 *zhi* department).

Ma Xianzhi notes: *Yi* (夷)—Fan Qin’s edition writes "几" (*ji*), and in Jiang Yong’s "Twenty-One Department Phonetic Series," *yi* (夷), *xi* (希), and *wei* (微) all belong to the 脂 *zhi* department. *Shou* (首) belongs to the 幽 *you* department, *hou* (后) to the 侯 *hou* department, with 幽 and 侯 in harmony. Yao Wentian: *Yi* (夷), *xi* (希), *wei* (微) rhyme (五齐 *wu qi* level tone); *jie* (诘), *yi* (一) rhyme (四入 *si ru* entering tone); *mei* (昧), *wu* (物) rhyme (二月 *er yue* entering tone); *zhuang* (状), *xiang* (象), *huang* (恍) rhyme (十六庚 *shi liu geng* departing tone); *shou* (首), *hou* (后), *dao* (道), *you* (有) rhyme (十四○ *shi si ○* rising tone); *shi* (始), *ji* (纪) rhyme (四之 *si zhi* rising tone). The character *hou* (后) harmonizes with *hou* (侯), while *you* (有) shifts into the same rhyme. Deng Tingzhen concurs, though he does not mention *shou* (首), *hou* (后), *dao* (道), or *you* (有). *Jie* (诘) is pronounced *ji*, and *jie* (诘) and *yi* (一) are the entering tones of the 至 *zhi* department.

Xiao Tong: *Yi* (夷), *xi* (希), *wei* (微) rhyme; *jie* (诘), *yi* (一), *mei* (昧), *wu* (物) rhyme; *shou* (首), *hou* (后), *dao* (道), *you* (有), *shi* (始), *ji* (纪) rhyme. The differing divisions among scholars further demonstrate that the original text was highly harmonious. For instance, *shou* (首) and *hou* (后) rhyme, yet Gu Yanwu doubted that "后 (*rear*) in antiquity never rhymed with 首 (*head*), and *Laozi*’s '迎之不见其首，随之不见其后' (*approaching it, one does not see its head; following it, one does not see its rear*) is prose, not rhymed verse" (*Tang Yun Zheng*, Volume 14, *Hou*). This shows his ignorance of the 幽 *you* and 侯 *hou* departments’ harmony, obscuring the true face of *Laozi*’s philosophical poetry.

Kong Guangsen’s *Shisheng Lei* (8, *Zhi* category) states: "In antiquity, there was no distinction between departing and entering tones." As corroborating evidence, he cites the *Laozi*: "其上不皦 (*its above is not bright*), 其下不昧 (*its below is not dark*). 绳绳不可名 (*endlessly unnameable*), 复归于无物 (*returning to nothingness*)." Jiang Yougao’s *Tang Yun Sisheng Zheng* (8, *Wu*) states: "*Wu* (物) is pronounced *wenfu* cut. According to ancient departing tones, it should be grouped with the 未 *wei* department. The *Laozi*’s 'Zan Xuan' chapter rhymes '复归于无物' (*returning to nothingness*) with '昧' (*dark*)." Deng Tingzhen states: "*Mei* (昧) and *wu* (物) rhyme; characters from the 未 *wei* and 勿 *wu* series share the same ancient pronunciation. The *Shuowen* lists *hu* (曶) and *mei* (昧) consecutively. *Hu* (曶) means 'profound darkness,' while *mei* (昧) means '昧爽 (*meishuang*), dawn’s light.' Their sounds are similar, and their meanings close, hence their characters appear in sequence. Sima Xiangru’s *Fu* reads '曶爽暗昧' (*profound darkness and obscurity*), with Wei Zhao reading *hu* (曶) as *mei kui* cut—all evidence that 未 *wei* and 勿 *wu* sounds belong to the same department."

The *Jinglong* stele edition contains ninety-two characters on the right; the Dunhuang annotated edition notes ninety (actually ninety-one); the He and Wang editions, ninety-four; the Fu edition, one hundred; and the Fan edition, ninety-five.

The He Shang Gong edition titles this chapter "Zan Xuan (In Praise of the Mysterious) Fourteenth," the Wang edition titles it "Chapter Fourteen," and the Fan edition titles it "The Chapter on 'Invisible When Seen' Fourteenth."

**Chapter Fifteen**
Those of old who were adept in the Way—
Yu Yue states: He Shang Gong’s commentary reads, "This refers to a ruler who has attained the Dao." Thus, "adept in the *shi* (士)" should be "adept in the *shang* (上)," hence his explanation as a ruler who has attained the Dao. The error arises from the similarity in form between *shang* (上) and *shi* (士).
Qian Zhi notes: Yu Yue’s interpretation is incorrect. According to He Shang Gong’s commentary, "adept in the *shi* (士)" should be "adept in the *Dao* (道)." The Fu Yi edition writes *Dao* (道) for *shi* (士), which serves as evidence.
Bi Yuan states: "*Dao* (道) is written as *shi* (士) in the He Shang Gong and Wang Bi editions." However, *Dao* (道) is correct; the Gao Biao edition also writes *Dao* (道).
Ma Xulun states: The *Hou Han Shu*’s "Biographies of the Disenfranchised" quotes this as *Dao* (道). According to He Shang Gong’s commentary, it seems he also wrote *Dao* (道)... The *Shiwen* confirms that *Dao* (道) is correct. The current Wang Bi edition’s *shi* (士) likely derives from the text of Chapter Sixty-Eight. Further, this sentence shares the same meaning as Chapter Sixty-Five’s "Those of old who were adept in the Dao," and it also resonates with the later phrase "those who preserve this Dao."

Subtle, mysterious, and profoundly penetrating, so deep as to be unknowable.
Only because it is unknowable is one compelled to describe it:
Jiang Xichang states: The *Shiji*’s "Biography of Laozi" records Laozi as saying, "...A good merchant hides his wealth as if empty; a noble person of great virtue appears foolish." This aligns with the meaning of "subtle, mysterious, and profoundly penetrating, so deep as to be unknowable."
Yi Shunding states: The *Wen Xuan*’s commentary on Zhang Zai’s *Fu on the Wei Capital* quotes Laozi: "Those of old were subtle, mysterious, and profoundly penetrating, so deep as to be unknowable. Only because they were unknowable was one compelled to praise them." The character *song* (颂, "praise") is the ancient form, while *rong* (容, "describe") is the modern form... "Compelled to describe it" means "compelled to depict it."
Chen Zhu states: The seal script form of *song* (颂) is "○," so *rong* (容) is also an ancient loan character; no emendation is necessary.
Qian Zhi notes: "Unknowable" is written as "unfathomable" in the Fan edition, with a note stating, "ancient edition."

Cautious, as if fording a river in winter;
Yan Kejun states: He Shang Gong writes *yu* (豫) as "与兮," while Wang Bi writes "豫焉."
Luo Zhenyu states: The *Shiwen* notes that *yu* (豫) is sometimes written as *ao* (懊). The character *yan* (焉) appears as *xi* (兮) in the Jingfu edition. The Jinglong, Imperial Commentary, and Dunhuang Bing editions omit *yan* (焉).
Li Daochun states: "Cautious, as if fording a river in winter" is sometimes written as "与兮," but versions omitting *xi* (兮) in the following six or three phrases are incorrect.

Wary, as if fearing neighbors on all sides;
Yan Kejun states: *You* (犹) is written as "犹兮" in the He Shang Gong and Wang Bi editions.
Wang Chang states: All editions include *xi* (兮) after *you* (犹); the Lu Xisheng to Yuan editions match this for both phrases.
Luo Zhenyu states: The Jinglong and Imperial Commentary editions both omit *xi* (兮).
Qian Zhi notes: Ye Mengde’s *Yanxia Fangyan* (Part One) states: "To be cautious before an event is called *yu* (豫); to be cautious after an event is called *you* (犹). *You* and *yu* are originally the names of two animals. Ancient language often borrowed from things to convey meaning, but later generations, familiar only with the meaning and not the original referents, arbitrarily fabricated explanations, leading to errors." Now, according to the *Erya*’s "Explanation of Beasts," "*You* resembles a muntjac and is skilled at climbing trees." The *Shiwen* cites the *Shizi*: "*You* is a five-chi-tall dog." The *Shuowen*’s "Dog" section states: "*You* belongs to the *jue* (玃) category. Another saying: In Longxi, a puppy is called *you* (猷)." The *Yanshi Jiaxun*’s "Evidence from Writing" chapter states: "*You* is the name of an animal. Upon hearing human sounds, it cautiously climbs trees, moving up and down in this manner, hence the term *youyu* (犹豫)." The *Han Shu*’s "Annals of Empress Gao" reads, "The plan was *youyu* (犹豫) and not yet decided," with Yan Shigu commenting: "*You* is the name of an animal. The *Erya* states, '*You* resembles ○ and is skilled at climbing trees.' This animal is by nature suspicious and often dwells in mountains. Upon suddenly hearing a sound, it fears someone is coming to harm it, so it cautiously climbs a tree. After a long time with no one appearing, it dares to descend, only to climb again shortly after—repeating this behavior, hence indecision is called *youyu*. Another saying: In Longxi, a puppy is called *you*. Dogs follow people, often cautiously moving ahead, waiting for their owner. If the owner does not arrive, they return to greet them, hence the term *youyu*." *Youyu* is also written as *youyu* (犹与). The *Shiji*’s "Annals of Empress Lü" reads, "*Youyu* (犹与) and not yet decided," with the *Suoyin* stating: "*You* resembles an ape, with an upturned nose and long tail, and is by nature suspicious." The *Han Shu*’s "Biography of Huo Guang" reads, "unable to bear *youyu* (犹与)," with a note stating: "*Youyu* means indecision." It is also written as *yin yu* (冘豫). The *Hou Han Shu*’s commentary on the "Biography of Dou Wu" states: "*Yin yu* means unsettled." Gao You’s commentary on the *Lüshi Chunqiu* writes it as *you yu* (由与).
Wang Niansun’s *Dushu Zazhi* (Volume Four, Part One) states: "*Youyu* is a double-voiced word, akin to the *Chu Ci*’s *yiyou* (夷犹), and does not refer to an animal fearing humans and cautiously climbing trees, nor to a puppy cautiously moving ahead of its owner."

Both interpretations are plausible, though Wang’s is superior.

Here it speaks of one who treads winter streams as if fearing the cold, who regards the four neighbors as if dreading enemies—*you* and *yu*, hesitating and not advancing—all to depict the demeanor shaped by circumstance.

"Solemn as a guest":
Yan Kejun notes that the *Heshang Gong* and Wang Bi versions include the characters *xi qi* (兮其) after *yan* (俨). Wang Chang states that *Heshang Gong* reads *yan xi qi ruo ke* (俨兮其若客), while Wang Bi has *yan xi qi ruo rong* (俨兮其若容). Upon examination, *ke* (客, "guest") rhymes with the four characters *shi* (释), *pu* (朴), *gu* (谷), and *zhuo* (浊) below; the reading *rong* (容, "demeanor") is incorrect. Chen Zhu states that Wang Bi’s version writes *rong* (容) for *ke* (客). Luo Zhenyu observes that the *Jingfu* edition reads *ke* (客), while the *Jinglong*, *Yinglun*, and *Yuzhu* editions all read *yan ruo ke* (俨若客). Chen Zhu further notes that Fu Yi’s edition also reads *yan ruo ke* (俨若客); the reading *ke* (客) is correct. *Ke* (客) and *shi* (释) form a rhyme. The reading *rong* (容) arises from a misreading of the preceding phrase *qiang wei zhi rong* (强为之容, "forced demeanor").

"Melting like ice about to dissolve":
Yan Kejun notes that *Heshang Gong* and Wang Bi read *huan xi ruo bing zhi jiang shi* (涣兮若冰之将释), with *xi* (兮) appearing in the next three phrases. Luo Zhenyu states that the *Jinglong*, *Yinglun*, and *Yuzhu* editions all read *huan ruo bing jiang shi* (涣若冰将释). Takeuchi Yoshio notes that the Dunhuang manuscript writes *zhuo* (汋) for *shi* (释). Qian Zhixi observes that the Suizhou edition also writes *zhuo* (汋). Liu Shipei states that the *Wenzi*’s "Shang Ren" chapter reads *huan xi qi ruo bing zhi ye* (涣兮其若冰之液). It is suspected that the *Daodejing*’s ancient text read *ye* (液, "fluid"). The phrase *jiang shi* (将释, "about to dissolve") appears to be a later gloss, which editors incorporated into the main text. Yi Shunding notes that the *Kaogong Ji*’s "Gong Ren" commentary reads *ye* (液) as *shi* (醳). The *Shanhaijing*’s "Beishan Jing" states, "*Ye* (液) is pronounced like *yi* (悦) in *yiyi* (悦怿)." *Shi* (醳) and *yi* (怿) both interchange with *shi* (释)... The *Gu Ming*’s "Wang bu yi" (王不怿) is written as *wang bu shi* (王不释) in Ma Rong’s version, serving as evidence. *Ye* (液) shares the same pronunciation and meaning as *shi* (释), hence their interchangeability. Jiang Xichang states that the *Shuowen* defines *shi* (释) as "to dissolve" and *ye* (液) as "water exhausted." Ice may be said to dissolve but not to be "water exhausted," so *shi* (释) is contextually superior. However, *shi* (释) was also borrowed as *ye* (液) in antiquity. The *Liji*’s "Yue Ling" reads *bing dong xiao shi* (冰冻消释), with the *Shiwen* noting, "*Shi* (释) is originally written as *ye* (液)." This is an example. The *Wenzi*’s *ye* (液) is a loan character, while the *Daodejing*’s *shi* (释) is the original.

"Uncarved as raw wood, turbid as muddy water, vast as a valley."
Yan Kejun notes that the *Yuzhu* edition reads *kuang ruo gu, hun ruo zhuo* (旷若谷，浑若浊), while *Heshang Gong* reads *kuang xi qi ruo gu, hun xi qi ruo zhuo* (旷兮其若谷，浑兮其若浊). Wang Bi’s version matches *Heshang Gong*’s, with *hun* (混) for *hun* (浑). Wang Chang states that the Xingzhou edition reads *hun ruo pu, kuang ruo gu, hun ruo zhuo* (混若朴，旷若谷，混若浊), matching this passage’s syntax; the Dunhuang edition’s *hun* (混) may be an error influenced by the following text. Wei Jiasun notes that in *zhen zhi pu* (镇之朴), the *Yuzhu* edition writes *pu* (朴), while the others write *pu* (扑). Yan Kejun’s collation of *pu* (朴), *pu sui xiao* (朴虽小), and *zhi pu* (之朴) omits the *pu* (扑) variant. He observes that wood-radical clerical script often borrows the hand radical, and Tang-era rhyme schemes were inconsistent; this final instance may be disregarded in later collations. Qian Zhixi notes that *hun* (混) and *hun* (浑) are interchangeable. The *Yuzhu*, Xing Xuan, Qingyang, Panxi, Lou Zheng, Shitang, *Heshang Gong*, Gu Huan, Li Daochun, and Fan Yingyuan editions all write *hun* (浑). Wang Niansun’s *Dushu Zazhi* (Volume Nine) states, "*Hun* (混) and *hun* (浑) were homophonous in antiquity."

Can the turbid be stilled through serenity?

Wei Jiasun states: Stele inscriptions uniformly use *shu* (孰) for *shu* (熟). The *Yuzhu* edition writes *shu* (熟) in "ripen it to maturity," while I write *shu* (孰); Yan’s collation is incomplete.

Qian Zhixi notes: The character *shu* (熟) did not exist in antiquity. The *Shuowen* defines *shu* (孰) as "food cooked to doneness." The *Liji Liyun* reads: "Then they ate raw flesh and chewed *shu* (孰) grain." The *Hanshu Yan An zhuan* states: "The five grains flourished and *shu* (孰)." *Shu* (孰) and *shu* (熟) are interchangeable; the fire radical was a later addition. The *Gongyang Commentary* to *Yin 1* asks: "Whom does the *wangzhe* (王者) refer to?" The *Lunyu* states: "What cannot be endured?" The commentary explains: "Who." *Shui* (谁) and *shu* (孰) are phonetic shifts of the same word. Bi Yuan notes: The *Heshang Gong* edition reads: "Who can still the turbid through serenity, slowly clarifying?" Some versions write *zhi* (止) for *yi* (以), rhyming with the following *jiu* (久); this is likely correct.

How can it be stirred into motion? Slowly arising.

Yan Kejun states: The *Yuzhu* edition writes "how can it endure for long," while the *Heshang Gong* and Wang Bi editions read "who can endure for long." The *Dayian* omits the character *jiu* (久). Takeuchi Yoshio notes: The Dunhuang, Jing, and Sui manuscripts all lack the two instances of *shu neng* (孰能).

Qian Zhixi notes: These two lines differ across editions. The Fu edition reads: "Who can still the turbid to clarity, slowly clarifying? Who can endure in stillness to stir motion, slowly arising?" The Fan edition omits *cheng* (澄) in the first line but matches the second. The *Guangming* edition reads: "Who can still the turbid, stirring it to slow clarity? Who can endure for long, stirring it to □□ (the characters *xu sheng* (徐生) are effaced)?" The character *xu* (徐) carries the meaning of leisurely, unhurried, or gradual. The *Shuowen* defines *xu* (徐) as "slow." The *Erya* *Shitian* Li commentary states: "*Xu* (徐) means leisurely." The *Erya* *Shidi* Li commentary explains: "Between the Huai and the sea, the *qi* is expansive and unhurried, the temperament calm and gradual, hence the name *Xu* (徐)." "Still the turbid, slowly clarifying" parallels "endure in stillness, slowly arising." Wu Cheng states: "The turbid is the moment of motion; when followed by stillness, it gradually clarifies. Stillness is the moment of rest; when stillness is followed by motion, it gradually arises."

Those who preserve this Dao do not desire fullness.

Bi Yuan states: Gao You’s commentary on the *Huainanzi* notes, "The character *bao* (保) is sometimes written as *fu* (服)." Ma Xulun remarks: "According to the Zhuang edition of the *Huainanzi* *Daoying Xun*, *bao* (保) is written as *fu* (复); the Wang edition concurs. The *Wenzi* *Shou Ruo* chapter writes it as *fu* (服). I contend that *bao* (保), *fu* (复), and *fu* (服) are interchangeable through the *zhi* and *you* rhyme groups." Jiang Xichang argues: "Though *bao* (保), *fu* (复), and *fu* (服) may be interchangeable, the Zhuang edition of the *Huainanzi* should be followed, using *fu* (复). The *Shuowen* defines *fu* (复) as 'to go and come.' Duan Yucai’s commentary on the radical states: '*Fan* (返) means to return; *huan* (还) means to revert.' Both denote going and then coming back, so *fu* (复) shares the same meaning as *fan* (返) and *huan* (还). In Chapter 40, 'Reversion is the movement of the Dao'—*fan* (反) is *fan* (返). Thus, 'One who reverts to this Dao does not desire fullness' is akin to saying 'One who returns to this Dao does not desire fullness.' Only by not being full can one remain worn yet whole."

Yan Kejun notes: "The *Yu zhu* edition reads *gu neng bi bu xin cheng* (故能弊不新成); the *Heshang Gong* edition reads *gu neng bi bu xin cheng* (故能蔽不新成); the *Dayian* edition reads *gu neng bi bu xin cheng* (故能敝不新成). Wang Bi’s commentary explains *bi* (蔽) as 'to cover,' aligning with the *Heshang Gong* edition." Hong Yixuan observes: "'The character *bi* (蔽) contrasts with *xin* (新); here, *bi* (蔽) is interchangeable with *bi* (敝). Below, 'Worn, then renewed'—the *Shiwen* writes *bi* (弊) as *bi* (蔽). In the *Analects* *Zihan*, 'worn-out quilted robe'—the *Shiwen* notes: '*Bi* (弊) is originally written as *bi* (敝).' In the *Zhuangzi* *Xiaoyaoyou*, 'Who would weary themselves thus?'—the *Shiwen* states: 'Sima Biao’s edition writes *bi* (蔽).' These characters were interchangeable in ancient script." Yu Yue asserts: "*Bi* (蔽) is a loan for *bi* (敝). The Tang *Jinglong* stele writes *bi* (弊), also a loan for *bi* (敝). The *Yongle Dadian* correctly writes *bi* (敝). The three characters *bu xin cheng* (不新成) appear as *fu cheng* (复成) in the *Jinglong* stele. However, the *Huainanzi* *Daoying Xun* quotes the *Laozi* as saying, 'One who adheres to this Dao does not desire fullness, thus can be worn yet not newly whole.' This matches the ancient text, though the modern edition omits the character *er* (而), leaving the meaning incomplete."

Yi Shunding proposes: "It likely should read *gu neng bi er xin cheng* (故能蔽而新成). *Bi* (蔽) is a loan for *bi* (敝); *bu* (不) is a scribal error for *er* (而). *Bi* (敝) contrasts with *xin* (新); 'can be worn yet newly whole' echoes Chapter 22’s 'Worn, then renewed,' paralleling the earlier 'can be turbid yet clear, can be still yet arise.'" The *Huainanzi* *Daoying Xun* reads *gu neng bi er bu xin cheng* (故能蔽而不新成), confirming the ancient text included *er* (而), while *bu* (不) was likely a later interpolation. The *Wenzi* *Shi Shou* chapter reads *shi yi bi bu xin cheng* (是以蔽不新成), also a later alteration. Some editions read *er bu cheng* (而不成) or *fu cheng* (复成), but these distort the meaning. Emendations based on conjecture are less reliable than cross-referencing the text itself.

Qian Jibo’s case: Qian Daxin states, "'Thus can be covered yet not newly whole'—the stone inscription reads *neng bi fu cheng* (能弊复成), far superior to other editions." This is correct. The Fu edition reads *shi yi neng bi er bu cheng* (是以能敝而不成), omitting *xin* (新) and contradicting the *Laozi*’s meaning. Yi’s argument, using "Worn, then renewed" to support *gu neng bi er xin cheng* (故能蔽而新成), is stronger than Yu Yue’s interpretation of "preferring wear over freshness." Chen Jiru’s *Laozi Jun* claims, "To be worn yet not newly whole means unchanging, like a single day spanning a hundred years"—utterly pedantic. In the *Zhengyi* commentary, *neng bi fu cheng* (能蔽复成) corresponds to the earlier line "One who reverts to this Dao does not desire fullness." Thus, *bi er xin cheng* (蔽而新成) is less fitting than the *Jinglong*, *Suizhou*, Li Rong, and Sima Guang editions’ *bi er fu cheng* (蔽而复成), which align more closely with the *Laozi*’s meaning.

**[Phonology]**
This chapter’s rhyme groups, per Jiang Yong’s reading:
- *tong*, *rong* (東部);
- *chuan*, *lin* (文、真通韻, *chuan* rhymes with *chun*);
- *ke*, *shi* (魚部, *shi* in *shurusheng*);
- *pu*, *gu*, *zhuo* (侯部, *pu* as *pangmu* 旁木反, *zhuo* as *zhaimu* 宅木反).

The *qing*, *sheng*, *ying*, *ying*, and *cheng* rhyme in the *Geng* group.

Moreover, Xi Dong and Karlgren both treat *ke*, *shi*, *pu*, *gu*, and *zhuo* as a single rhyme, while Yao Wentian groups *ke* and *shi* as one rhyme (the entering tone of *wuxi*) and *pu*, *gu*, and *zhuo* as another (the entering tone of *liuwu*). Karlgren renders *yu xi* (豫兮) as *ao xi* (懊兮), with *ao* rhyming with *you* (犹), *yan* (俨) with *huan* (涣), and *dun* (敦) with *hun* (混). In reality, *yan* and *huan* do not rhyme.

The character *ke* (客) is also written as *rong* (容), while *shi* (释) appears alternatively as *zhuo* (汋) or *ye* (液), all of which maintain the rhyme. Furthermore, in the line *"shu neng zhuo yi jing zhi, xu qing"* (孰能浊以静之，徐清), the character *jing* (静) is preceded by *zhi* (止) in some versions, with *zhi* rhyming with the subsequent *jiu* (久), while *cheng* (澄) rhymes with the following *qing* (清) as well as *sheng*, *ying*, and *cheng*.

Additionally, it is noted that in stele versions of this chapter, the particle *xi* (兮) is omitted, thereby losing the melodic beauty of the Chu dialect in the *Five Thousand Words*. This should be corrected according to other editions. Tan Xian’s *Futang Diary* (Volume 5) states: *"The stone inscriptions from Yizhou use the fewest particles, leading some to consider them closer to antiquity. Fu Yi’s definitive edition, predating the stone versions, contains the most particles, yet both extremes likely deviate from the original—too much is as flawed as too little."* This precisely refers to such cases.

Gu Yanwu’s *Rectification of Tang Rhymes* (Volume 52, *Geng* group) states: *"Sheng" (生) is pronounced *suo geng*, and should be written as *suo zheng*.* It cites the *Laozi*:

*"Thus, being and non-being give rise to each other,
Difficulty and ease complete each other,
Long and short shape each other,
High and low incline toward each other."*

*"Who can still the turbid to gradually attain clarity?
Who can stir the tranquil to gradually bring forth life?
Those who preserve this Dao do not desire fullness.
Only by not being full can one remain unspoiled and not newly completed."*

*"Of old, those who attained the One:
Heaven attained the One and became clear,
Earth attained the One and became tranquil,
The spirits attained the One and became efficacious,
The myriad things attained the One and came to life,
The lords and kings attained the One and became the standard for all under heaven."*

The *Jinglong Stele* version contains eighty characters; the Dunhuang manuscript notes eighty (in fact, seventy-nine); the *Heshang Gong* and Wang Bi versions, ninety-seven; the Fu Yi version, ninety-eight; and the Fan Yingyuan version, ninety-nine. The *Heshang Gong* version titles this chapter *"Manifesting Virtue, Fifteen"*; the Wang Bi version, *"Chapter Fifteen"*; and the Fan Yingyuan version, *"The Chapter on the Ancient Masters of the Dao, Fifteen."*

**Chapter Sixteen**
Attain utmost emptiness, guard profound stillness.
Qian’s note: The character *"zhi"* (致) is written as *"zhi"* (至) in the *Jingfu* and *Heshang Gong* versions. The character *"du"* (笃) appears as *"○"* in the *Jinglong*, *Jingfu*, Zhao Mengfu, and other versions. The *Character Dictionary* states: *"Du* (笃), from the *Shuowen*: ‘A horse’s gait slows and falters; from *ma* (马) and phonetic *zhu* (竹).’ Commonly written as *○*." Additionally, the *Shitoku* version includes the particle *"ye"* (也) after *"ji"* (极) and *"du"* (笃).

Qian’s note: The *Laozi* mentions *"xu"* (虚, emptiness) five times, but only in Chapter Five (*"xu er bu qu"* 虚而不屈, "empty yet unexhausted") and this chapter (*"zhi xu ji"* 致虚极, "attain utmost emptiness") does it seem to carry the meaning of *"xuwu"* (虚无, emptiness and nothingness). The *Guangya* (*Explanations of Terms*, Volume 3) defines *"xu"* as *"kong"* (空, void). The *Western Capital Rhapsody* states: *"There was one called the Master of Emptiness,"* with the commentary: *"Xu* means *wu* (无, nothingness)." *Xu* also implies an empty cavity, hence its gloss as void or nothingness. However, the doctrine of emptiness and nothingness is a later misinterpretation derived from *Zhuangzi* and *Liezi*; the *Laozi* contains no such notion. *"Empty yet unexhausted, moving yet ever emerging"* reflects the *Laozi*’s grasp of the *Yijing*’s principles of change, expansion, and contraction. As Shao Yong said, *"Laozi grasped the essence of the *Yi*,"* precisely referring to this. *"Attaining utmost emptiness"* aligns with holding fast to the essential and embracing the root, maintaining clarity and emptiness—akin to the *Analects*’ *"cultivating oneself to bring peace to the people."* Wang Tong’s remark, *"When clarity and emptiness prevailed, the Jin court fell into chaos—this was not Laozi’s fault,"* refers to this very principle.

All things arise together, and I thereby observe their return.
Yan Kejun notes: The Wang Bi version omits the character *"qi"* (其). Ji Yun states: The *Heshang Gong* commentary and other versions all include *"qi"* after *"guan"* (观). Luo Zhenyu notes: The *Jinglong*, *Imperial Commentary*, *Jingfu*, and British Library versions all include *"qi"* after *"guan."* Jiang Xichang states: The *Huainanzi* (*Daoying* chapter) reads, *"I thereby observe their return,"* and the *Wenzi* (*Daoyuan* chapter) also includes *"qi."* The Wang Bi version omits it and should be corrected accordingly. Wang Bi’s commentary—*"observing their reversion through emptiness and stillness"*—serves as evidence.

The teeming things,
Each returns to its root.
Qian’s note: *"Yun yun"* (云云) appears as *"yun yun"* (芸芸) in the *Heshang Gong* and Wang Bi versions, and as *"fan wu ○○"* (凡物○○) in the Fu and Fan versions. The *Zhuangzi* (*Zai You* chapter), the commentary to Jiang Yan’s *"Miscellaneous Imitations"* in the *Wen Xuan*, and the Suizhou stele version all render it as *"yun yun."* The original likely read *"yun yun."* The characters *"○"* and *"yun"* are interchangeable. Gu Yewang’s *Jade Chapters* (*Yun* section) cites the *Laozi*: *"All things teeming, returning to their root."* Here, *"yun"* denotes restlessness. The *Lüshi Chunqiu* states: *"Clouds drift westward, teeming without cease through winter and summer,"* and the *Han History* reads: *"Those who expound teem endlessly,"* both employing the same sense. Alternatively, *"○"* (from the *Jade Chapters*) is pronounced *yun* or *yun*, meaning *"the disorder of things."* The *Shuowen* defines it as *"the chaotic disorder of things,"* which also fits. Another theory holds that *"yun yun"* is an abbreviation of *"○○,"* with Fu Yi using the original character.

Returning to the root is called stillness;
Stillness is called returning to destiny;
Returning to destiny is called constancy;
Knowing constancy is called enlightenment.
Qian’s note: *"Stillness is called returning to destiny"* appears identically in the *Imperial Commentary*, Xing Xun, Qingyang, Lou Zheng, Panxi, Wang Xizhi, Gao Bi, Zhao Mengfu, Fu, and Fan versions, as well as this stele. The *Heshang Gong* and Wang Bi versions read *"This is called returning to destiny."*

Not knowing constancy, reckless action brings misfortune.
Yan Kejun states: *"Forgetting action brings misfortune"* appears in other versions as *"reckless action brings misfortune."* The *Heshang Gong* version occasionally writes *"wei"* (萎), which is erroneous.
Qian’s note: *"Wang"* (忘, forgetting) and *"wang"* (妄, recklessness) were interchangeable in antiquity. Han Fei’s *Explaining the Laozi* reads: *"Those with foresight lack cause and forget their intentions,"* with Wang Xianshen’s commentary: *"Wang* is interchangeable with *wang* (妄)." The *Zuozhuan* (Duke Xiang, Year 27) commentary states: *"Speaking of the Duke’s frequent forgetfulness,"* with the *Exegesis* noting: *"Wang* is also written as *wang* (妄)."*

The *Zhuangzi*’s "Robber Zhi" chapter states: *"Thus, to uphold the upright without forgetting,"* with the *Exegesis* noting: *"‘Forgetting’ is sometimes written as ‘recklessness.’"* This further confirms the ancient interchangeability of *wang* (忘) and *wang* (妄). Thus, *"reckless action brings misfortune"* is equivalent to *"forgetting action brings misfortune."*

Here, *"returning to destiny is called constancy"* and *"not knowing constancy, reckless action brings misfortune"* align with the *Yijing*’s meaning. The *Xugua Zhuan* states: *"Returning precludes recklessness, hence it is followed by ‘Wuwang’ (No Recklessness)."*

Knowing constancy brings tolerance,
tolerance brings impartiality,
impartiality brings kingship,
kingship brings heaven,
heaven brings the Dao,
the Dao brings enduringness.

Yan Kejun notes: *"Tolerance brings impartiality"*—the *Yu zhu*, *Heshang Gong*, and Wang Bi versions write *"nai"* (乃) instead of *"neng"* (能), and the same applies to the following four lines. Additionally, *"impartiality brings kingship"* and the subsequent four lines appear in the Xingzhou edition as *"impartiality brings life, life brings heaven."*

Takeuchi Yoshio observes: The phrase *"knowing constancy"* is followed by a *"yue"* (曰) in the old manuscript of the *Heshang Gong* version and the *Guangming Chuang*, though most versions omit it. ... According to the commentary’s meaning, Wang Bi’s edition also includes *"yue."*

*"Impartiality brings life"*—in most Wang Bi editions, *"sheng"* (生, life) is written as *"wang"* (王, kingship). This has been corrected based on the Dunhuang unannotated version and the *Daozang*’s *Cijie* edition.

Lao Jian remarks: *"Knowing constancy brings tolerance, tolerance brings impartiality"*—*"tolerance"* (容) and *"impartiality"* (公) form a rhyme. *"Heaven brings the Dao, the Dao brings enduringness"*—*"Dao"* (道) and *"enduringness"* (久) form a rhyme. However, the two lines *"impartiality brings kingship, kingship brings heaven"* lack a close rhyme. The character *"wang"* (王, kingship) is inherently dubious. Wang Bi’s commentary on these two lines states: *"Utterly impartial, one reaches all-pervading universality; all-pervading universality then attains unity with heaven."* Yet *"all-pervading universality"* clearly does not explicate *"kingship."* The *Daozang*’s *Longxing Stele* edition reads *"impartiality brings life, life brings heaven,"* but *"life"* (生) is even more inexplicable.

Upon examination, the *Zhuangzi*’s "Heaven and Earth" chapter states: *"Those who grasp the Dao attain complete virtue; those with complete virtue attain complete form; those with complete form attain complete spirit; those with complete spirit embody the sage’s Dao."* The character *"wang"* (王) in these two lines is likely a corruption of *"quan"* (全, complete). Thus, *"impartiality brings completeness, completeness brings heaven"*—*"completeness"* (全) and *"heaven"* (天) form a rhyme. Wang Bi’s commentary on *"all-pervading universality"* is apt. Furthermore, the *Lüshi Chunqiu*’s "Bensheng" chapter states: *"The Son of Heaven’s actions aim to preserve heaven’s completeness,"* with Gao You’s commentary: *"‘Complete’ means ‘accordant.’"* This supplements Wang Bi’s incomplete exegesis. The modern *"wang"* (王) and the stele’s *"sheng"* (生) are both corrupted forms of *"quan"* (全), with *"sheng"* (生) being particularly graphically similar to *"quan"* (全), serving as evidence of textual evolution.

One’s body does not perish in danger.

Qian’s note: The *Yu zhu* edition writes *"mo"* (殁) instead of *"mei"* (没), and the Fu and Fan editions also use *"mo."* Lao Jian’s *Ancient Textual Study* mistakenly follows the Fu edition in writing *"mei."*

**[Phonology]**
This chapter’s rhymes, according to Jiang Yong:
- *du* (笃) and *fu* (复) rhyme (幽 rhyme group),
- *yun* (芸) and *gen* (根) rhyme (文 rhyme group),
- *jing* (静) and *ming* (命) rhyme (耕 rhyme group),
- *chang* (常), *ming* (明), *chang* (常), *xiong* (凶), *rong* (容), *gong* (公), and *wang* (王) rhyme (阳 and 东 rhyme groups in harmonized rhyme; *ming* reads *mang*, *xiong* rhymes with *xuwang*, *rong* rhymes with *wang*, *gong* rhymes with *guang*).

*Dao* (道), *jiu* (久), and *dai* (殆) rhyme (之 and 幽 rhyme groups in harmonized rhyme; *dao* rhymes with *tuyi*, *jiu* reads *yi*, *dai* rhymes with *tuyi*).

Qian’s note: *Chang* (常), *ming* (明), and *wang* (王) belong to the 阳 rhyme group; *xiong* (凶), *rong* (容), and *gong* (公) belong to the 东 rhyme group, with 阳 and 东 in harmonized rhyme. Additionally, *dai* (殆) belongs to the 之 rhyme group, while *dao* (道) and *jiu* (久) span the 之 and 幽 rhyme groups, with 之 and 幽 in harmonized rhyme.

Yao Wentian groups *chang* (常) and *ming* (明) as one rhyme (十六庚, level tone) and *xiong* (凶), *rong* (容), and *gong* (公) as another (一东, level tone). Deng Tingzhen concurs.

Gu Yanwu’s *Tang Yun Zheng*, fascicle 52 (庚):
*"Ming* (明) was anciently pronounced *molang*; by phonetic principles, it should be *milang."* Citing the *Laozi*:
- *"Returning to destiny is called constancy; knowing constancy is called illumination."*
- *"Not seeing oneself is illumination; not asserting oneself is clarity."*
- *"Those who stand on tiptoe cannot stand; those who stride cannot walk. Those who see themselves are not illuminated; those who assert themselves are not clear."*
- *"Knowing others is wisdom; knowing oneself is illumination. Overcoming others requires strength; overcoming oneself is power."*
- *"This is called subtle illumination: the soft overcomes the hard, the weak overcomes the strong."*
- *"Seeing the small is illumination; preserving softness is power. Using its light, returning to its illumination, leaving no harm to the body—this is called practicing constancy."*
- *"Knowing harmony is constancy; knowing constancy is illumination. Excessive life is ominous; the mind’s control of qi is strength."*

Fascicle 14 (有):
*"Jiu* (久) was anciently pronounced *ji."* Citing the *Laozi*:
- *"Heaven brings the Dao, the Dao brings enduringness; the body does not perish in danger."*
- *"Knowing contentment avoids disgrace; knowing limits avoids danger—this can endure."*
- *"The mother of a state can endure long."*

Also citing Yang Shen: *"Before Confucius, *jiu* was pronounced *ji*; only after Confucius transmitted the *Yijing* did it acquire the *jiu* pronunciation."* Examples from the *Yijing*:
- *Lin* hexagram commentary: *"Great prosperity through correctness—this is heaven’s Dao. By the eighth month, there will be misfortune, for decline does not endure."*
- *Qian* hexagram commentary: *"The dragon soars with regret—fullness cannot endure. The nine in the fifth place: Heaven’s virtue cannot be primary."*
- *Daguo* hexagram commentary: *"The withered poplar blooms—how can this endure? The old woman and the young man—how shameful!"*
- *Li* hexagram commentary: *"Treading cautiously to avoid blame; yellow and radiant—attaining the central Dao."*

Here the *Li* hexagram commentary concludes: *"The sun declining from its zenith—how can this endure?"*

The *Jiji* hexagram commentary rhymes *bèi* (惫), *yí* (疑), *shí* (时), and *lái* (来), while the *Zagua* rhymes *zhǐ* (止), thus preserving both *jǐ* and *jiǔ* pronunciations in the transmitted *Yijing* texts.

Laozi states: *"One who does not lose their place endures; one who dies yet does not perish is long-lived."* Now, Laozi and Confucius were contemporaries, and in Laozi’s text, the character *jiǔ* (久) appears three times—once rhyming with *dài* (殆), once with *mǔ* (母), and once with *shòu* (寿).

The *Jinglong* stele version contains sixty-seven characters; the Dunhuang version, sixty-six; the Heshang version, sixty-eight; and the Wang, Fu, and Fan versions, sixty-seven. The Heshang version titles this "Returning to the Root, Sixteen"; the Wang version, "Chapter Sixteen"; and the Fan version, "Attaining the Utmost of Emptiness, Sixteen."

**Chapter Seventeen**
In the highest antiquity, the people merely knew their rulers existed.
*Qian’s note:* The *Liji·Quli* states, *"In the highest antiquity, virtue was prized; next, reciprocity was practiced."* Zheng Xuan annotates: *"The highest antiquity refers to the age of emperors and kings, when the people gave without expecting return."* What Laozi describes is precisely the perfect governance of remote antiquity, where the Dao pervaded and nurtured all under heaven, yet no active governance was imposed. The people, immersed in non-action, forgot their rulers’ existence.

*"The people merely knew their rulers existed"*—Ji Yun notes: *"The Yongle Encyclopedia has ‘不’ (not) instead of ‘下’ (merely); Wu Cheng’s edition also reads ‘不’."* Now, Jiao Hong’s *Laozi Yi* follows Wu Cheng’s version. Additionally, Wang Bi’s old annotated edition, appended with Sun Kuang’s textual corrections, states: *"Modern editions read ‘不’ instead of ‘下’."* The reading *"did not know"* also yields a profound meaning.

Next, they were cherished and praised.
Yan Kejun notes: The imperial commentary and Heshang versions read *"cherished and praised them,"* while Wang Bi’s reads *"cherished and praised them."* *Qian’s note:* Fu Yi’s edition reads *"next, they were cherished; next, they were praised."*

Next, they were awed and scorned.
Yan Kejun notes: The Heshang version includes *"next"* after *"awed them."* Li Daochun states: *"Next, they were awed; next, they were scorned"*—those who read *"awed and scorned them"* are incorrect. Yu Shengwu notes: He’s collated edition omits the second *"next."* Ji Yun observes that the *Yongle Encyclopedia* lacks *"next"* before *"scorned them."* The correct reading is *"next, they were awed; next, they were scorned."* The preceding line reads *"next, they were cherished and praised,"* and the Heshang version correctly uses *"之"* (them) instead of *"而"* (and). All stone inscriptions concur (the *Jinglong* stele writes *"豫"* for *"誉,"* as the two were interchangeable in antiquity). The two lines form a parallel structure.

*"Awed"* should be read as *"威"* (authority), as the two were interchangeable in antiquity, requiring no further proof. The *Guangya·Shigu* defines *"侮"* (scorn) as *"轻"* (disdain). *"Authority"* and *"scorn"* are semantically linked, just as *"cherished"* and *"praised"* in the preceding line are mutually reinforcing.

When trust is insufficient, distrust arises!
Yan Kejun notes: The Heshang and Wang Bi versions include *"焉"* (thus) after *"insufficient."* Wang Bi’s version also adds *"焉"* after *"distrust."* Wang Niansun states: The version without *"焉"* is correct. *"Trust is insufficient"* forms one phrase; *"thus distrust arises"* forms another. *"焉"* means *"thereupon"*—when trust is insufficient, distrust follows. The *Lüshi Chunqiu·Jichun* commentary states: *"焉* means *thereupon.*"* The *Pinli* records: *"At the feast, qi was emitted, thus filling the vessel."* That is, qi was emitted, *thereupon* filling the vessel. The *Zuozhuan·Jin Yu* states: *"焉 began issuing decrees,"* meaning *thereupon* decrees were issued.

Thus the *Questions of Three Years* states: "Therefore, the former kings *thereupon* established moderation and regulation." That is, the former kings *thereupon* established moderation and regulation for them. The *Guanzi·Kuidu* states: "When the people’s wealth is sufficient, the ruler’s levies *thereupon* know no end." That is, the levies *thereupon* know no end.

Later scholars, failing to grasp the meaning of *"焉"* (thereupon), mistakenly treated *"信不足焉"* ("trust is insufficient, thereupon") as a single phrase. Thus, they added another *"焉"* at the end of the following line to create parallelism, unaware of their error.

Qian Zhi notes: Wang’s interpretation is correct. However, while Wang recognized that the *"焉"* in the second line was superfluous, he did not suspect that the *"焉"* in the first line might also be an interpolation. The versions of the *Imperial Commentary*, Xing Xuan, Qingyang, Lou Zheng, Panxi, Gu Huan, Gao Di, and others all omit *"焉"* in both lines, matching this stele.

*"By its esteemed words."*
Yan Kejun notes: The *Imperial Commentary* writes *"由"* ("by") as *"犹"* ("still"), the *Heshang Gong* version as *"犹兮"* ("still, ah"), and Wang Bi’s as *"悠兮"* ("leisurely, ah"). Lu Deming states: *"悠"* ("leisurely") is written as *"由"* ("by") in the versions of Sun Deng, Zhang Ping, and Du Bi, with one variant reading *"犹"* ("still").

Qian Zhi notes: The *Imperial Commentary*, Xing Xuan, Qingyang, Panxi, Lou Zheng, Shichō, Gu Huan, Gao Di, Peng Si, and Fan Yingyuan all write *"犹"* ("still"). *"由"* ("by") and *"犹"* ("still") are interchangeable. The *Xunzi·Fuguo* states: *"由* (still) will not suffice to encourage them," with the commentary: "Interchangeable with *犹* (still)." The *Chuci* reads: *"尚由由而进之"* ("still hesitantly advancing"), with the commentary: "Meaning *犹豫* (hesitant)." In Chapter 15 of the *Laozi*, *"犹兮若畏四邻"* ("still, as if fearing the four neighbors") aligns in meaning with the *"由"* ("by") in *"由其贵言"* ("by its esteemed words"), both conveying a sense of leisurely contemplation. Thus, writing it as *"悠"* ("leisurely") is also semantically valid.

*"Success achieved, affairs completed, the hundred clans say: ‘We are naturally thus.’"*
Yan Kejun notes: Most versions read *"功成"* ("success achieved"), but the *Jingfu* and *Dunhuang Jia* versions read *"成功遂事"* ("success achieved, affairs completed"), which is preferable.

*"The hundred clans say: ‘We are naturally thus.’"* The *Heshang Gong* and Wang Bi versions include *"皆"* ("all") before *"谓"* ("say"). Fan Yingyuan’s version reads: *"百姓皆曰我自然"* ("the hundred clans all say: ‘We are naturally thus’"). The *Zhuangzi·Gengsang Chu*, in Guo Xiang’s commentary, cites it as *"而百姓皆谓我自尔"* ("and the hundred clans all say: ‘We are thus of ourselves’"). The *Jingxun Tang* version of Fu reads: *"百姓皆曰我不然"* ("the hundred clans all say: ‘We are not thus’"). The *Book of Jin·Wang Tanzhi* in *"On Abolishing Zhuangzi"* states: *"成功遂事，百姓皆曰我自然"* ("success achieved, affairs completed, the hundred clans all say: ‘We are naturally thus’"), matching the text of *Kaizen’s Exegesis of the Laozi* and the *Book of Jin*.

Song Xiangfeng notes: *"百姓皆谓我自然"* ("the hundred clans all say: ‘We are naturally thus’")—the *Baihutong·Haotian* states: "The Yellow Emperor ruled the world under the title *Ziran* (Naturally). *Ziran* means ‘solely vast and great virtue.’" Here, *"百姓皆谓我自然"* ("the hundred clans all say: ‘We are naturally thus’") directly quotes the Yellow Emperor’s words. The following line, *"希言自然"* ("sparse words are natural"), further elaborates on *ziran* (naturalness), stating: *"Thus, those who act in accordance with the Dao are one with the Dao; those who embody virtue are one with virtue."* This is the meaning of "vast and great virtue." Other texts mistakenly write *"有熊"* ("Youxiong"), likely a graphical error, as *Youxiong* lacks the connotation of "vast and great virtue." Moreover, the *Liezi* records the Yellow Emperor’s journey to the land of Huaxu, repeatedly stating *"自然而已"* ("merely natural"), confirming that *Ziran* (Naturally) was the Yellow Emperor’s title for ruling the world.

Qian Zhi notes: Song’s interpretation may not be definitive. However, since ancient times, the Yellow Emperor and Laozi have been paired, as in the *Lunheng·Ziran*: *"Huang refers to the Yellow Emperor; Lao refers to Laozi."* Both the Yellow Emperor and Laozi revered *ziran* (naturalness). The *Lunheng* cites the *"Song of Striking the Earth"*:
*"The sun rises, and I work;
The sun sets, and I rest.
I dig a well to drink,
I till the fields to eat—
What power does the emperor hold over me?"*
This is the essence of *ziran* (naturalness), which Laozi upheld. In Chapter 25: *"Man models himself on earth, earth on heaven, heaven on the Dao, and the Dao on ziran (naturalness)."* In Chapter 51: *"Nothing commands it, yet it is constantly ziran (natural)."* In Chapter 23: *"Sparse words are ziran (natural)."* In Chapter 64: *"To assist the self-transformation of the myriad things without daring to act."* From these passages, it is clear that Laozi’s teachings ultimately culminate in *ziran* (naturalness). Thus, the *Lunheng·Hantian* states: *"The Dao of heaven is ziran (natural); ziran (naturalness) is non-action."* The *Qian’gao* states: *"The schools of the Yellow Emperor and Laozi discuss the Dao of heaven and grasp its essence."*

**[Phonology]**
For this chapter, Jiang’s *Rhyme Readings* groups:
- *誉* (praise) and *侮* (disdain) as rhymes (the *yu* and *yu* rhymes intermingle; *誉* is a rising tone, *侮* rhymes with *武*),
- *焉* (thereupon), *言* (words), and *然* (thus) as rhymes (the *yuan* rhyme group).

Qian Zhi notes: *誉* belongs to the *yu* rhyme group, *侮* to the *yu* group, with *yu* and *yu* intermingling. Karlgren groups *信* (trust), *言* (words), and *然* (thus) as rhymes. Chen Zhu groups the four *"之"* as rhymes, and *有* (have), *誉* (praise), *畏* (fear), *侮* (disdain) as rhymes, with *焉* (thereupon), *焉* (thereupon), *言* (words), and *然* (thus) as rhymes. *誉* is phonetically linked to *与* (with), and *与* and *以* (by) were anciently interchangeable. *侮* is linked to *每* (each), and *每* to *母* (mother).

The *Jinglong Stele* version contains 38 characters; the *Dunhuang* version matches it. The *Heshang Gong* version has 40 characters, Wang Bi’s and Fan Yingyuan’s 44, and Fu’s 47. The *Heshang Gong* titles this chapter *"Pure Wind, Seventeenth,"* Wang Bi’s *"Chapter Seventeen,"* and Fan Yingyuan’s *"The Supreme, Chapter Seventeenth."*

---

**Chapter Eighteen**
When the great Dao declines, *ren* (benevolence) and *yi* (righteousness) arise.
When *zhi* (wisdom) and *hui* (discernment) emerge, great falsity appears.

Yan Kejun notes: Most versions read *"仁义"* ("benevolence and righteousness"), while Wang Bi writes *"智慧"* ("wisdom and discernment"), with some variants as *"慧知"* ("discernment and knowledge"), which is incorrect.

Yan Hongxuan states: *"When* zhi *and* hui *emerge, great falsity appears"*—Hongxuan notes that *"hui"* should be written as *"hui"* (discernment). The *Shiwen* edition reads *"zhihui"* (knowledge and discernment). The *Shuowen* states: *"Hui* (惠) means benevolence, composed of 'heart' and '○'."* *"Hui* (慧) means cleverness, composed of 'heart' and phonetic *hui* (彗)."* *"Hui"* (惠) and *"hui"* (慧) are not the same. In the *Analects*, *Wei Ling Gong* chapter, *"fond of practicing petty cleverness,"* the *Shiwen* notes: *"The Lu pronunciation reads* hui *as* hui." This is a case of loan characters.

Ji Yun remarks: *"Hui* (慧) and *hui* (惠) were interchangeable in antiquity." Qian Zhi notes: *"Fei* (癈) should be written as *fei* (废)." The *Jinglong* and *Guangming* editions both write *"fei"* (癈). The *Zijian* states: *"Fei* (废), pronounced *fang fei*, means 'a collapsed house' in the *Shuowen*, distinct from the character for disability." Also, *"ren yi"* (人义) should follow other editions as *"ren yi"* (仁义). The *Zhuangzi*, *Ma Ti* chapter, states: *"When the Dao and virtue are not abandoned, why seek benevolence and righteousness?"*—this is derived from here.

When the six relations are not in harmony, filial piety and compassion arise.

Yan Kejun states: *"Xiao ci"* (孝慈), the *Dayian* edition writes *"xiao zi"* (孝子). Luo Zhenyu remarks: In these three phrases—after *"fei"* (废), *"chu"* (出), and *"he"* (和)—the *Guangming* edition includes the character *"yan"* (焉). Below, *"When the state is in chaos, loyal ministers appear,"* after *"luan"* (乱), there must also have been a *"yan"* (焉), though the stone is too worn to confirm. Qian Zhi notes: The *Shichu* edition includes *"yan"* (焉), matching the *Guangming*, and also has *"yan"* (焉) after *"luan"* (乱).

*"Six relations"*—Wang Bi’s commentary: *"Father and son, elder and younger brothers, husband and wife."* The *Lüshi Chunqiu*, *Lun Ren* chapter, asks: *"What are the six kin?"* and answers: *"Father and mother, elder and younger brothers, wife and children."* The interpretation of *"xiao ci"* (孝慈) as two characters is correct. The *Zuozhuan*, *Zhao* 25th year, *Zhengyi*, and the *Shijing*, *Xiaoya Caiqi*, *Kong Yingda Zhengyi*, cite the *Laozi* with added and misordered characters, but the two characters *"xiao ci"* (孝慈) match this stele.

When the state is in chaos, loyal ministers appear.

Qian Zhi notes: The *Huainanzi*, *Daoying Xun*, cites this phrase identically. The Fan edition reads *"loyal and steadfast ministers"* with the character *"zhen"* (贞), matching Wang Bi’s edition. Minagawa Kien’s edition writes *"loyal and trustworthy"* (忠信), pairing it with the above *"filial piety and compassion"* (孝慈). Also, the character *"hun"* (昏): the Song-printed *Heshang Gong* edition, Zhao Mengfu’s edition, and Lou Zheng’s edition write it as *"𣅔"*, while the *Dunhuang*, *Suichuan*, various Wang editions, Fu, and Fan editions all write *"hun"* (昏). The *Shuowen* states: *"Hun* (昏) means 'darkness at dusk,' composed of 'sun' and a reduced *di* (氐); one says it is phonetic *min* (民)."* Duan Yucai’s *Kuangmiu* cites Dai Tong’s *Liu Shu Gu*: *"The Tang edition of the* Shuowen *uses a reduced* min *(民), while Xu’s edition uses a reduced* shi *(氏). Chao Yuezhi said this was because the Tang tabooed* min *and changed it to* shi. *Thus, the original* Shuowen *wrote* 𣅔*, composed of 'sun' and phonetic* min *(民). The Tang edition, to avoid the taboo, reduced one stroke, hence 'composed of a reduced* min'."* Ding Zhongyou states: *"Examining Han steles,* 𣅔 *is the standard character,* hun *a variant. ... The* Old Tang Book*, *Gaozong Ji*, records that in the twelfth month of Xianqing 2, the character* 𣅔 *was changed to* hun *(昏). From this, we know* 𣅔 *was altered to the variant* hun *to avoid the temple name taboo. Observing pre-Xianqing Wei steles, all* 𣅔 *use* min *(民), while post-Xianqing Tang steles, to avoid the taboo, all write* hun *(昏)."* (*Shuowen Jiezi Gulin*, *Chen Ji*, *Ri* section)

**[Phonology]**
This chapter, according to Jiang Yong’s *Yun Du*, has no rhyme. Yao Wentian: *"Yi* (义) and *wei* (伪) rhyme (eleven *ma* departing tone)." Deng Tingzhen: *"Fei* (废) and *chu* (出) also rhyme." Deng states: *"Chu* (出) in ancient pronunciation reads like *Yi Ding*’s *Chu Liu* (鼎颠趾, 利出否) *chu* (出). *Wei* (伪) in ancient pronunciation reads like *e* (讹). The* Shangshu*, *Yao Dian*, reads *ping zhe nan e* (平秩南讹), while the* Hanshu*, *Wang Mang Zhuan*, writes *nan wei* (南伪)." Gao Buhan: *"Fei* (废), *yi* (义), *chu* (出), and *wei* (伪) rhyme in alternating lines; *luan* (乱) and *chen* (臣) rhyme." Qian Zhi notes: *"Yi* (义) in antiquity was universally pronounced *e* (俄). The* Hong Fan *reads *wu pian wu po, zun wang zhi yi* (无偏无颇，遵王之义), and Emperor Xuanzong of Tang changed *po* (颇) to *bei* (陂). His edict briefly states: *'I have pondered this phrase thrice and always found it grounded. According to the following text, all rhyme, except for* po *(颇), which truly disrupts the harmony. It should be changed to* bei *(陂).'* Wu Yu states: *'The ancient character* yi *(义) was universally pronounced* e *(俄). The* Zhouli *commentary also reads* e *(俄). Thus, the ancient* Shangshu *wrote* wu pian wu po, zun wang zhi yi *(无偏无颇，遵王之义) to rhyme with* e *(俄). Emperor Ming of Tang, taking* yi *(义) in modern pronunciation as* yi *(乂), changed* po *(颇) to* bei *(陂) to conform to modern pronunciation, and the ancient pronunciation was thus lost.' Now, evidence from the* Yi*: *'The cauldron’s handle is altered, losing its* yi *(义); the duke’s gruel is overturned—how trustworthy is that?' The* Zhongyong *states: *'Ren* (仁) *is humanity;* yi *(义) is appropriateness.' From this, we know that in this chapter of the* Laozi*,* yi *(义) should also be pronounced* e *(俄). As for* wei *(伪), the* Zhuangzi*, *Zhi Beiyou*, states: *'Ren* (仁) *can be enacted,* yi *(义) can be diminished, and ritual is mutual falsity.'* Wei *(伪) also belongs to the* ge *rhyme group, rhyming with* wei *(为) and* kui *(亏). Gu Yanwu states: *'The* Shijing *reads* min zhi e yan *(民之讹言), while the Stone Classics write* wei yan *(伪言). The* Hanshu*, *Wang Mang Zhuan*, reads* yi nan wei *(以劝南伪), and Yan Shigu notes: 'Read as* e *(讹).' Guo Pu’s* Fangyan *commentary reads* wei yan e *(伪言讹).' From this, we know* yi *(义) and* wei *(伪) rhyme. Ma Xulun’s* Maoshi Zhengyun Houxu *states: *'In this chapter,* da *(大),* zhi *(智),* liu *(六), and* guo *(国) rhyme at the beginning of the upper lines, while* fei *(废),* chu *(出),* he *(和), and* luan *(乱) rhyme at the end of the upper lines.'"

Moreover, it is not merely that *yi* (义) and *wei* (伪) serve as rhymes at the ends of lines.

The Jinglong stele version contains twenty-six characters; the Dunhuang, He [Shangong], and Wang [Bi] versions are the same. The Fu [Yi] version has twenty-eight characters, and the Fan [Yingyuan] version thirty. The He Shangong version titles this "Vulgar Shallowness, Chapter Eighteen," the Wang [Bi] version "Chapter Eighteen," and the Fan [Yingyuan] version "The Chapter on the Abandonment of the Great Dao, Eighteen."

**Chapter Nineteen**
Abandon sagacity, discard wisdom, and the people will benefit a hundredfold;
Ji Yun notes: The *Yongle Dadian* places the two lines "Abandon sagacity" after the two lines "Abandon benevolence."
Takeuchi Yoshio states: The Suizhou version writes *min* (民) as *ren* (人), likely to avoid the Tang taboo.
Wei Jiasun notes: In the imperial commentary, "wisdom" (*zhi*, 智) is written as "knowledge" (*zhi*, 知) for the phrase "Abandon sagacity, discard wisdom."
Qian [Zhi] observes: The Suizhou, Fu [Yi], and Fan [Yingyuan] versions also write "knowledge" (*zhi*, 知); the Fan version writes "discard" (*qi*, 弃) as *qi* (弃), and the next two lines follow suit. The *Zhuangzi*, *Qu Qie* chapter, reads: "Thus, abandon sagacity, discard knowledge, and great thieves will cease"; the *Zai You* chapter reads: "Abandon sagacity, discard knowledge, and the world will be greatly ordered"—both write "knowledge" (*zhi*, 知). The *Huainanzi*, *Dao Ying Xun*, cites the *Laozi* as writing "wisdom" (*zhi*, 智).
Abandon benevolence, discard righteousness, and the people will return to filial piety and compassion;
Abandon skill, discard profit, and thieves and bandits will be no more.
Yan Kejun states: "Abandon benevolence" (*jue ren*, 绝仁) appears as "abandon the people" (*jue min*, 绝民) in all other versions.
Qian [Zhi] observes: The character *min* (民) is an error arising from the repetition of *min* in the surrounding text.
These three, being insufficient as cultural adornments, thus necessitate attachment to something else.
Wei Jiasun notes: The imperial commentary includes the character *yi* (以) before "being" (*wei*, 为).
Luo Zhenyu states: Neither the Jinglong nor Jingfu versions include the character *yi* (以).
Takeuchi Yoshio states: The Suizhou version reads "These three sayings are as cultural adornments" (*ci san zhe yan wei*, 此三者言为), the Jing version "These three are as cultural adornments" (*ci san zhe wei*, 此三者为), and the Dunhuang version "These three sayings are as cultural adornments" (*ci san yan wei*, 此三言为).
Qian [Zhi] observes: The Fan version omits the character *ci* (此); the Fu version writes "insufficient" (*bu zu*, 不足) as "not yet" (*wei zu*, 未足); the Fu and Fan versions include the character *ye* (也) after "sufficient" (*zu*, 足). Furthermore, the *Qunshu Zhiyao*, Volume 34, cites the line "thieves and bandits will be no more" and immediately follows with "as cultural adornments are insufficient, manifest plainness, embrace simplicity, reduce selfishness, and diminish desires," omitting the eight characters "these three" (*ci san zhe*, 此三者) and "thus necessitate attachment to something else" (*gu ling you suo shu*, 故令有所属). It is suspected that these were marginal notes mistakenly incorporated into the main text.
Yu Xingwu states: Now, *wei* (为) and *wei* (伪) were interchangeable in antiquity. The *Book of Documents*, *Yao Dian*, reads "to regulate the southern *wei* (伪)"; the *Records of the Grand Historian*, *Annals of the Five Emperors*, writes "southern *wei* (为)." The *Record of Rites*, *Monthly Ordinances*, reads "do not create excessive skill," with a note: "In the current *Monthly Ordinances*, 'create' (*zuo wei*, 作为) is written as 'deceitful *wei*' (*zha wei*, 诈伪)." "Cultural adornment" (*wen*, 文) should be read as in the *Xunzi*, *Ruxiao*: "select what is correct and adorn it" (*qu shi er wen zhi ye*, 取是而文之也)—*wen* means "to embellish." "These three" refers to sagacity and wisdom, benevolence and righteousness, skill and profit. "With deceit, embellish what is insufficient" (*yi wei wen bu zu*, 以伪文不足) means to use deceit to embellish what is lacking. The following lines, "thus necessitate attachment to something else, manifest plainness, embrace simplicity, reduce selfishness, and diminish desires," all indicate that one should not engage in deceitful embellishment. Abandon it there and attach it here—this is the original meaning of the *Laozi*.
Manifest plainness, embrace simplicity, reduce selfishness, and diminish desires.
Qian [Zhi] observes: The character *pu* (朴) in the He Shangong, Gu [Yanwu], and Fan [Yingyuan] versions matches this stele. The Wang Bi and Fu Yi versions write *pu* (朴), while the imperial commentary writes *pu* (扑).
Bi Yuan states: "*Pu* (朴) is sometimes written as *pu* (朴)—both are the same."
Liu Shipei states: Now, *si* (私) should be written as *si* (思). The *Hanfeizi*, *Jie Lao* chapter, reads: "All virtue is gathered through non-action, completed through desirelessness, stabilized through non-thinking, and solidified through non-use." "Thinking" (*si*, 思) and "desire" (*yu*, 欲) are mentioned together. Furthermore, the *Wen Xuan*, Li Shan’s commentary on Xie Lingyun’s *Fangshan* poem, cites the *Laozi*: "Reduce thinking, diminish desires." This is evidence that the ancient text wrote *si* (思), which explains "reduce thinking" here.
Qian [Zhi] observes: *Si* (私) was originally written as *si* (思). The Tang-era *Wang Zhen Lun Bing Yao Yi Shu*, the *Qiang Si Qi* version, the Song-era Chen Xianggu version, and the Yuan-era *Da De San Nian* stele at the Panxi Palace in Baoji County, Shaanxi, all write *si* (思) instead of *si* (私)—this is the evidence. Only the *Zhuangzi*, *Shan Mu* chapter, reads: "Their people are foolish and simple, reduce selfishness, and diminish desires," matching this stele. The He Shangong commentary on "reduce selfishness" states: "Truly without selfishness," which aligns with the meaning of Chapter Seven of the *Laozi*: "Is it not because they are without selfishness that they can perfect their selfishness?" Interpreting the *Laozi* with the *Laozi* itself, we know that Liu’s theory, while plausible, cannot be taken as definitive.

**Phonology**
For this chapter, Jiang [Yong]’s *Rhyming Readings* groups the rhymes as follows: *bei* (倍), *ci* (慈), and *you* (有) (in the *zhi* 部, with *bei* pronounced as *pi*, and *ci* in the falling tone). *Zu* (足), *shu* (属), *pu* (朴), and *yu* (欲) rhyme (in the *hou* 部). Yao Wentian and Deng Tingzhen concur. Gao Heng argues that the line "Abandon learning and have no worries" should belong to this chapter, rhyming *zu* (足), *shu* (属), *pu* (朴), *yu* (欲), and *you* (忧). Now, *you* (忧) belongs to the *you* 部, which harmonizes with the *hou* 部. Deng Tingzhen states: *Bei* (倍), *ci* (慈), and *you* (有) form a rhyme. Characters with the sounds *sheng* (声), *zi* (兹), and *you* (有) were classified under the *zhi* 部 in ancient phonology. The *Shijing*, *Zhan Ang*, reads: "Like a merchant’s threefold profit," rhyming with "women have no public affairs."

The Jinglong stele version contains forty-four characters; the Dunhuang version is the same. The He [Shangong], Wang [Bi], and Fan [Yingyuan] versions have forty-five characters, while the Fu [Yi] version has forty-seven. The He Shangong version titles this "Returning to Simplicity," the Wang [Bi] version "Chapter Nineteen," and the Fan [Yingyuan] version "The Chapter on Abandoning Sagacity and Discarding Wisdom, Nineteen."

Chapter Twenty: Abandon Learning and Be Without Care

Yi Shunding states: The *Wenzi* cites "Abandon learning and be without care" above "Abandon sagacity and discard wisdom," suggesting the ancient text was thus arranged. This aligns with the three instances of "abandon" sharing the same meaning. Yet in the present version, it appears above the line "Only 'yes' and 'flattery'," where its meaning seems misplaced.

Ma Xulun says: The line "Abandon learning and be without care" should belong to the preceding chapter. He further notes: Chao Gongwu’s *Dushu Ji* cites the Minghuang edition, which also appends "Abandon learning and be without care" to the end of the former Chapter Nineteen.

Jiang Xichang argues: Judging by the text’s logic, this line should belong to the preceding chapter, serving as the conclusion to the passage "Abandon sagacity and discard wisdom, abandon benevolence and discard righteousness, abandon cunning and discard profit."

Chao Gongwu’s *Junzhai Dushu Zhi* records that the Tang-era Zhang Junxiang’s *Thirty Commentaries on the Laozi* attaches "Abandon learning and be without care" to the end of the "Abandon sagacity and discard wisdom" chapter, treating "Only 'yes' and 'flattery'" as a separate chapter—a division differing from other versions, yet one that should be followed. Later, Gui Youguang and Yao Nai also assigned this chapter to the preceding one, which is correct.

Li Dafang states: The line "Abandon learning and be without care" cannot be severed and assigned to the following chapter. For the three lines—"Manifest plainness and embrace simplicity, reduce selfishness and diminish desire, abandon learning and be without care"—follow the preceding sentence "These three, as literary expressions, are insufficient, hence they are given something to belong to." "Manifest plainness and embrace simplicity" corresponds to the two lines on "abandoning benevolence"; "reduce selfishness and diminish desire" corresponds to the two lines on "abandoning cunning"; and "abandon learning and be without care" corresponds to the two lines on "abandoning sagacity." The line "These three, as literary expressions, are insufficient" summarizes the preceding text, while "hence they are given something to belong to" introduces what follows. The structure is clear, leaving no room for doubt.

Only "yes" and "flattery"—how far apart are they?
Goodness and evil—how distant are they?

Wu Cheng says: Both "yes" (*wei*) and "flattery" (*a*) are responsive sounds—*wei* is upright and compliant, while *a* is devious and obsequious. "How far apart" (*jihe*) means they are not far removed from each other.

Liu Shipei argues: *A* should be written as *he* (呵). The *Shuowen* states: "He: to speak loudly in anger." The *Guangya Shigu* defines *he* as "anger." The vulgar form of *he* is *he* (呵). The *Hanshu Shihuo Zhi* reads: "Bound yet not rebuked," with Yan Shigu’s note: "To reproach in anger." Thus, *wei* is an affirmative response, while *he* is a word of reproach. Human anger arises from what one rejects, so Laozi, to rhyme with *he* below, substitutes *he* for *fou* (否). "Only 'yes' and 'flattery'" thus means "compliance and opposition."

Wu Nei Yixiong states: The Dunhuang and Suizhou versions write "good" (*shan*) as "beauty" (*mei*).

Yi Shunding says: The Wang Bi edition reads "beauty and evil—how distant are they," matching the Fu Yi version. The commentary notes: "Only 'yes' and 'flattery,' beauty and evil—how distant are they," confirming this. The current text’s "how distant" (*ruohe*) is not the original Wang Bi reading.

Jiang Xichang says: Gu Huan’s *Chengshi* commentary glosses "compliance as beauty, opposition as evil," indicating Cheng wrote *mei* (beauty). In Chapter Two, "When all under heaven know beauty as beauty, this is evil," both instances pair beauty and evil. The Fu Yi version writes *shan* (good) as *mei* (beauty), which should be followed. Here, *a*, *he*, *e* (evil), and *ruo* (distant) form a rhyme; the received texts’ "how distant" (*ruohe*) should be amended to "distant how" (*he ruo*), which should also be adopted.

Yan Kejun says: "How distant are they" (*xiang qu he ruo*)—Wang Bi may have written "distant how" (*ruo he*), which is incorrect.

What people fear cannot but be feared.

Sun Kuang’s *Gu Jin Ben Kao Zheng* notes: "Cannot" (*bu ke*) is also written as "dare not" (*bu gan*).

Qian Zhi observes: The *Huainanzi Dao Ying Xun* cites the preceding two lines, matching this stele.

Vast and boundless, its end not yet reached!

Wei Jiasun says: Between "vast" (*mang*) and "its" (*qi*), the original has a blank space—either awaiting carving, an error in chapter division, or a strict adherence to line spacing. Later, between the two "pure" (*chun*) characters, there is also a gap, following the example of the first line on the stele’s reverse. It is suspected that due to a flaw in the stone, the text was written continuously, and the space after *mang* was left intact.

Qian Zhi observes: The blank after *mang* is neither a damaged character nor a chapter division but likely an uncarved *xi* (兮).

Yan Kejun says: The *Yu Zhu* edition writes "vast" (*huang*) as *mang*. The Heshang Gong and Wang Bi versions include *xi* (兮) after *huang* and *zai* (哉) at the end of the sentence.

Wu Yun says: The Xing edition writes *huang* (荒) as *mang* (莽).

Wang Lanquan suspects it is a corruption of *huang*.

Qian Zhi observes: The Guangming and Muromachi editions write *huang*, while the stele writes *mang*. *Mang* is interchangeable with *mang* (茫), actually *mang* (芒), borrowed for *huang* (荒), the modern *mang* (茫). The *Shijing Chang Fa* reads: "The great waters, vast and boundless," and the *Xuan Niao* reads: "Dwelling in the Yin lands, vast and boundless," with the *Zhuan* glossing it as "a great appearance." The *Zuozhuan Xiang Si* reads: "The distant traces of Yu, vast and boundless," with the note: "A distant appearance." The *Huainanzi Chu Zhen* reads: "Its Dao, vast and obscure," with the note: "A broad and great appearance." The *Tan Shi Fu* reads: "Why gaze at the heavens, so vast and boundless," with the note: "Like *mengmeng* (梦梦)." The *Zhuangzi Da Zong Shi* reads: "Vast and wandering beyond the dust and grime," with the *Shiwen* glossing it as "a boundless appearance." The Suizhou stele writes *mang* (莽), likely because "grass grows deep" is called *mang*, sharing with *mang* the sense of vast, boundless, and distant.

The *Xiao Er Ya Guang Yu* states: "Mang (莽) means great." The *Lüshi Chunqiu Zhi Jie* reads: "Why is it so *mangmang* (莽莽)?" with the note: "An appearance of great length." The *Zhuangzi Xiaoyaoyou* reads: "Those who travel to the *mangcang* (莽苍)," with Cui’s annotation: "The color of the wild grasslands." The meanings of *mang* (忙), *mang* (莽), and *huang* (荒) are closely related.

"All people bustle joyfully, as if partaking in a grand feast." Ma Xulun notes: "*Xi* (熙) is a loan character for *xi* (媐)." The *Shuowen* states: "*Xi* (媐) means joyful delight." Qian Zhi observes: "*Xixi* (熙熙) here shares the same meaning as *xi* (熙) in the *Zhuangzi Ma Ti* chapter: 'chewing their food and *xi* (熙),' and in the *Liezi Yang Zhu* chapter: '*xixi* (熙熙) while awaiting death.'" *Xixi* (熙熙) is equivalent to *xixi* (嘻嘻). The *Shu Chao* (Vol. 15) cites the *Zhuangzi* with *xi* (熙) written as *xi* (嘻), while the *Chuxue Ji* (Vol. 9) and *Shiwen Leiju* (Posterior Collection, Vol. 20) both write it as *xi* (嬉). The *Yanzi Chunqiu* (Vol. 6) originally reads: "The sage is not one to *xi* (嬉) with." *Xi* (熙), *xi* (嘻), and *xi* (嬉) share the same meaning; thus, "all people *xixi* (熙熙)" is to say all people *xixi* (嘻嘻).

Yan Kejun states: "'As if partaking in a grand feast'—*lao* () is a variant character." The imperial commentary writes "as if feasting (*ru xiang* 如享)," while the *Shiwen* writes "as if boiling (*ruo heng* 若亨)," citing the *Heshang Gong* version as "as if offering (*xiang* 飨)." Qian Zhi notes: The Suizhou edition mistakenly writes "grand minister (*da zai* 大宰)" instead of "grand feast (*tai lao* 太牢)." The *Yiwen Leiju* (Vol. 3) cites the *Heshang Gong* version as "as if feasting (*ruo xiang* 若享)," while the *Yuzhu Baodian* (Vol. 3) cites it as "and feasting (*er xiang* 而飨)." Takeuchi Yoshio states: "As if boiling a grand feast (*ruo heng tai lao* 若亨太牢)"—the Wang Bi edition writes *heng* (亨), which Lu Deming reads as "boiling (*peng* 烹)." The *Heshang Gong* reads it as "feasting (*xiang* 享)" and further alters *heng* (亨) to *xiang* (飨). Current editions of the *Heshang Gong* and Wang Bi versions both write "feasting (*xiang* 享)." The *Yuzhu Baodian* (Vol. 3) cites this passage as "feasting (*xiang* 飨)," aligning with Lu’s citation of the *Heshang Gong* version. Thus, the single character *heng* (亨) has been variously interpreted, leading to divergent versions of the text.

"Like ascending a terrace in spring." Yan Kejun states: The imperial commentary and Wang Bi edition write "like ascending a terrace in spring (*ru chun deng tai* 如春登台)," while the *Heshang Gong* writes "like ascending a spring terrace (*ru deng chun tai* 如登春台)." Bi Yuan notes: "Like ascending a terrace in spring (*ru chun deng tai* 如春登台)"—the Wang Bi and Gu Huan editions both concur, as do the Tang *Minghuang* edition and the Yizhou stone inscriptions. The *Daozang* edition published in the tenth year of the Zhengtong reign (1445) of the Ming dynasty first erroneously writes "ascending a spring terrace (*deng chun tai* 登春台)," followed by the Lu Xisheng and Wang Zhen editions, and now all popular editions replicate this error. Additionally, Li Shan’s commentary on the *Xianju Fu* also errs in this regard.

Yu Yue states: The phrase "like ascending a terrace in spring (*ru chun deng tai* 如春登台)" follows the same structure as the fifteenth chapter’s "like fording a river in winter (*ruo dong she chuan* 若冬涉川)." The *Heshang Gong* version, "like ascending a spring terrace (*ru deng chun tai* 如登春台)," is incorrect. However, its commentary states: "In spring, Yin and Yang interact, and the myriad things are stirred; ascending a terrace to observe them, one’s will is deeply moved." This suggests that the commentary did not originally treat "spring terrace" as a single phrase. The edition it relied upon must have read "ascending a terrace in spring (*chun deng tai* 春登台)," and the present transmission has merely inverted the characters.

Jiang Xichang states: The *Daode Zhenjing Xuande Zuan Shu* by Tang scholar Qiang Siqui cites the *Heshang Gong* version of the text as "like ascending a terrace in spring (*ru chun deng tai* 如春登台)," which precisely matches the Song *Heshang Gong* edition. Yu Yue’s assertion that the *Heshang Gong* edition must have originally read "ascending a terrace in spring (*chun deng tai* 春登台)" is correct. The *Cheng* commentary in the Gu edition states: "And like ascending a terrace in spring (*you ru chun ri deng tai* 又如春日登台)," indicating that Cheng also wrote "like ascending a terrace in spring (*ru chun deng tai* 如春登台)." ...The Wang Bi edition, *Heshang Gong* edition, and various stone inscriptions all write "ascending a terrace in spring (*chun deng tai* 春登台)." This appears to be the ancient version, and it seems unwarranted to arbitrarily alter it based on later editions.

The character "like" (*ru* 如) should follow the stele edition’s "as if" (*ruo* 若) to maintain parallelism with the preceding sentence. The *Shiwen* writes "as if" (*ruo* 若) in the previous sentence, and this should be consistent.

My *po* unmanifested—

Yan Kejun notes: The *Imperial Commentary* reads "I alone fear its unmanifestation" (*wo du pa qi wei zhao* 我獨怕其未兆), while the *Heshang Gong* edition has "I alone fear, ah, its unmanifestation" (*wo du pa xi qi wei zhao* 我獨怕兮其未兆). The *Shiwen* writes "vast" (*kuo* 廓), citing *Heshang Gong* as "tranquil" (*bo* 泊). Fu Yi’s edition reads "My *po* alone, ah, its unmanifestation" (*wo du po xi qi wei zhao* 我獨魄兮其未兆), and the *Dayian* edition has "I, tranquil, ah, its unmanifestation" (*wo bo xi qi wei zhao* 我泊兮其未兆). Wang’s edition, citing the Xingzhou version, matches this. Lu Wenchang states: The modern text reads "I alone, tranquil, ah, its unmanifestation" (*wo du bo xi qi wei zhao* 我獨泊兮其未兆), while Wang Bi’s edition writes "vast" (*kuo* 廓) for "tranquil" (*bo* 泊), and the Zang edition has "fear" (*pa* 怕). The *Shuowen* states: "Fear (*pa* 怕) means non-action." The Zang edition is correct. Now Wang Bi’s edition writes "tranquil" (*bo* 泊), while the ancient editions have "*po*" (*po* 魄). Luo Zhenyu notes: The *Jingfu* and *Yinglun* editions both read "fear" (*pa* 怕). Hong Yixuan comments: "I alone fear, ah, its unmanifestation" (*wo du pa xi qi wei zhao* 我獨怕兮其未兆), with *Heshang Gong*’s annotation: "I alone am fearfully still, without the manifest signs of quiet desires." Yixuan observes: The *Shuowen* defines "fear" (*pa* 怕) as "non-action, from the heart, pronounced *bai*," its meaning derived from this. Vulgar editions write the character "tranquil" (*bo* 泊), which is incorrect. Qian Zhi notes: The modern text’s "tranquil" (*bo* 泊) and "*po*" (*po* 魄) share a phonetic gloss. The *Records of the Grand Historian*, in the biography of Li Yiji, writes "fallen and *po*" (*luo po* 落魄) as "fallen and tranquil" (*luo bo* 落泊). Similarly, "tiger *po*" (*hu po* 虎魄) is written as "amber" (*hu po* 珀). The *Guoyu*, in the *Jin Yu*, states: "Its *po* is manifest among the people," with Wei Zhao’s annotation: "Manifest (*zhao* 兆) means visible." Here, "my *po* unmanifested" (*wo po wei zhao* 我魄未兆) conveys the meaning of fear in non-action. Like an infant yet to laugh.

Yan Kejun states: All editions read "like an infant yet to laugh" (*ru ying er zhi wei hai* 如嬰兒之未孩). Bi Yuan notes: *Heshang Gong* and Wang Bi write "like" (*ru* 如) as "as if" (*ruo* 若). The character "laugh" (*hai* 咳) is written as "infant" (*hai* 孩) in *Heshang Gong*. The *Shuowen Jiezi* states: "Laugh (*hai* 咳) is the seal script form of infant (*hai* 孩)." The ancient scripts are identical. Lao Jian comments: "Like an infant yet to laugh" (*ru ying er zhi wei ke* 如嬰兒之未咳), the character "laugh" (*ke* 咳) appears as "infant" (*hai* 孩) in the *Jinglong* and *Kaiyuan* editions. Fu, Fan, and *Jingfu* editions, along with the *Shiwen*, all write "laugh" (*ke* 咳). Fan’s annotation: "Laugh (*ke* 咳), pronounced *he lai*. Zhang Xuanjing’s edition matches the ancient version." The *Jiyun* universally writes "infant" (*hai* 孩). Note that "infant" (*hai* 孩) is the ancient form of "laugh" (*ke* 咳). Qian Zhi notes: The *Shuowen*’s section on "child" lacks the character "infant" (*hai* 孩), which appears under the "mouth" section for "laugh" (*ke* 咳). The *Guangyun* defines "infant" (*hai* 孩) as "a newborn child" and "laugh" (*ke* 咳) as "a child’s laughter," both pronounced *hu lai*.
