The *Leipian* states: "Infant (*hai* 孩) and laugh (*ke* 咳) are the same, meaning a child’s laughter." "Infant" (*hai* 孩) and "laugh" (*ke* 咳) were originally one character. Fu and Fan’s editions write "laugh" (*ke* 咳), with identical pronunciation and meaning. The *Shiwen* includes the character "laugh" (*ke* 咳), indicating Wang’s edition wrote "laugh" (*ke* 咳). The *Jingfu* and *Shimachō* editions also write "laugh" (*ke* 咳).

Adrift, as if with no place to return!

Yan Kejun notes: *Heshang Gong* includes the characters "ah, like" (*xi ruo* 兮若) after "adrift" (*cheng cheng* 乘乘). Wang Bi’s edition reads "weary, ah, as if with no place to return" (*lei lei xi ruo wu suo gui* 儽儽兮若無所歸). Qian Zhi notes: Fu Yi’s edition reads "weary, ah, its insufficiency, with no place to return" (*lei lei xi qi bu zu yi wu suo gui* 儡儡兮其不足以無所歸), while Fan’s edition has "weary, ah, as if insufficient, seemingly with no place to return" (*lei lei xi qi ruo bu zu si wu suo gui* 儽儽兮其若不足似無所歸). The Suzhou and Gu Huan editions read "stalwart, with no place to return" (*kui wu suo gui* 魁無所歸). The *Jingfu*, *Louzheng*, *Xingxuan*, *Panxi*, and *Yinglun* editions all write "adrift, ah, as if with no place to return" (*cheng cheng xi ruo wu suo gui* 乘乘兮若無所歸). Zhu Junsheng states: In the *Shuowen*, "weary" (*lei* 儽) means "a drooping appearance. Also said to mean lazy and slack, from *ren* 人 and *lei* 累 phonetic." It differs slightly from "weary" (*lei* 儡). The character is also written as "weary" (*lei* 儽), and is mistakenly written as "○." The *Guangya*, in *Shigu* 2, states: "○ means labor." The *Shi Xun* reads: "○○ means fatigue." In the *Laozi*, "○○, ah, as if with no place to return" (*○○兮若無所歸*), the *Shiwen* annotates: "Defeated, also scattered." *Heshang Gong*’s edition writes "adrift" (*cheng cheng* 乘乘), an error for "drooping" (*chui chui* 垂垂). Takeuchi Yoshio states: Wang’s edition reads "weary, ah" (*lei lei xi* 儽儽兮), while the old manuscript *Heshang Gong* has "weary, ah" (*lei lei xi* 儡儡兮), and the *Jinglong* stele writes "adrift, ah" (*cheng cheng xi* 乘乘兮). Since "weary" (*lei* 儽) and "weary" (*lei* 儡) share the same sound, and the *Shuowen* defines "weary, weary" (*lei lei* 儽儽) as "a drooping appearance," it does not align with "adrift" (*cheng cheng* 乘乘) in sound or meaning. I suspect "adrift" (*cheng cheng* 乘乘) is a corruption of "drooping" (*chui chui* 垂垂). If so, *Heshang Gong*’s edition originally wrote "weary, weary" (*lei lei* 儡儡), and its gloss interprets it as the character "droop" (*chui* 垂).

All people have abundance; I alone seem lacking.

Yan Kejun notes: *Heshang Gong* includes the character "yet" (*er* 而) before "I" (*wo* 我). Luo Zhenyu notes: The *Jinglong* and *Imperial Commentary* editions both omit "yet" (*er* 而). Xi Tong states: "Lacking" (*yi* 遺) is borrowed for "insufficient" (*kui* 匱), meaning inadequacy. The *Liji*, in the *Ji Yi*, reads "and in old age, not lacking" (*er qiong lao bu yi* 而窮老不遺), with the *Shiwen* noting: "Lacking (*yi* 遺) is written as insufficient (*kui* 匱)," which serves as evidence. Yu Xingwu states: "Lacking" (*yi* 遺) should be read as "insufficient" (*kui* 匱). Both characters rhyme with *gui* 貴, and their sounds are close, making them interchangeable. ...The *Guangya*, in *Shigu*, states: "Insufficient (*kui* 匱) means increase." Wang Niansun argues that "insufficient" (*kui* 匱) should be "lacking" (*yi* 遺), as "lacking" has the sense of increase, while "insufficient" does not. The *Liji*, in the *Yue Ji*, reads "its resources insufficient" (*qi cai kui* 其財匱), with the *Shiwen* annotating: "Insufficient (*kui* 匱) means lacking." "All people have abundance, yet I alone seem insufficient" (*zhong ren jie you yu er wo du ruo kui* 衆人皆有餘而我獨若匱) contrasts "insufficient" (*kui* 匱) with "abundance" (*yu* 餘) as parallel phrases. Previous interpreters have all read "lacking" (*yi* 遺) literally, forcing an explanation of loss.

My heart is that of a fool—so muddled.

Yan Kejun notes: *Heshang Gong* and Wang Bi include the characters "also, alas" (*ye zai* 也哉) after "heart" (*xin* 心). For "muddled" (*chun chun* 純純), *Heshang Gong* and Wang Bi write "chaotic, ah" (*dun dun xi* 沌沌兮), with the *Shiwen* noting: "Chaotic (*dun* 沌) is also written as *tun* 忳."

Bì Yuǎn states: Wang Bi follows *Heshang Gong* in writing "pure" (*chún* 纯), and the text of Sū Língzhī also reads "pure." The reading "pure" is correct. Lù Démíng notes: "Originally also written as *tún* 忳." Yet both "chaotic" (*dùn* 沌) and *tún* 忳 are incorrect.

Qiān Zhī observes: The reading "pure" (*chún* 纯) is correct. The *Yi Jing*'s *Wen Yan* states, "Pure and refined is essence" (*chún cuì jīng yě* 纯粹精也), with Cuī Jìn’s commentary: "Unmixed is called pure" (*bù zá yuē chún* 不杂曰纯). The *Huainanzi*'s *Yaolüe* reads, "Not cleaved or divided, pure and uncarved" (*bù pōu pàn chún pǔ* 不剖判纯朴), with the annotation: "Pure and uncarved is primordial simplicity" (*chún pǔ tài sù yě* 纯朴，太素也). The stele edition writes "pure, pure" (*chún chún* 纯纯), while the Muromachi edition has "chaotic, chaotic" (*dùn dùn* 沌沌), though the meaning is the same. The *Zhuangzi*'s *Shan Mu* chapter states: "Pure and constant, one is likened to madness" (*chún chún cháng cháng nǎi bǐ yú kuáng* 纯纯常常，乃比于狂). Its *Zai You* chapter reads: "Chaotic and undifferentiated, never departing for a lifetime" (*hún hún dùn dùn zhōng shēn bù lí* 浑浑沌沌，终身不离). Thus, *chún chún* 纯纯 is the same as *dùn dùn* 沌沌. Péng Sǒng’s *Shiwen* notes: "Lǐ reads *chún chún* 纯纯 literally, as a term for simplicity and desirelessness." His interpretation is sound.

The common people are bright and clear; I alone seem dim.

Yan Kejun states: Wang Bi writes "I alone am dim-dim" (*wú dú hūn hūn* 我独昏昏). Xi Di says: "*Hūn hūn* 昏昏" appears in all other editions as "*ruò hūn* 若昏," but the syntax is discordant; here we follow Wang Bi’s version. The *Zhuangzi*’s *Zai You* chapter reads: "The utmost extremity of the supreme Dao is dim and silent" (*zhì dào zhī jí, hūn hūn mò mò* 至道之极，昏昏默默). Jiang Xichang says: Judging by the meaning of the text, the version with *hūn hūn* 昏昏 is correct. Below, Wang Bi’s commentary—"without desire to act, muddled and unclear, as if knowing nothing"—confirms that the ancient text of the *Laozi* read *hūn hūn* 昏昏, not *ruò hūn* 若昏. *Hūn hūn* 昏昏 is the opposite of *zhāo zhāo* 昭昭.

The common people are sharp and discerning; I alone am muddled and dull.
Jiao Hong says: "*Zhāo zhāo* 昭昭" and "*chá chá* 察察" originally appeared in the ancient text as "*jiē zhāo zhāo* 皆昭昭" and "*jiē xiāo xiāo* 皆嚣嚣." Qian Zhi notes: The Fu [Yi] and Fan [Yingyuan] editions read thus. Fan [Yingyuan] comments: "Wang Bi’s version matches the ancient text, though later editions omit the character *jiē* 皆." This confirms that Wang Bi’s original text included *jiē* 皆. Furthermore, "*mèn mèn* 闷闷" appears in the Fu and Fan editions as "*mǐn mǐn* 闵闵," with the character *ruò* 若 preceding both. Fan Yingyuan says: He Shangong and all other commentators write "*mèn mèn* 闷闷," which is phonetically identical. Han Yu’s *Ancient Rhapsody* contains the line: "Alone and sorrowful, when will it end? I rely on my writings to express myself" (*dú mǐn mǐn qí hé yǐ xī, píng wén zhāng yǐ zì xuān* 独闵闵其曷已兮，凭文章以自宣). Examining the character *mǐn mǐn* 闵闵 here, the annotation notes: "One version writes *mèn mèn* 闷闷," which precisely matches this passage. We now follow the ancient text.

Vast like the sea,
Yan Kejun says: The *Imperial Commentary* writes "*hū ruò huì* 忽若晦," He Shangong writes "*hū xī ruò hǎi* 忽兮若海," Wang Bi writes "*dàn xī qí ruò hǎi* 澹兮其若海," and the *Great Encyclopedia* writes "*piāo hū* 漂乎," with another version reading "*hū xī* 忽兮." Qian Zhi notes: Yan Zun’s edition writes "*hū xī ruò huì* 忽兮若晦," the Fu [Yi] edition writes "*dàn xī qí ruò hǎi* 淡兮其若海," the Fan [Yingyuan] edition writes "*dàn xī ruò hǎi* 澹兮若海," the *Imperial Commentary* and the British Library edition both write "*hū ruò huì* 忽若晦," while the Guangming, Jingfu, and Muromachi editions write "*hū xī qí ruò hǎi* 忽兮其若海." Li Daochun says: "'Vague like darkness' (*hū hū ruò huì* 忽乎若晦) or 'serene like the sea' (*dàn hū qí ruò hǎi* 淡乎其若海) are incorrect." Qian Zhi notes: The Wang [Bi] and Fan [Yingyuan] editions correctly use the character *dàn* 澹. Wang Xizhi’s edition also writes *dàn* 澹, though the stele edition mistakenly writes *dàn* 淡. The *Shuowen* states: "*Dàn* 澹 means water swaying; it is composed of the water radical and the phonetic *zhān* 詹." It is entirely distinct from *dàn* 淡. "*Hǎi* 海" sometimes appears as "*huì* 晦," a loan character for *hǎi* 海. The *Kaoling Yao* of the *Book of Documents* states: "The word *hǎi* 海 signifies dimness and obscurity, with nothing to be seen." The *Shiming*’s *Explanation of Water* says: "*Hǎi* 海 means *huì* 晦: it receives filth and turbidity, its color black and obscure." *Hǎi* 海 and *huì* 晦 share the same meaning. This describes the boundless, unfathomable vastness of the sea.

Drifting without end.
Yan Kejun says: The *Imperial Commentary* writes "*jì xī sì wú suǒ zhǐ* 寂兮似无所止," He Shangong writes "*piāo xī ruò wú suǒ zhǐ* 漂兮若无所止," the *Shiwen* cites He Shangong as writing "*yuān xī* 渊兮," Wang Bi writes "*liù xī ruò wú zhǐ* 飂兮若无止," and Liang Jianwen and Fu Yi write "*piāo xī* 飘兮." Qian Zhi notes: The Muromachi edition concurs. He Shangong and Wang Xizhi’s editions write "*liù xī ruò wú suǒ zhǐ* 飂兮若无所止," the Guangming edition writes "*xī ruò wú suǒ zhǐ* 兮若无所止," the Fan edition writes "*piāo xī sì wú suǒ zhǐ* 飘兮似无所止," the Imperial Library edition writes "*jì wú suǒ yǐ* 寂无所以," and the British Library edition matches the *Imperial Commentary*. Sun Kuang’s *Ancient and Modern Textual Collation* states: "'Drifting like without end' (*liù xī ruò wú zhǐ* 飂兮若无止) appears in one version as '*piāo xī ruò wú zhǐ* 漂兮若无止,' another as '*jiāo xī sì wú zhǐ* 胶兮似无止,' and another as '*jì ruò wú suǒ zhǐ* 寂若无所止.'" The version "*jiāo xī sì wú zhǐ* 胶兮似无止" is unattested in any known edition; it is likely a misprint of the character *○*. Takeuchi Yoshio says: The *Tianwen Chao*’s He Shangong edition writes "*○ xī* ○兮," the Guangming stele writes "*xī* 兮," and the Takikawa and Shidetang editions write "*piāo xī* 漂兮." The characters *○* and *○* are variant forms of *piāo* 漂, while *piāo* 漂 and *liù* 飂 are phonetically close. Wu Yun says: Wang Lanquan cites He Shangong’s edition as writing *yuān* 渊, with the note: "The current He Shangong edition writes *piāo* 漂." This stele writes *○*, a character frequently found in Northern steles. Bi Yuan says: The *Zhuangzi*’s line "deep and boundless like the sea" (*yuān yuān hū qí ruò hǎi* 渊渊乎其若海) draws from this passage. Qian Zhi notes: "*Piāo wú suǒ zhǐ* 漂无所止" is the most comprehensive interpretation. Drifting like the endless wind coursing through the great void, it shares the same meaning as *liù* 飂. The *Shuowen* states: "*Liù* 飂 means a high wind." The character also appears as *○*, as in the *Wu Capital Rhapsody*: "Riding the soaring winds of *sī fēng* ○○." It also appears as *○*, with the *Yupian* defining it as "the appearance of a high wind."

All people have their purposes; I alone am stubborn and coarse.
Yan Kejun says: "*Yǒu yǐ* 有以" appears in all other editions as "*yǒu yǐ* 有已." "*Wǒ dú wán* 我独顽" in He Shangong and Wang Bi’s editions includes the character *ér* 而 before *wǒ* 我. Takeuchi Yoshio says: The Dunhuang and Jingfu editions write *yǐ* 以 as *yǐ* 已. Qian Zhi notes: "*Yǒu yǐ* 有已" is equivalent to "*yǒu yǐ* 有以." The *Shuowen* states: "*Yǐ* 已 means 'to use.'" In clerical script, it also appears as *○*, written as *yǐ* 以. The *Guangya*’s *Explanation of Words* says: "*Yǐ* 已 means *yě* 也." Zheng Xuan’s commentary on the *Artificers’ Record* notes: "*Yǐ* 已 may also be written as *yǐ* 以." His commentary on the *Tan Gong* chapter says: "*Yǐ* 以 and *yǐ* 已 are originally the same character." The *Xunzi*’s *Fei Xiang* chapter reads: "What is the purpose?" (*hé yǐ yě* 何已也), with the annotation: "Same as *yǐ* 以." Thus, "*jiē yǒu yǐ* 皆有已" here means "*jiē yǒu yǐ* 皆有以," as in the *Zhuangzi*’s phrase "there must be a reason" (*qí bì yǒu yǐ* 其必有以).

I alone differ from others, and value the nourishment of the Mother.

Tao Hongqing states: The Fu Yi edition includes the character *yu* 欲 ("desire") after "*wo du* 我独" ("I alone"). According to Wang Bi’s commentary, "*Wo du yu yi yu ren* 我独欲异于人" ("I alone desire to differ from others"), the version Wang saw also contained *yu* 欲, which was later omitted in transcription. Laozi describes the essential subtleties of the Dao with fragmented and elusive expressions, often using words like *ruo* 若 ("as if"), *ru* 如 ("like"), *si* 似 ("resembling"), *jiang* 将 ("about to"), and *yu* 欲 ("desiring")—all conveying this same intent. Thus, the version with *yu* 欲 is superior.

Qian Zhi notes: The Dunhuang and Suizhou editions write *du* 独 ("alone") as *yu* 欲 ("desire"). Yan Kejun states: "*Er gui shi mu* 而贵食母" ("and value the nourishment of the Mother") appears in the imperial commentary as "*er gui qiu shi yu mu* 而贵求食于母" ("and value seeking nourishment from the Mother"). Li Daochun says: "*Er gui shi mu* 而贵食母" is sometimes rendered as "*er gui qiu shi yu mu* 儿贵求食于母" ("the child values seeking nourishment from the Mother"), which is incorrect. Lao Jian remarks: The two characters "*shi mu* 食母" in the Fan edition were mistakenly altered following Tang Emperor Xuanzong’s interpolation, becoming "*qiu shi yu mu* 求食于母." Xuanzong’s own note states, "The original lacked the characters *qiu* 求 ('seek') and *yu* 于 ('from'); these are my additions," making it clear this was not the ancient version, yet Fan failed to correct it.

Qian Zhi notes: Most interpretations of this line by various scholars are erroneous; only Su Che grasped its meaning, saying: "It is like an infant, taking no mixed nourishment, feeding only from the Mother." The *Zhuangzi*’s *Dechongfu* chapter reads, "*Tunzi shi yu qi si mu* 豚子食于其死母" ("the piglet feeds from its dead mother"), with Guo Xiang’s commentary: "Feeding on milk." Thus, "*shi mu* 食母" here means "feeding on milk from the Mother." Additionally, the Wang Xizhi edition includes *qiu* 求 ("seek") after *gui* 贵 ("value"), confirming this inscription was composed after Emperor Ming’s interpolations.

**[Phonology]**
For this chapter, Jiang Yong’s rhyme analysis reads:
*E* 阿 and *he* 何 rhyme (歌 *ge* department);
*wu* 恶 and *ruo* 若 rhyme (鱼 *yu* department; *wu* 恶 is a *wu*-entering tone, *ruo* 若 an entering tone);
*wei* 畏 and *wei* 畏 rhyme (脂 *zhi* department);
*zai* 哉, *xi* 熙, *tai* 台, and *hai* 孩 rhyme (之 *zhi* department; *zai* 哉 pronounced *zi*, *tai* 台 as *tuqi* 徒其反, *hai* 孩 as *huqi* 胡其反);
*gui* 归 and *yi* 遗 rhyme (脂 *zhi* department);
*hun* 昏 and *men* 闷 rhyme (文 *wen* department; *men* 闷 is level tone);
*hai* 海, *zhi* 止, *yi* 以, *bi* 鄙, and *mu* 母 rhyme (之 *zhi* department; *hai* 海 pronounced *xi* 喜).

Xi Diao’s analysis:
*E* 阿, *he* 何, *wu* 恶, and *ruo* 若 rhyme;
*xi* 熙, *lao* 牢, *tai* 台, and *hai* 孩 rhyme;
*gui* 归 and *yi* 遗 rhyme;
*dun* 沌, *hun* 昏, and *men* 闷 rhyme;
*hui* 晦, *zhi* 止, *yi* 以, *bi* 鄙, and *mu* 母 rhyme.

Chen Zhu’s analysis:
*You* 忧, *e* 阿, *he* 何, *wu* 恶, and *ruo* 若 rhyme;
*xi* 熙, *lao* 牢, *tai* 台, *hai* 孩, *gui* 归, *yi* 遗, and *zai* 哉 rhyme.
The rest aligns with Xi Diao.

Gao Benhan’s analysis:
*Huang* 荒 (variant *mang* 芒) and *yang* 央 rhyme;
*xi* 熙, *lao* 牢, *tai* 台, *zhao* 兆, *hai* 孩, *gui* 归, *yi* 遗, and *zai* 哉 form one rhyme group, while *gui* 归 and *yi* 遗 also rhyme independently.
Additionally, *hun* 昏, *men* 闷 (variant *min* 闵), *hai* 海 (variant *hui* 晦), *zhi* 止, *yi* 以, *bi* 鄙, and *mu* 母 form another rhyme group.

Yang Shuda states: Jiang Yong’s rhyme analysis is correct; Xi, Chen, and Gao all err.

Deng Tingzhen notes: *Wu* 恶 and *ruo* 若 rhyme. In ancient pronunciation, both *shanwu* 善恶 ("good and evil") and *haowu* 好恶 ("likes and dislikes") used the departing tone for *wu* 恶; later generations forcibly distinguished *wu* 恶 in *shanwu* 善恶 as an entering tone. The character *ruo* 若 rhymes with *fu* 赋 in the *Shijing*’s *Zheng Min*, and with *shuo* 硕 in *Da Tian* and *Bi Gong*; *shuo* 硕 in ancient pronunciation rhymed with *zhe* 柘. In *Sheng Min*, *zhe* 柘 rhymes with *lu* 路, while in the *Daxue*, *shuo* 硕 rhymes with *wu* 恶. In *Bi Gong*, *ruo* 若 further rhymes with *zuo* 作, and *zuo* 作 in ancient pronunciation aligned with *zuo* 祚 and *zuo* 胙. Cross-referencing these, *ruo* 若 broadly belongs to the departing tone of the *yu* 鱼 and *yu* 虞 departments, though its modern pronunciation has shifted from the departing tone.

Jiang Yougao states: *Men* 闷 is pronounced *mokun* 莫困切. However, in ancient times, it had a level tone and should be grouped with the *hun* 魂 department. In Laozi’s *Yi Su* chapter, "*Wo du menmen* 我独闷闷" ("I alone am content") rhymes with *hun* 昏. In the *Shun Hua* chapter, "*Qi zheng menmen* 其政闷闷" ("its governance is unadorned") rhymes with *chun* 醇 (see *Tang Yun Sisheng Zheng*, volume 26, *hun* 慁).

Another theory from Jiang Yougao holds that *lao* 牢 is not part of the rhyme.

Qian Zhi notes: *Lao* 牢 in ancient pronunciation was read as *li* 厘. Jiang Yong’s *Guyun Biaozhun* (Level Tone, Section 11) states: "*Lao* 牢 is pronounced *langhou* 郎侯切. According to ancient pronunciation, *lao* 牢 was thus, as the *Shiming* explains: '*Liu* 留 means *lao* 牢.' Laozi’s line, '*Zhongren xixi, ru lao tai lao, ru deng chuntai* 众人熙熙，如○太牢，如登春台' ('The multitude are merry, as if feasting on a grand sacrifice, as if ascending a spring terrace'), and Zhuang Xin’s citation of the proverb, '*Wang yang er bu lao, wei wei chi ye* 亡羊而补牢，未为迟也' ('Losing a sheep and mending the pen is not too late'), both read *lao* 牢 as *li* 厘—likely a dialectal variation."

Additionally, *tai* 台 was anciently read as *chi* 持. The *Shiming* states: "*Tai* 台 means *chi* 持." The character *tai* 台 derives from the phonetic *ㄓ*, hence its proximity to *chi* 持. *Hai* 孩 is pronounced *huli* 户黎切, so *lao* 牢, *tai* 台, and *hai* 孩 form a rhyme, as do *lao* 牢 and *zhao* 兆.

Ma Xulun states: "*Xi* 熙, *tai* 台, and *hai* 孩 rhyme at the ends of lines, a point previous scholars have clarified. As for *lao* 牢 and *zhao* 兆, they also harmonize at line ends, constituting an internal rhyme in poetry." (*Xiuci Shilun*)

The Jinglong stele edition contains 116 characters; the Dunhuang edition, 115; the Heshang Gong and Wang Bi editions, 132; the Fu Yi edition, 137; and the Fan edition, 141. The Heshang Gong edition titles this chapter "Yi Su Di Ershi" 异俗第二十 ("Different Customs, Twenty"), the Wang Bi edition "Ershi Zhang" 二十章 ("Chapter Twenty"), and the Fan edition "Jue Xue Wu You Zhang Di Ershi" 绝学无忧章第二十 ("Cutting Off Learning Brings No Sorrow, Chapter Twenty").

**Chapter Twenty-One**
The demeanor of Kong De follows only the Dao.
Wei Jiasun states: In the imperial commentary, *de* 得 ("attains") is written as *de* 德 ("virtue").
Yan Kejun notes: "*Shi cong* 是从" ("follows only") in the *Dayian* edition appears as "*zhi cong* 之从."

Qian's note: The character *wei* 唯 appears as *wei* 惟 in various Wang Bi editions, and as *wei* 唯 in the Daozang Wang Bi edition. *Kong* 孔 means "intense" or "great." The *Book of Documents* reads *liu fu kong xiu* 六府孔修 ("the six treasuries are greatly cultivated"), while the *Records of the Grand Historian* renders it *shen xiu* 甚修 ("intensely cultivated"). *Shen* 甚 carries the sense of "abundant," so *kong de* 孔德 may be understood as *sheng de* 盛德 ("abundant virtue"). Thus, this line speaks of the demeanor of abundant virtue, which follows only the embodiment of the Dao.

As a thing, the Dao is only dim and indistinct. Within the dim and indistinct, there are images; within the indistinct and dim, there are things.

Yan Kejun notes: The line *hu huang zhong you xiang, huang hu zhong you wu* 忽恍中有象，恍忽中有物 ("within the indistinct and dim, there are images; within the dim and indistinct, there are things") is identical in Gu Huan's edition. The imperial commentary reads: *Hu xi huang, qi zhong you ○; huang xi hu, qi zhong you wu* 忽兮恍，其中有○；恍兮忽，其中有物 ("Dim, ah indistinct—within it, there is ○; indistinct, ah dim—within it, there are things"). The Heshang Gong edition reads: *Hu xi huang xi, qi zhong you xiang; huang xi hu xi, qi zhong you wu* 忽兮恍兮，其中有像；怳兮忽兮，其中有物 ("Dim, ah indistinct—within it, there are images; indistinct, ah dim—within it, there are things"). Some versions invert these two lines. Wang Bi's edition matches the Heshang Gong, with *hu* 忽 written as *hu* 惚. Qian's note: In the Daozang Wang Bi edition, both instances of *hu xi* 惚兮 are written as *hu xi* 忽兮. The *Shiwen* glosses the character *huang* 怳, indicating that the Wang Bi edition originally wrote *huang* 怳. The commentary on the *Toutuo Temple Stele* cites the *Laozi* as writing *huang* 怳, and Wang Bi's commentary also uses *huang* 怳. The *Baopuzi*, in its "Dizhen" chapter, quotes the "Old Master" in a manner identical to the Heshang Gong edition. The British Library manuscript matches the imperial commentary. Additionally, the Dunhuang edition writes *wei huang* 惟恍 as *wei huang* 惟慌. The *Guangya* (*Shigu* 2) defines ○ as *hu* 忽 ("sudden"). The preface to the *Shennü Fu* reads *jingshen huanghu* 精神怳惚 ("spirit dim and indistinct"), with the commentary: "the sense of being unaware of oneself." The *Xu Yiqie Jing Yinyi* cites the *Zilin*: *huanghu* 恍惚 means "the mind is unclear." In the Fu Yi and Fan editions, these two characters are written as *mangwu* 芒芴, which were interchangeable in ancient times. The *Zhuangzi* ("Zhile") also reads: *Mang hu wu hu, er wu cong chu hu? Wu hu mang hu, er wu you xiang hu?* 芒乎芴乎，而无从出乎？芴乎芒乎，而无有象乎？ ("Dim, ah indistinct—how can one emerge from it? Indistinct, ah dim—how can there be images within it?") and *za hu mangwu zhi jian* 杂乎芒芴之间 ("intermingled within the dim and indistinct"). These phrases all derive from this passage. Chu Boshi states: *Mangwu* 芒芴 is read identically to *huanghu* 恍惚. The *Guang Hongming Ji* (13), in Shi Falin's *Bianzheng Lun Jiuzhen Pian*, cites *mangwu* 芒芴 as correctly written *huanghu* 恍惚. Yu Yue remarks: The two lines *hu xi huang xi* 惚兮恍兮 and *huang xi hu xi* 恍兮惚兮 should follow the two lines *huang xi hu xi* 恍兮惚兮. This is because they continue the preceding *wei huang wei hu* 惟恍惟惚 ("only dim and indistinct"), so one should first say *huang xi hu xi, qi zhong you wu* 恍兮惚兮，其中有物 ("indistinct, ah dim—within it, there are things"), rhyming with the four lines above: *Dao zhi wei wu, wei huang wei hu* 道之为物，惟恍惟惚 ("As a thing, the Dao is only dim and indistinct"). The subsequent line, *hu xi huang xi, qi zhong you xiang* 惚兮恍兮，其中有象 ("dim, ah indistinct—within it, there are images"), then shifts the rhyme. Wang Bi's commentary reads: "The myriad things begin and are completed, yet one does not know how this occurs. Thus it is said: indistinct, ah dim—dim, ah indistinct—within it, there are images." The commentary likely quotes the entire passage but omits the four characters *qi zhong you wu* 其中有物 ("within it, there are things"). Nevertheless, this demonstrates that the version Wang Bi saw had not yet inverted the lines.

Jiang Xichang remarks: According to the *Qiang Ben Cheng Shu*, the quoted passage reads: *Huanghu zhong you xiang, huhuang zhong you wu* 恍惚中有象，惚恍中有物 ("within the indistinct and dim, there are images; within the dim and indistinct, there are things"). The Daozang Heshang Gong edition reads: *Huang xi hu xi, qi zhong you wu; hu xi huang xi, qi zhong you xiang* 怳兮忽兮，其中有物；忽兮怳兮，其中有像 ("indistinct, ah dim—within it, there are things; dim, ah indistinct—within it, there are images"), which aligns with Yu Yue's proposal.

Within the profound darkness, there is essence; this essence is most true, and within it, there is reliability.

Yan Kejun notes: The line *○ ming zhong you jing* ○冥中有精 ("within the profound darkness, there is essence") is identical in Gu Huan's edition. The imperial commentary reads *○ xi ming, qi zhong you jing* ○兮冥，其中有精 ("profound, ah dark—within it, there is essence"), while the Heshang Gong and Wang Bi editions read *○ xi ming xi, qi zhong you jing* ○兮冥兮，其中有精 ("profound, ah dark—within it, there is essence"). Luo Zhenyu notes: In the imperial commentary, *zhen* 真 is written as ○, a variant character for *zhen* 真. Qian's note: The *Huainanzi* ("Daoying Xun") cites these four lines identically to the Wang Bi edition. The *Wen Xuan* (commentary on Shen Yue's "Zhongshan Shi") cites *○ xi ming, zhong qi you jing* ○兮冥，中其有精 ("profound, ah dark—within it, there is essence"). The Lou Zheng and Panxi editions read *yao xi ming, qi zhong you jing* 杳兮冥，其中有精 ("remote, ah dark—within it, there is essence"). The Guancang edition reads *○ ming zhong you jing* ○冥中有精 ("within the profound darkness, there is essence"). The Fu Yi edition reads *you xi ming xi, qi zhong you jing* 幽兮冥兮，其中有精 ("remote, ah dark—within it, there is essence"), and the Fan edition reads *you xi ming xi, zhong you jing xi* 幽兮冥兮，中有精兮 ("remote, ah dark—within it, there is essence"). The characters ○, *you* 幽, and *yao* 杳 are phonetically close and interchangeable. Additionally, the line *qi jing shen zhen* 其精甚真 ("this essence is most true") appears in Wang Xizhi's edition as *you jing shen zhen* 有精甚真 ("there is essence, most true"). This line is absent in the Suizhou edition.

Qian's note: The *Guanzi* ("Neiye") states: "Essence is the utmost of *qi*; essence is the purest of *qi*. In all human life, Heaven bestows its essence." This aligns with the meaning of *jing* 精 ("essence") in this chapter. *Jing* reflects an ancient, naive materialist conception, as discussed in detail in Feng Youlan's essay "The Material Nature of the Dao in Pre-Qin Daoism." The *Zhuangzi* ("Dechong Fu") reads *fu Dao you qing you xin, wu wei wu xing, ke zhuan er bu ke shou, ke de er bu ke jian* 夫道有情有信，无为无形，可传而不可受，可得而不可见 ("The Dao has *qing* and reliability, is without action and formless, can be transmitted but not received, can be attained but not seen"). Here, *qing* 情 should be *jing* 精 ("essence"), so *you qing you xin* 有情有信 ("has *qing* and reliability") corresponds to *qi zhong you jing, qi zhong you xin* 其中有精，其中有信 ("within it, there is essence; within it, there is reliability").

From ancient times to the present, its name does not depart.

Wu Yun states: The Fu Yi edition reads *zi jin ji gu* 自今及古 ("from the present to ancient times"), and the Wang Bi edition matches this stele. Fan Yingyuan remarks: The line *zi jin ji gu* 自今及古 ("from the present to ancient times") is identical in the editions of Yan Zun and Wang Bi. Ma Xulun notes: Most editions read *zi gu ji jin* 自古及今 ("from ancient times to the present"), which is incorrect. *Gu* 古, *qu* 去, and *fu* 甫 rhyme. Fan claims "Wang Bi matches the ancient edition," yet in Wang Bi's commentary, both instances read *zi gu ji jin* 自古及今 ("from ancient times to the present"). This is likely because later editors altered the text based on other editions, affecting both the base text and Wang Bi's commentary.

Jiang Xichang states: According to the *Collected Commentaries on the Authentic Classic of Dao and Virtue* (including annotations by Emperor Xuanzong of Tang, Heshang Gong, Wang Bi, and Wang Pang), Wang Bi’s commentary reads: “Thus it is said, ‘From the present to ancient times, its name does not depart.’” This precisely aligns with Fan Yingyuan’s version of Wang Bi’s text, sufficiently proving that the current edition has been altered by later hands—Ma Xulun’s argument is correct.

"To encompass the many progenitors."
"How do I know the nature of the many progenitors? By this."

Takeuchi Yoshio states: The Dunhuang, Jing, and Sui editions write *zhong* 众 ("many") as *zhong* 终 ("end"), as *zhong* and *zhong* were homophonous in ancient pronunciation.
Qian Zhi notes: The Jinglong edition writes *zhong* 众 and not *zhong* 终—this is an erroneous collation. The Palace Library edition also writes *zhong* 终. However, *zhong* 终 is incorrect.

The character *yue* 阅 in ancient texts glosses as "to gather" or "to total." Ōta Seiken cites the *Liezi* ("Zhongni" chapter): "He gathered forty disciples to travel together." The *Huainanzi* ("Yuandao Xun") states: "The totality of the myriad things all passes through one aperture; the roots of the hundred affairs all emerge from one gate." The *Chuzhen Xun* reads: "What heaven covers, what earth bears, what the six directions enclose, what yin and yang exhale, what rain and dew moisten, what the Dao and virtue sustain—all these are born of one father and mother and encompassed in one harmony." Gao You’s commentary: "*Yue* 阅 means ‘to total.’" Only Ōta argues that *zhongfu* 众甫 refers to "many fathers," citing the *Zhuangzi* ("Tiandi" chapter), where Nie Que states: "There are clans and ancestors; one may be a father to many, but not the father of fathers." He claims that in ancient texts, *fu* 甫 and *fu* 父 were interchangeable. Though his view aligns with Yu Yue’s, it is highly forced.

Examining classical texts, *fu* 甫 consistently glosses as "great." Derivative characters from *fu* all carry the meaning of "great." For instance, the *Xunzi* ("Rongru" chapter) annotates *bo* 薄 as "broad and great in appearance"; the *Han Shi Waizhuan* ("Changwu") glosses *fu* 敷 as "great"; the *Shuowen* defines *bo* 博 as "greatly penetrating"; the *Book of Songs* ("Beishan") annotates *pu* 溥 (via Mao’s commentary) as "great"; the *Book of Songs* ("Chegong") annotates *pu* 圃 (via Mao’s commentary) as "broad"; the *Shuowen* defines *pu* 酺 as "the king’s virtue spreading widely in grand feasting" and *pu* 誧 as "grand speech" (see Dai Zongxiang’s *Shi Fu*). From this, *zhongfu* 众甫 clearly means "the many great ones." Within the realm, there are the Four Greats—"to encompass the many progenitors" thus means to total the Four Greats.

Yan Kejun states: The phrase *zhi ran* 之然 appears in the imperial commentary and the modern Heshang Gong edition as *zhi ran zai* 之然哉, while Wang Bi’s edition reads *zhi zhuang zai* 之状哉. The *Shiwen* notes: "One version of Heshang Gong’s text simply reads, ‘How do I know?’"
Wu Yun states: The phrase *wu he yi zhi* 吾何以知 appears in the Fu Yi edition as *xi yi zhi* 奚以知.
Fan Yingyuan states: The character *xi* 奚 is from the ancient edition.

**[Phonology]**
This chapter’s rhyme scheme, per Jiang Yong’s analysis:
- *Rong* 容 rhymes with *cong* 从 (East Division).
- *Wu* 物 rhymes with *hu* 惚 (Zhi Division; *hu*, pronounced *hujie*).
- *Huang* 恍 rhymes with *xiang* 象 (Yang Division).
- *Hu* 忽 rhymes with *wu* 物 (Zhi Division).
- *Ming* 冥 rhymes with *jing* 精 (Geng Division).
- *Zhen* 真 rhymes with *xin* 信 (Zhen Division; *xin*, level tone).
- *Qu* 去 rhymes with *fu* 甫 (Yu Division).

Yao Wentian, Deng Tingzhen, and Xi Tong concur. Bernhard Karlgren reads *zi gu ji jin* 自古及今 as *zi jin ji gu* 自今及古, rhyming *gu* 古, *qu* 去, and *fu* 甫. Additionally, *ming* 冥, *jing* 精, *zhen* 真, and *xin* 信 form a paired rhyme. Wei Jiangong notes that these four lines should be examined for their potential rhyme, just as *ming* 名 rhymes with *men* 门 and *ying* 盈 rhymes with *chen* 尘 (see *Studies on Ancient Phonological Systems*).

The Jinglong stele edition contains sixty-one characters, matching the Dunhuang edition. The Heshang Gong, Wang Bi, Fu Yi, and Fan Yingyuan editions contain seventy-one characters. Heshang Gong titles this chapter "Emptying the Heart, Twenty-One," Wang Bi titles it "Chapter Twenty-One," and Fan Yingyuan titles it "The Countenance of the Power of Emptiness, Twenty-One."

**Chapter Twenty-Two**
"Bent, then whole; crooked, then upright."
Yan Kejun states: The phrase *wang ze zheng* 枉则正 appears identically in the Fu Yi edition, while other editions read *ze zhi* 则直.
Qian Zhi notes: The Sui Prefecture, Palace Library, and Fan Yingyuan editions all read *zheng* 正. Fan states: "The character *zheng* 正 aligns with Wang Bi’s ancient edition; one version reads *zhi* 直."
Takeuchi Yoshio states: The Jing and Sui editions write *zhi* 直 as *zheng* 正, matching the *Huainanzi* ("Daoying Xun"). However, the *Daoying Xun* actually cites the two lines as *zhi* 直—Takeuchi’s collation is incorrect.

Moreover, "bent, then whole" echoes the *Zhuangzi* ("Tianxia" chapter), which describes Lao Dan’s Dao: "All seek fortune, yet he alone bends to preserve wholeness." The *Hongfan* states, "Wood is said to be bent and straight"—this also uses wood as a metaphor. "Bent" refers to what the *Zhuangzi* ("Xiaoyaoyou" chapter) calls "curled and not fitting the compass or square," and what the *Renjianshi* chapter calls "clenched and unfit for beams or pillars." As the saying goes, "Straight trees are felled first; sweet wells run dry first," and "I walk in curves, sparing my feet"—this embodies the meaning of "bent, then whole."

"Crooked, then upright": *Wang* 枉, per the *Shuowen*, means "twisted and bent, from *mu* 木 and *qu* ○ phonetic." The *Guangya* ("Shigu" 1) glosses *qu* ○ as "bent," meaning "contorted and bowed"—essentially "yielding." *Zheng* 正 in other editions reads *zhi* 直; *wang* 枉 and *zhi* 直 form a parallel. "Crooked, then straight" means "great straightness appears bent." The *Analects* states, "Elevate the straight and set them above the crooked." The *Huainanzi* ("Benjing Xun") reads, "Correct the crooked to make it straight." The stele text reads *zheng* 正, which also means "straight."

The *Mo Pian* of the *Guiguzi* states, "That which is *zheng* 正 is *zhi* 直." The *Guangya* ("Shigu" 1) reads, "*Zhi* 直 is *zheng* 正." The *Wenyan* commentary to the *Yijing* says, "*Zhi* 直 is its *zheng* 正." *Zhi* 直 and *zheng* 正 may be mutually defined.

That which is hollow becomes full; that which is worn becomes new. Yan Kejun notes, "‘Worn, then new’—the *Shiwen* writes it as *bi* 蔽; Fu Yi and the present Wang Bi edition write *bi* 敝." Qian’s annotation: The Daoist Canon’s Wang Bi edition writes *bi* 弊; the Imperial Commentary edition, the Palace Library edition, the Suizhou edition, the Heshang edition, and all stone inscriptions write *bi* 弊; the *Taiping Yulan* (159) also writes *bi* 弊.

As for the character *wa* 洼, the Daoist Canon’s Heshang edition writes *wa* 窊. *Wa* 洼 and *wa* 窊 are the same character, both meaning "sunken and low-lying." *Wa* 窊 is the ancient form of *wa* 洼. The *Shuowen* states, "*Wa* 窊 means ‘filthy and slanted downward.’" The *Guangya* ("Shigu") reads, "*Wa* 窊 means ‘low.’" Xia Song’s *Guwen Sisheng Yun* (2) cites the *Ancient Laozi* as writing *wa* 窊○. Peng Qi’s *Shiwen* notes, "*Wa* 洼 is pronounced *li wu gua*; it means ‘hollow.’ Where the earth is hollow, water fills it—this illustrates how the virtue of humility is ever full."

That which is little is gained; that which is much may be lost.

Thus the sage embraces the One and becomes the model for all under heaven.

Yan Kejun notes: "Some editions write *huo* 惑 instead of *huo* 或."
Qian’s commentary: The Suizhou edition and the Palace Library edition agree with this stone inscription. Moreover, the *Outer Chapters of the Shenzi* cites seven sentences from "Laozi says," omitting only the two characters *shi yi* 是以, matching Fu Yi’s version. Here, *de* 得 refers to the "attainment of the One" as spoken of in Chapter 39. *Huo* 或 should be read as *huo* 惑, meaning "sometimes this, sometimes that," contrasting with the meaning of "attaining the One."

Not displaying oneself, thus one is illuminated;
Not asserting oneself, thus one is distinguished;
Not boasting, thus one achieves merit;
Not priding oneself, thus one endures.

Qian’s commentary: In the stele edition, the character *zhang* 彰 is damaged and unclear, and the following *bu* 不 is effaced; these should be supplemented according to other editions. Furthermore, in the Suizhou and Palace Library editions, the phrase "Not displaying oneself, thus one is illuminated" appears after "Not asserting oneself, thus one is distinguished"; in Tang Li Yue’s edition, "Not boasting, thus one achieves merit" appears after "Not priding oneself, thus one endures." Additionally, the *Zhuangzi* ("Shanmu") states: "I have heard the Perfect Person say, 'Those who boast achieve no merit; those who complete merit fall; those who complete fame are diminished. Who can relinquish merit and fame and return to the multitude?'" This echoes Chapter 9 of the *Laozi*—"Having achieved merit, withdraw the self; this is the Dao of heaven"—and the present chapter’s teaching, "Not boasting, thus one achieves merit."

Only by not contending does nothing under heaven contend with him.

Yan Kejun notes: The Heshang edition omits the character *neng* 能.
Qian’s commentary: The *Huainanzi* ("Yuandao") states, "Because he does not contend with the myriad things, none dare contend with him," which is drawn from this chapter. Wang Niansun says: "'None dare' originally read 'none can'; later scholars altered it following the *Wenzi* ("Daoyuan"). Only by not contending with the myriad things can none contend with him—this is what is meant by 'the soft and weak overcome the hard and strong.' If it read 'none dare,' it would miss the point. Below, it says, 'Great merit, firm and unyielding, none can contend with it.' The *Laozi* states, 'Only by not contending does nothing under heaven contend with him,' and again, 'Because he does not contend, nothing under heaven can contend with him.' All these serve as evidence." Wei Zheng’s *Qunshu Zhiyao* cites this sentence as "none can contend with him."

What the ancients called "the crooked is preserved whole"—was this an empty saying?
Thus it is preserved whole and returned.

Yan Kejun notes: "Was this an empty saying" in other editions reads "Was this an empty saying indeed?" "Thus preserved whole" in other editions reads "truly preserved whole," without the character *gu* 故.
Wei Jiasun notes: The Imperial Commentary includes a *zhe* 者 after *quan* 全, and the following sentence reads "Was this empty speech indeed?" Yan cites the *zai* 哉 but overlooks the *zhe* 者 and *yan* 言.
Qian’s commentary: The Suizhou edition matches this stone inscription. *Cheng* 成 should be *cheng* 誠. Xia Song’s *Guwen Sisheng Yun* (2) cites the *Ancient Laozi*, where *cheng* 成 appears as ○, and *cheng* 誠 appears as ○. In the received text, *cheng* 成 appears seventeen times, while *cheng* 誠 appears only here. Moreover, "the crooked is preserved whole" is an ancient saying; the *Sunzi* ("Jiudi") states, "Those skilled in the Dao preserve themselves through crookedness," which clearly attests to this. The *Zhuangzi* ("Tianxia") discusses the *Laozi*, saying, "While others seek fortune, he alone preserves himself through crookedness, saying, 'May I merely avoid blame?'" This is drawn from the present chapter.

**[Phonology]**
This chapter’s rhyme scheme, according to Jiang’s reading:
*Ying* 盈 and *xin* 新 rhyme (Zhen and Geng in harmonious rhyme; these two lines originally appeared below "the crooked becomes straight," but have been moved here according to rhyme).
*Zhi* 直, *de* 得, *huo* 惑, and *shi* 式 rhyme (Zhi group; *huo* 惑 read as *hu bi*).
*Ming* 明, *zhang* 彰, *gong* 功, and *zhang* 长 rhyme (Yang and Dong in harmonious rhyme; *gong* 功 rhymes as *guang*).
*Zheng* 争 and *zheng* 争 rhyme (Geng group).

Qian’s commentary: *Ying* 盈 belongs to the Geng group, *xin* 新 to the Zhen group—these are Zhen and Geng in harmonious rhyme. *Ming* 明, *zhang* 彰, and *zhang* 长 belong to the Yang group; *gong* 功 to the Dong group—these are Yang and Dong in harmonious rhyme. The character *zhi* 直 in the Jing, Suizhou, and Palace Library editions is written as *zheng* 正, which belongs to the Geng group. Xi Diao takes *quan* 全, *zheng* 正, *ying* 盈, and *xin* 新 as rhyming, saying: "Rhyme *quan* 全 and *xin* 新 with *zheng* 正 and *ying* 盈—this is a case of sound variation, like the rhyming of *qing* 清, *ren* 人, *xin* 新, *nian* 年, *sheng* 生, *lian* 怜, *sheng* 声, *ming* 鸣, *zheng* 征, and *cheng* 成 in the *Jiu Bian*." Gao Benhan agrees with Xi, though he treats *zheng* 正 and *ying* 盈 as internal rhyme. He also takes *de* 得 and *huo* 惑 as rhyming, *yi* 一 and *shi* 式 as rhyming, and *ming* 明, *zhang* 彰, *gong* 功, *zhang* 长, *zheng* 争, and *zheng* 争 as a single rhyme. The various theories are divergent; only Jiang’s rearrangement of the text to fit the rhyme seems unsatisfactory. This chapter actually employs two alternating rhymes: *quan* 全, *ying* 盈, and *xin* 新 form one rhyme; *zhi* 直, *de* 得, *huo* 惑, and *shi* 式 form another. Chen Zhu takes *zai* 哉 and *zhi* 之 as rhyming. *Zai* 哉 and *zhi* 之 both belong to the Zhi group. Yao Nai treats "What the ancients called 'the crooked is preserved whole'—was this an empty saying? Truly preserved whole and returned" as a single section with the following chapter, "Sparse speech is natural," arguing: "*Yan* 言, *quan* 全, and *ran* 然 rhyme. 'Still as if valuing speech, merit achieved and affairs completed, the hundred clans all say, "We are naturally thus"—this explains the present passage.'"

The Jinglong stele edition contains seventy-seven characters; the Palace Library edition, seventy-four; the Heshang, Wang, Fu, and Fan editions, seventy-eight.

The Heshang Gong edition titles this "Benefiting Through Humility, Twenty-Second," the Wang Bi edition titles it "Chapter Twenty-Two," and the Fan edition titles it "The Crooked Is Preserved Whole, Chapter Twenty-Two."

**Chapter Twenty-Three**
Sparse speech is natural.
Whirlwinds do not last the morning,
Fierce rains do not last the day.
Who brings these about?
Heaven and Earth.

Yan Zun notes: "Below 雨, the character 不 is effaced; it should be restored according to other editions."
"希" is consistent across all editions; the Fu edition writes it as "稀."
"终" is written as "崇" in both the Fu and Fan editions.
Above "飘风," the Wang, Fu, and Fan editions include the character "故."
Luo Zhenyu states: The Jinglong, Guangming, Jingfu, and British Library editions all omit "故."
Additionally, the Palace Library edition writes "骤" as "○," while the Fan edition writes it as "暴."
Ma Xulun states: "崇" and "终" are ancient loan characters. In the *Book of Documents*, "其終出于不祥," the Ma edition writes "終" as "崇," serving as evidence.
He further states: In the Palace Library edition, "骤" is written as "趨," as "趨" and "骤" were also ancient loan characters.
Who is responsible for these?
Heaven and Earth.

"Heaven and Earth above cannot endure long—how much less can man?

Yan Kejun states: The Heshang and Wang Bi editions include the character *zhe* 者 after *ci* 此. *Shang bu* 尚不 in all other editions appears as *shang bu* 上不, and *yu ren* 于人 at the end of the sentence in all other editions includes the particle *hu* 乎.
Qian Zhi notes: The Palace Library and Suizhou editions omit *hu* 乎. The *Zuozhuan* *Zhaogong* 28th year *Zhengyi* commentary cites: 'Even Heaven and Earth cannot endure forever—how much less man *hu* 乎,' and the *Mouzi Lihuo Lun* also cites: 'Even Heaven and Earth cannot last long—how much less man *hu* 乎,' both including *hu* 乎.

Thus, those who devote themselves to the Way align with the Way;
those who align with virtue/power are embraced by virtue/power;
those who align with loss are met with loss.

Yan Kejun states: The ancient characters *de* 得 and *de* 德 were interchangeable; *dezhi* 德之 thus means *dezhi* 得之.
The Heshang edition reads: 'Thus, those who devote themselves to the Way align with the Way; those devoted to virtue/power align with virtue/power; those devoted to loss align with loss. Those who align with the Way, the Way delights in attaining them; those who align with virtue/power, virtue/power delights in attaining them; those who align with loss, loss delights in attaining them.'
The Imperial Commentary and Wang Bi editions omit the three *le* 乐 characters; the rest follows the Heshang edition.
Yu Yue states: The two characters *dao zhe* 道者 in the Wang edition are superfluous. The original text reads: 'Those who devote themselves to the Way align with the Way,' and the following *dezhe* 德者 and *shizhe* 失者 elliptically follow the preceding *congshi* 从事, as if to say: 'Those who devote themselves to the Way align with the Way; those who devote themselves to virtue/power align with virtue/power; those who devote themselves to loss align with loss.' The *Huainanzi Dao Ying* chapter cites Laozi: 'Those who devote themselves to the Way align with the Way,' proving that the ancient edition did not repeat *dao zhe* 道者.
Wang Bi’s commentary states: 'Thus, those who devote themselves to the Way... therefore it is said they align with the Way,' showing that the edition Wang relied on indeed read: 'Thus, those who devote themselves to the Way align with the Way.'
Ji Yun states: The *Yongle Dadian* omits *le* 乐, and the following two sentences are the same.
Yi Shunding states: Wang Bing’s commentary on the *Suwen Si Qi Tiao Shen Da Lun* chapter cites this passage, also omitting *le* 乐.
Luo Zhenyu states: The Imperial Commentary and British Library editions omit *le* 乐.
Qian Zhi notes: The Fu and Fan editions also omit *le* 乐. The two *dezhi* 德之 should read *dezhi* 得之. Though *de* 德 and *de* 得 were anciently interchangeable, here it should be *de* 得. The Suizhou and Palace Library editions both read *dao dezhi* 道得之 and *de dezhi* 德得之; the Fu and Fan editions also read *de* 得, as this *de* 得 pairs with the following *shi* 失 to form parallel structure.

The trust that is insufficient gives rise to distrust.

Yan Kejun states: The Heshang and Wang Bi editions read: 'Trust is insufficient *yan* 焉, and so there is distrust *yan* 焉.'
Luo Zhenyu states: The Jinglong and British Library editions omit both *yan* 焉; the Jingfu edition omits the second *yan* 焉.
Qian Zhi notes: The Suizhou, Palace Library, and Wang Xizhi editions also omit both *yan* 焉; the Fu and Muromachi editions omit the second *yan* 焉. Omitting the second *yan* 焉 is correct, as explained in Wang Niansun’s *Dushu Zazhi Yubian* (Part 1).
These two sentences also appear in Chapter Seventeen and may be a misplaced repetition.

[Phonology]
This chapter, according to Jiang Yong’s *Yun Du*, has no rhyme.
Chen Zhu: The three *de* 德 and *zhi* 之 characters rhyme.
Gao Benhan: *Yan* 言 and *ran* 然 rhyme.
Qian Zhi notes: *Yan* 言 and *ran* 然 both belong to the *yuan* 元 rhyme group. Moreover, *tian* 天 and *di* 地 form a rhyming couplet; the six *tong* 同 characters rhyme across alternating lines; the two *xin* 信 characters rhyme at the beginning and end. This exemplifies the free-rhyming style used in the *Laozi*.

The Jinglong stele edition contains fifty-eight characters; the Palace Library edition is the same. The Heshang edition has eighty-seven characters; the Wang edition, eighty-eight; the Fu edition, ninety-two; and the Fan edition, eighty-three. The Heshang edition titles this chapter 'Emptiness and Nothingness Twenty-Third'; the Wang edition, 'Chapter Twenty-Three'; and the Fan edition, 'Sparse Speech and Naturalness Chapter Twenty-Third.'

Chapter Twenty-Four
Those who stand on tiptoe do not endure..."

Yan Kejun states: The *Yuzhu* and Heshang editions read "Those who stand on tiptoe (*qi* 跂) do not endure," while Wang Bi’s edition has "Those who stand on tiptoe (*qi* 企) do not endure." Luo Zhenyu notes: The *Shiwen* glosses, "The Heshang edition has *chi* 豉." It appears that *chi* is likely a corruption of *qi* 跂. The *Yuzhu* and *Guangming* editions also read *qi* 跂. The *Guangming* edition includes the line "Those who pant do not endure" above this. Wu Yun, in *Erbai Lantingzhai Jinshi Ji*, collating the *Guangming* edition, states: "All other editions lack the four characters 'Those who pant do not endure.'" Wei Jiasun remarks: Few characters remain on this stele, but among them, the line "Those who pant do not endure" (Yan Qian’s note: "文" is a misprint for "久") is absent from all transmitted block-printed editions and other stone inscriptions. Yan Qian notes: The Palace Library and Suizhou editions both correctly read "Those who pant do not endure." The *Shuowen* defines *chuan* 喘 as "rapid breathing." Moreover, *qi* 企 and *qi* 跂 were used interchangeably in antiquity. The *Zhuangzi*’s "Autumn Floods" chapter reads, "to pick up without standing on tiptoe (*qi* 跂)," and the *Shiwen* notes, "*Qi* 跂 is written as *qi* 企 in one version." In the "Gengsang Chu" chapter, "men see him standing on tiptoe (*qi* 跂)," the ancient manuscript scroll reads *qi* 企. The *Wen Xuan*’s *Jiang Fu* commentary by Li Shan also states, "企 and 跂 are the same." Thus, the Heshang edition’s *qi* 跂 is equivalent to *qi* 企. The *Hanshu*’s "Annals of Emperor Gaozu," in Yan Shigu’s commentary, defines *qi* 企 as "to lift the heels and stretch the body." The *Yupian* states: "*Qi* 跂, pronounced *chi* 豉. There is a country of those who walk on tiptoes, whose people walk without their heels touching the ground." The *Zilin* defines *qi* 企 as "to lift the heels." The meanings of the two characters are also identical.

○者不行.
Yan Kejun states: "○者" appears as "○者" in all editions. I believe it should be "○者." Wei Jiasun remarks: In the original engraving, "○" is offset to the right, suggesting the left half of "○" was omitted. Yan’s emendation to "○" as "○" is incorrect. Yan Qian notes: "○" is equivalent to *kua* 跨. The *Yupian*’s section on "○" provides two pronunciations: *kou hua* and *kou wa*, both meaning "to take a stride," identical to *kua* 跨. The *Shuowen* defines *kua* 跨 as "to step over," and Duan Yucai comments: "To widen the space between the legs in order to cross something." The Muromachi edition reads the first two lines as "Those who stand on tiptoe (*qi* 跂) do not endure; those who stand on tiptoe (*qi* 跂) do not walk," but the repetition of *qi* 跂 is erroneous.

Those who rely on their own vision are not enlightened; those who assert their own correctness are not illustrious; those who boast achieve no merit; those who are self-conceited do not endure. Yan Kejun states: The Heshang and Wang Bi editions include the particle *zhe* 者 after "rely on their own vision," and the same applies to the following four lines. Wei Jiasun remarks: The *Yuzhu* edition includes *zhe* 者 after "vision," but omits it in the next three lines. Yan Qian notes: The *Wen Xuan*’s commentary on the "Indictment of Wang Yuan" omits both instances of *zhe* 者. Additionally, the Palace Library and Suizhou editions read "boast" (*zi rao* 自饶) instead of "self-assertion" (*zi fa* 自伐).

In the Way, these are called surplus food and superfluous conduct. Yan Kejun states: "In the Way" (*qi zai Dao* 其在道) appears as "in the Way, too" (*qi zai Dao ye* 其在道也) in Wang Bi’s edition, and as "in relation to the Way" (*qi yu Dao* 其于道也) in the *Yuzhu* and Heshang editions. Yan Qian notes: The character *zhui* 赘 in the Palace Library and Suizhou editions appears as *chuo* 啜, which is incorrect. The *Fangyan* defines *chuo* 啜 as "to offer food," and the *Zilin* defines it as "to pour wine as an offering, to sacrifice." The phrase *chuo xing* 啜行 is meaningless, likely a phonetic corruption. Wang Dao states: "Conduct" (*xing* 行) should be "form" (*xing* 形). "Superfluous form" refers to forms that are appendages, such as webbed toes. Yi Shunding remarks: "Conduct" (*xing* 行) may be interchangeable with "form" (*xing* 形). "Superfluous form" aligns with Wang Bi’s commentary on "superfluity." Superfluity can refer to form but not to conduct. The *Liezi*’s "Tang’s Questions" chapter reads, "Taihang and Wangwu, the two mountains," and Zhang Zhan’s commentary notes, "行 should be 形." This confirms that *xing* 行 and *xing* 形 were used interchangeably in ancient texts. Zhuang Xichang states: According to Li Yue’s *Daode Zhenjing Xinzhu* from the Tang dynasty: "Like leftover food, like excess flesh on the body." Lin Xi’s *Daode Zhenjing Kouyi* from the Song dynasty states: "Leftover food is discarded; superfluous growths on the body are detested." Chen Jingyuan’s *Daode Zhenjing Cangshi Zuanwei* from the Song dynasty states: "Like discarded leftovers, which people detest; like attached growths, which people find ugly." All three texts interpret *xing* 行 as *xing* 形. Yan Qian notes: Reading *xing* 行 as *xing* 形 is correct. The *Zhuangzi*’s "Webbed Toes" chapter states: "Attached growths and hanging wens emerge from the body and exceed one’s nature." The *Guangya* defines *zhui* 赘 as "a wen." The *Shiming* explains it as "a piece of flesh growing horizontally, attached to the body," or "a tumor." The character *xuan* 县 in "attached growths and hanging wens" is written as *xuan* 悬 in the *Yiqiejing Yinyi* and the *Wen Xuan*’s commentary on Chen Kongzhang’s "Proclamation to Yuzhou on Behalf of Yuan Shao." Since attached growths and hanging wens emerge from the body, they are called "superfluous forms." *Zhui xing* 赘行 should be read as *zhui xing* 赘形, as the characters were interchangeable in ancient texts. Gao Heng states: I suspect "conduct" (*xing* 行) should be "clothing" (*yi* 衣). In ancient script, *yi* 衣 was written as ○, and *xing* 行 as ○, leading to confusion due to their similarity. The *Fayan*’s "Inquiring into the Way" chapter states, "Whether using or not using intelligence, whether benefiting or not benefiting, there is no superfluity or deficiency," and Sima Guang’s commentary notes: "Excess is called superfluity; insufficiency is called deficiency." Thus, superfluity is also surplus. "Surplus food and superfluous clothing" is akin to "surplus food and surplus clothing." When food is in surplus, the hungry detest it; when clothing is in surplus, the cold detest it. Hence, it is said, "Some beings may detest them," which aligns with the modern proverb, "One family’s warmth and fullness invite a thousand families’ resentment."

Here follows the translation:

---

Zhu Qian’s note: Gao’s argument is highly discerning, yet emending the text to explain the *Classic* makes it difficult to inspire confidence. Moreover, the phrase "superfluous clothing" (*zhuì yī* 赘衣) does not simply mean "surplus clothing" (*yú yī* 余衣). The *Guangyun*, under the *ji* 霁 rhyme for *zhuì* 赘, states: "*Zhuì yī* is an official title." It is thus abundantly clear that it cannot form a parallel with "surplus food" (*yú shí* 余食). "Some beings may detest them," and therefore the man of the Way does not dwell in such a state.

Yan Kejun says: In the phrase "some beings may detest them" (*wù huò è zhī* 物或恶之), all versions lack the character *you* 有 ("may"). In the phrase "therefore the man of the Way does not dwell" (*gù yǒu dào bù chǔ* 故有道不处), the *Yu zhu* 御注 and Wang Bi’s editions include the particle *zhe* 者 after *Dao* 道, while the *Heshang Gong* 河上公 edition includes *zhe* 者 and ends the sentence with *ye* 也. Zhu Qian’s note: In the phrase "some (*huò* 或) may detest them," all versions lack the character *you* 有. The *Guan* 馆 edition and *Suizhou* 遂州 edition omit the character *huò* 或 after *you* 有. The *Guangya*, in its first chapter on glosses, states: "*Huò* 或 means *you* 有." This shows that *huò* 或 and *you* 有 were interchangeable in antiquity, and one of them must be superfluous. I suspect that this *you* 有 is a phonetic shift from *chǒu* 丑 ("repulsive"). Xia Song’s *Guwen Sisheng Yun*, in its fifth fascicle, cites an ancient *Laozi* that includes the character *chǒu* 丑, written as ○. Further note: Sima Guang’s commentary states: "These are all cases of external striving and internal depletion. Just as discarded surplus food provokes disgust, so an attached superfluous form provokes revulsion." Here, *chǒu* 丑 ("repulsive") and *è* 恶 ("detest") form a parallel. I suspect that the version Sima Guang saw originally read: "some beings find them repulsive and detest them" (*wù huò chǒu è zhī* 物或丑恶之).

**[Phonology]**
For this chapter, Jiang Sheng’s *Yun Du* 韵读 groups the rhymes as follows: *xíng* 行, *míng* 明, *zhāng* 彰, *gōng* 功, *cháng* 长, and *xíng* 行 (the *yang* 阳 and *dong* 东 rhymes intermingle, with *gōng* 功 rhyming as *guāng* 光); *è* 恶 and *chǔ* 处 rhyme (both in the *yu* 鱼 rhyme group, with *chǔ* 处 in the departing tone). Yao Wentian agrees, though Deng Tingzhen does not include *gōng* 功. Note: *xíng* 行, *míng* 明, *zhāng* 彰, and *cháng* 长 belong to the *yang* 阳 rhyme group, while *gōng* 功 belongs to the *dong* 东 group—this is an instance of *yang* and *dong* rhymes intermingling.

The *Jinglong* 景龙 stele edition contains forty-two characters. The *Guan* 馆 edition’s note mistakenly records "thirty-one characters" (卅 is an error for ○). The *Heshang Gong* 河上公, *Fu* 傅, and Wang [Bi] editions contain forty-eight characters; the Wang [Bi] and Fan [Yingyuan] editions contain forty-seven. The *Heshang Gong* edition titles this chapter "Bitter Kindness" (*Kǔ ēn* 苦恩, twenty-fourth), while the Wang edition titles it "Chapter Twenty-Four" and the Fan edition titles it "The Chapter on One Who Stands on Tiptoe Does Not Endure" (*Qǐ zhě bù lì zhāng dì èrshísì* 跂者不立章第二十四).

---

**Chapter Twenty-Five**
There is a thing, chaotic yet complete, born before Heaven and Earth.
Silent and void!
It stands alone and does not change,
circling everywhere without peril,
and may be called the Mother of Heaven and Earth.
I do not know its name;
I style it the *Dao*.
Forced to name it, I call it *great*.

---

Zhu Qian’s note: In the stele edition, the phrase "I force a name upon it, calling it" (*wú qiǎng wéi zhī míng yuē* 吾强为之名曰) is followed by a character that is indistinct due to erosion; it should be supplemented as *dà* 大 ("great") based on other editions. Furthermore, all editions lack the second *wú* 吾 ("I") in this sentence, which is likely superfluous. The Fan edition includes the characters *gù qiǎng* 故强 ("therefore forced") before *zì* 字 ("style"), while the Fu edition writes *qiǎng* 强 as *qiáng* 強. Fan Yingyuan says: "Wang Bi’s edition matches the ancient version. The *Heshang Gong* edition lacks the character ○, and I follow the ancient version." Liu Shipei says: According to the *Han Feizi*’s *Jie Lao* 解老 chapter, "The sage observes its profound emptiness, employs its all-pervading circulation, and forcibly styles it the *Dao*," the character *qiǎng* 强 ("forced") should precede *zì* 字 ("style"), aligning with the phrase below, "forced to name it, I call it *great*" (*qiǎng wéi zhī míng yuē dà* 强为之名曰大). The present text is missing this character.

Yu Shunding says: According to the *Zhouyi Jijie* (Collected Explications of the *Book of Changes*), volume seventeen, Gan Bao quotes: "Laozi says, *'I do not know its name; forcibly styling it, I call it the Dao.'*" The character *qiǎng* 强 ("forced") precedes *zì* 字 ("style"), matching the version cited in the *Mouzi*. Zhuang Xichang says: Fan [Yingyuan] states that "Wang Bi’s edition matches the ancient version," which implies that Wang’s text also includes *qiǎng* 强 before *zì* 字. In the *Zhuangzi*’s "Zeyang" chapter, Guo Xiang’s commentary reads, "and forcibly styles it the Dao," indicating that Guo’s edition likewise includes *qiǎng* 强. Reasoning from principle, if *great* is a forced name, then *Dao* must also be a forced style—thus, the version with *qiǎng* 强 before *zì* 字 is correct.

□□ passes away; passing away is called *far*; far is called *return*.
Qian Zhi notes: The stele edition includes the characters *dà yuē* 大曰 ("great is called") before *shì* 逝 ("passes away"), though the inscription is blurred and unclear; these should be restored according to other editions. Yan Kejun says: For *"far is called return,"* the *Heshang Gong* and Wang Bi editions write *fǎn* 反 ("return"). Wu Yun says: The Fu and Yizhou editions both write *fǎn* 返 ("return") instead of *fǎn* 反. Qian Zhi notes: The Panxi, Louzheng, Gu Huan, and Zhao Mengfu editions also write *fǎn* 返, matching this stele. *Return* means that all things, in their multiplicity, each revert to their root. To describe the body of the Dao: *great* does not suffice to encompass it, so it is named *passing away*. The *Guangya*’s *Shigu* section states: *"Passing away* 逝 means *to proceed* 行." The *Analects* says, *"The passing away is like this!"* and Huang Kan’s commentary explains: "An expression of departure." Yet *passing away* still does not suffice, so it is further named *far*. The *Shuowen* states: *"Far* 远 means *distant* 辽." The *Erya*’s *Shigu* section says: *"Far* 远 means *remote* 遐." The *Guoyu* commentary explains: "Referring to what lies beyond the reach of ear and eye." However, where there is departure, there must be return, so it is also called *return*. The *Shuowen* states: *"Return* 返 means *to come back* 还." The *Guangya*’s *Shigu* section says: *"Return* 返 means *to revert* 归." In returning, the Dao circulates without cease.

The Dao is great; Heaven is great; Earth is great; the king is great.
Yan Kejun says: In all editions, the character *gù* 故 ("thus") precedes *"the Dao is great."* For *"the king is great,"* all editions include *yì* 亦 ("also") after *wáng* 王 ("king"). Qian Zhi notes: The Fu edition omits *gù* 故, the Suzhou edition omits *yì* 亦, and the Palace Library edition omits both *gù* 故 and *yì* 亦. Additionally, the Fu and Fan editions write *rén* 人 ("human") instead of *wáng* 王 ("king"). Fan Yingyuan says: The character *rén* 人 ("human") in Fu Yi’s edition matches the ancient version, while the *Heshang Gong* edition writes *wáng* 王 ("king"). From the perspective of *Heshang Gong*, the king is the most exalted among humans, reflecting a reverence for the sovereign. However, considering the later phrase *"humans emulate Earth,"* the ancient version’s meaning is coherent. Moreover, humans are the most spiritually endowed of all beings, standing alongside Heaven and Earth as one of the Three Powers. When entrusted with this Dao, humans are indeed also great. Chen Zhu says: The *Shuowen*’s *Da* 大 section states: *"Heaven is great, Earth is great, humans are also great"*—depicting the human form. This is the version Xu Shen encountered. Duan Yucai’s commentary notes: *"The Laozi says, 'The Dao is great, Heaven is great, Earth is great, humans are also great.' ... 'Humans emulate Earth, Earth emulates Heaven, Heaven emulates the Dao.'" Thus, Duan’s edition likely also read *"humans are also great."* Otherwise, he would have specified that modern editions read *"the king is also great."* The correction is now established. Humans are the most spiritually endowed of all beings, the most evolved product of Heaven’s process—hence, *"humans are also great."*

Within the realm, there are four great things, and the king occupies one of them.
Yan Kejun says: For *"and the king occupies one,"* the *Heshang Gong* and Wang Bi editions write *"and the king resides among them."* Qian Zhi notes: The Fan edition writes *rén* 人 ("human") instead of *wáng* 王 ("king"). The Fu edition reads *"and the king occupies one of them in honor,"* where *zūn* 尊 ("honor") is likely a miswriting of *yān* 焉 ("among") due to graphical similarity. The *Guang Hongming Ji*, in Falin’s response to Fu Yi’s critique of Buddhism, quotes the following line as *"and the Dao occupies one of them."* Additionally, the character *chǔ* 处 ("occupies") in the Palace Library and Fu editions is written as *chǔ* 处, while the Fan edition writes *jū* 居 ("resides"); *chǔ* 处 is correct. Jiang Xichang says: "According to Wang Bi’s commentary, *'occupying the greatness of the ruler,'* Wang’s edition writes *jū* 居 as *chǔ* 处. The *Huainanzi*’s *Daoying Xun* also quotes it as *chǔ* 处."

Humans emulate Earth; Earth emulates Heaven; Heaven emulates the Dao; the Dao emulates spontaneity.
Qian Zhi notes: For *"humans emulate Earth,"* the Fu edition retains *rén* 人 ("humans"), while Kou Caizhi’s edition writes *wáng* 王 ("king")—a later interpolation by those who revered the sovereign, altering the original text. This practice has a long history. However, Gu Huan’s *Chengshu* commentary states, *"Humans* 人 refers to the king," which, though convoluted, still serves as evidence that the *Laozi* originally read *rén* 人, not *wáng* 王.

**[Phonology]**
In this chapter, Jiang Yong’s *Yun Du* reads rhymes as follows: *chéng* 成 and *shēng* 生 rhyme (Geng 耕 department); *gǎi* 改, *dài* 殆, *mǔ* 母, and *dào* 道 rhyme (Zhi 之 and You 幽 interdepartmental rhyme, with *gǎi* 改 read as *yǐ* 已 and *dào* 道 rhyming as *tú yǐ fǎn* 徒以反). *Dà* 大 and *shì* 逝 rhyme (Zhi 祭 department, with *dà* 大 read as *tú liè fǎn* 徒列反 and *shì* 逝 as *shí liè fǎn* 时列反). *Yuǎn* 远 and *fǎn* 反 rhyme (Yuan 元 department). Yao Wentian and Deng Tingzhen did not address the character *dào* 道. Qian Zhi notes: *Gǎi* 改, *dài* 殆, and *mǔ* 母 belong to the Zhi 之 department; *dào* 道 belongs to the You 幽 department—these form an interdepartmental rhyme. Xi Di: *Gǎi* 改, *dài* 殆, and *mǔ* 母 rhyme; *shì* 逝, *yuǎn* 远, and *fǎn* 反 rhyme. He adds: *"Shì* 逝 is read as *xiān* 鲜. For example, in the *Book of Songs*’ *Sang Rou*, *'shì bù yǐ zhuó'* 逝不以濯 is cited in the *Mozi*’s *Shang Xian* as *'xiān bù yǐ zhuó'* 鲜不以濯. In the *Book of Songs*’ *Xin Tai*, *xiān* 鲜 rhymes with *cǐ* 泚 and *mí* 弥; in *Gu Feng*, *sōu* 搜 and *wēi* 萎 rhyme with *yuàn* 怨—all serving as examples."*

Chen Zhu: The five instances of *dà* 大 rhyme with *yān* 焉, *tiān* 天, and *rán* 然.
Karlgren: *Dà* 大, *shì* 逝, *yuǎn* 远, and *fǎn* 返 form one rhyme, while *yuǎn* 远 and *fǎn* 返 also rhyme independently. Additionally, *tiān* 天 and *rán* 然 rhyme.
Qian Zhi notes: *Yuǎn* 远 and *fǎn* 反 rhyme. The *Analects*’ *Zi Han* chapter cites lost *Shi* 诗 verses; the *Chu Ci*’s *Li Sao*, *Guo Shang*, and *Ai Ying* all provide collateral evidence. Furthermore, the *dà* 大 in *"qiǎng míng zhī yuē dà"* 强名之曰大 rhymes distantly with the five *dà* 大 below.
Chen Di states: *"Gǎi"* 改 is pronounced *jǐ* 己, as *Shuowen* lists *jǐ* 己 as its phonetic. In the *Laozi*: *"Dúlì ér bù gǎi, zhōu xíng ér bù dài"* 独立而不改，周行而不殆; the *Zhuangzi* cites an ancient poem: *"Měi chéng zài jiǔ, è chéng bù jí gǎi"* 美成在久，恶成不及改.
The *Jinglong* stele version contains seventy-nine characters; the *Guan* edition’s chapter-end note matches this count. The *Heshang Gong* version has eighty-six characters, Wang Bi’s eighty-five, Fu Yi’s eighty-seven, and Fan Yingyuan’s eighty-eight. The *Heshang Gong* titles it *"Xiàng Xuán Zhāng Dì Èrshíwǔ"* 象玄章第二十五, Wang Bi’s *"Èrshíwǔ Zhāng"* 二十五章, and Fan Yingyuan’s *"Yǒu Wù Hùn Chéng Zhāng Dì Èrshíwǔ"* 有物混成章第二十五. The *Jinglong* stele mistakenly merges the following chapter’s *"Jìng wèi zào jūn"* 静为躁君 into this one.

**Chapter Twenty-Six**
*Virtue is the root of the light; stillness is the lord of the restless.*
Qian Zhi notes: Huang Kan’s *Lunyu Xue’er Yishu* cites it as *"Zhòng wèi qīng gēn, jìng wèi zào běn"* 重为轻根，静为躁本—*"gēn"* 根 and *"běn"* 本 form a parallel, and the meaning is superior.
*Thus the noble person travels all day without leaving the baggage train.*
Yan Kejun states: *"Shì yǐ jūnzǐ"* 是以君子 appears as *"shì yǐ shèngrén"* 是以圣人 in the *Heshang Gong* and Wang Bi versions.
Qian Zhi notes: Han Fei’s *Jie Lao* uses *"jūnzǐ"* 君子; the *Panxi*, *Lou Zheng*, *Gao Diao*, Fu, Fan, and Wang Xizhi editions all concur. Karlgren’s edition omits the four characters *"shì yǐ jūnzǐ"* 是以君子. The *Suizhou* edition reads *"xíng zhōng rì"* 行终日 instead of *"zhōng rì xíng"* 终日行. The *Yuzhu* and *Jingfu* editions write *"zī"* 辎 as ○, with Luo Yun noting: "This is an alternate form of *zī* 辎." Hong Yixuan states: The *Heshang Gong* commentary reads: *"Zī, jìng yě. Shèngrén zhōng rì xíng Dào, bù lí qí jìng yǔ zhòng yě."* 辎，静也。圣人终日行道，不离其静与重也. Yixuan notes: The *Wen Xuan*’s *Dongjing Fu* cites Xue Zong’s annotation: *"Zīzhòng, chē yě."* 辎重，车也, and Li Shan’s annotation: *"Zhāng Jí yuē: ‘Zīzhòng, yǒu yī zhī chē yě.’"* 张楫曰：「辎重，有衣之车也。」 This suggests the noble person remains as though within a covered carriage to nurture stillness—it does not mean *zī* 辎 itself signifies stillness. The commentary’s interpretation is flawed.
Xu Zi states: According to ancient glosses, *"zī"* 辎 was never defined as *"jìng"* 静... The *Wen Xuan* annotations are superior to the gloss *"zī, jìng yě"* 辎，静也.
The terms *"zīzhòng"* 辎重, *"róng guān"* 荣观, *"yàn chǔ"* 燕处, and *"wàn shèng zhī zhǔ"* 万乘之主 are all parallel in structure.
Qian Zhi notes: Hong and Xu’s arguments are sound. Fang Risheng’s *Yunhui Xiaobu* cites: The *Shuowen* defines *"zī"* 辎 as *"píng chē, qián yī chē, hòu cóng chē, zī shēng"* 軿车，前衣车，后从车，甾声, with Xu Shen adding: *"Suǒwèi kù chē"* 所谓库车. The *Zilin* states: *"Zài yīwù chē, qián hòu jiē bì"* 载衣物车，前后皆蔽. The *Zuozhuan*’s *Xuan 12* *Zhengyi* cites the *Shuowen*: *"Zī, yī míng píng, qián hòu bì yě"* 辎，一名軿，前后蔽也. The *Hou Hanshu*’s *Yu Fu Zhi* annotation reads: *"Píng chē yǒu yī bì wú hòu yuán zhě, wèi zhī zī"* 軿车有衣蔽无后辕者，谓之辎. The *Shiming* states: *"Zī, píng yě. Yǒu dǐ yuē zī, wú dǐ yuē píng"* 辎，屏也。有邸曰辎，无邸曰軿. The *Guangwu Ji* annotation cites the *Shiming*: *"Zī, yě. Wèi jūn liáng shíwù zá zài zhī, yǐ qí léi zhòng, gù chēng zīzhòng"* 辎，也。谓军粮什物杂载之，以其累重，故称辎重. The *Qian Han Shu*’s *Han Anguo Zhuan* reads *"jī zīzhòng"* 击辎重, with Yan Shigu noting: *"Zī wèi yī chē, zhòng wèi zài zhòngwù chē, gù xíngzhě zhī zī, zǒng yuē zīzhòng"* 辎谓衣车，重谓载重物车，故行者之资，总曰辎重. (Volume 2)
Fang’s research is thorough: *Zīzhòng* 辎重 refers to a covered wagon carrying supplies, enclosed front and rear, laden with weight—hence the term. In antiquity, ceremonial processions used passenger carriages, while military marches employed war chariots, both followed by *zīzhòng* 辎重 wagons. This metaphor illustrates that the noble person’s daily conduct must always be rooted in weightiness, never acting recklessly.
*Though there be splendid vistas, they dwell in tranquil detachment.*
Yan Kejun states: *"Yàn chǔ"* 燕处 appears as *"yàn chǔ"* 宴处 in the Wang Bi and Fu Yi versions.
Qian Zhi notes: The current Wang Bi edition writes *"yàn"* 燕; the *Yuzhu*, *Jingfu*, and *Guan* editions also use *"yàn"* 燕. The *Shiwen* lists *"yàn"* 宴: *"Yú jiàn fǎn, Jiǎnwén yún: ‘Wèi jìng sī zhī suǒ yàn jū yě.’"* 于见反，简文云：「谓静思之所宴居也。」 The *Wen Xuan*’s *You Tiantai Shan Fu* annotation concurs.
*How can a ruler of ten thousand chariots treat the world lightly with his own person?*
Yan Kejun states: *"Rúhé"* 如何 appears as *"nàihé"* 奈何 in other editions; *"yǐ shēn"* 以身 includes an *"ér"* 而 above *"yǐ"* 以 in other versions.
Jiao Hong states: *"Nàihé"* 奈何 appears as *"rú zhī hé"* 如之何 in ancient editions.
Qian Zhi notes: The Fu and Fan ancient editions both read *"rú zhī hé"* 如之何, though the *"zhī"* 之 may be superfluous. *"Nàihé"* 奈何 is likely a gloss, as the *Qiang Ben Chengshu*’s commentary reads *"rúhé nàihé yě"* 如何奈何也—this serves as evidence.
*Lightness loses the root; restlessness loses the lord.*
Yan Kejun states: *"Qīng zé shī chén"* 轻则失臣 appears as *"shī běn"* 失本 in Wang Bi and *"shī gēn"* 失根 in the *Dayian*.
Qian Zhi notes: The correct text should read *"qīng zé shī gēn, zào zé shī jūn"* 轻则失根，躁则失君, forming a parallel with the opening line *"zhòng wèi qīng gēn, jìng wèi zào jūn"* 重为轻根，静为躁君.

The Suizhou edition, Fu edition, and Fan edition all render *"shī chén"* 失臣 as *"shī běn"* 失本.
Bi Yuan states: Wang Bi follows the *Heshang Gong* edition in reading *"qīng zé shī chén"* 轻则失臣.
Fan Yingyuan says: The character *"běn"* 本 is consistent with the ancient editions of Yan Zun and Wang Bi. The *Heshang Gong* edition reads *"qīng zé shī chén"* 轻则失臣, which does not cohere with the preceding text; the ancient edition should be followed.
Ma Xulun says: The original *Laozi* text reads *"gēn"* 根. The character *"gēn"* 根 was corrupted into *"mù"* 木 through scribal omission, and later scholars emended it to *"běn"* 本 to suit the meaning.
Furthermore, the *Yongle Dadian* preserves Wang Bi’s reading *"qīng zé shī gēn"* 轻则失根, and Wu Cheng, Jiao Hong, Li Zhi, and Shi Deqing’s editions all concur.
Yu Yue says: This should be followed. The opening of this chapter reads *"zhòng wèi qīng gēn, jìng wèi zào jūn"* 重为轻根，静为躁君, so it concludes with *"qīng zé shī gēn, zào zé shī jūn"* 轻则失根，躁则失君, meaning that without heaviness there is no root, and without stillness there is no lord. As for the pairing of *"jūn"* 君 and *"chén"* 臣, this was a later interpolation by those who exalted the ruler and does not reflect the original *Laozi* text.

**[Phonology]**
In this chapter, Jiang Yong’s *Rhyme Readings* notes:
*"gēn"* 根 and *"jūn"* 君 rhyme (Wen rhyme group);
*"xíng"* 行 and *"zhòng"* 重 rhyme (Yang and Dong rhyme groups, with *"zhòng"* 重 rhyming as *"zhái wáng"* 宅王);
*"guān"* 观 and *"rán"* 然 rhyme (Yuan rhyme group, with *"guān"* 观 pronounced as *"juān"* 涓);
*"zhǔ"* 主 and *"xià"* 下 rhyme (Hou and Yu rhyme groups, with *"zhǔ"* 主 rhyming as *"zhǔ"* 渚).
*"chén"* 臣 and *"jūn"* 君 rhyme (Dong and Zhen rhyme groups).
Qian Zhi notes: Gao Benhan concurs.
*"xíng"* 行 belongs to the Yang rhyme group, *"zhòng"* 重 to the Dong rhyme group, with Yang and Dong being interchangeable.
*"chén"* 臣 belongs to the Zhen rhyme group, *"jūn"* 君 to the Wen rhyme group, with Wen and Zhen being interchangeable.
However, *"shī chén"* 失臣 should follow the *Yongle Dadian*’s reading of *"shī gēn"* 失根 to correspond with the opening line, with *"gēn"* 根 and *"jūn"* 君 forming a rhyme.

The *Jinglong Stele* edition contains forty-six characters; the *Guan* edition notes "thirty-six characters" at the end of the chapter, where "thirty" is a corruption of "○."
The *Heshang Gong* and Wang Bi editions contain forty-seven characters; the Fu and Fan editions contain forty-nine.
The *Heshang Gong* edition titles this chapter *"Zhòng Dé Dì Èrshíliù"* 重德第二十六; the Wang Bi edition titles it *"Dì Èrshíliù Zhāng"* 二十六章; the Fan edition titles it *"Zhòng Wèi Qīng Gēn Zhāng Dì Èrshíliù"* 重为轻根章第二十六.

**Chapter Twenty-Seven**
*Good traveling leaves no wheel tracks;*
Luo Zhenyu says: The *Jingfu* edition includes the character *"zhě"* 者 after *"xíng"* 行, and similarly after *"shàn yán"* 善言, *"shàn jiào"* 善教, *"shàn bì"* 善闭, and *"shàn jié"* 善结. The *Guangming* edition concurs.
Qian Zhi notes: The Muromachi edition also concurs.
Yan Kejun says: *"Zhé jì"* 辙迹 appears as *"chè jì"* 彻迹 in the *Heshang Gong* edition and as *"chè jì"* 彻迹 in Wang Bi’s edition.
Emperor Jianwen of Liang states: It should have the *"chē"* 车 radical; the current *"chì"* 彳 radical is due to the scarcity of ancient characters.
Wu Yun says: *"Zhé"* 辙 appears as *"chè"* 彻 in the Fu edition.
Lu’s *Baojing Shīwén Kǎoyì* notes: The *Shuowen* lacks the character *"zhé"* 辙. The *Zhuangzi*, *Zhanguo Ce*, and *Shiji* all use *"yì"* 轶 for *"zhé"* 辙.
Note: *"Yì"* 轶 is a loan character; the proper form should be *"zhé"* 辙.
Qian Zhi notes: In the *Laozi*, the characters *"chè"* 彻 and *"zhé"* 辙 have distinct meanings. Chapter Seventy-Nine reads *"wú dé sī chè"* 无德司彻, using *"chè"* 彻, while this chapter reads *"shàn xíng wú zhé jì"* 善行无辙迹, using *"zhé"* 辙.
The *Gǔ Wén Sìshēng Yùn* by Xia Song, volume five, cites the ancient *Laozi* with *"chè"* 彻 written as ○ and *"zhé"* 辙 as ○, where *"zhé"* 辙 denotes wheel tracks.
Peng Song’s *Shīwén* states: *"Zhé"* 辙 is pronounced as *"lǐ zhí liè"* 李直列切, meaning the ruts left by wheels rolling over the ground.

"Good words bear no blemish," Wang Bi annotates as *"xiá zhé"* 瑕谪. The *Imperial Commentary* and Heshang Gong’s version render it as *"xiá"* 瑕 [lacuna]. Yan Kejun states: *"Jiǎ"* 瘕 appears as a variant; the Yizhou edition concurs. Wu Yun notes: "Without blemish," modern editions use the vulgar character. Qian Zhi observes: The *Shiwen* lists *"zhé"* 谪, and *"zhé"* 谪 is also acceptable. Yang Xiong’s *Fangyan*, chapter three, defines *"zhé"* 谪 as "anger," with Guo Pu’s annotation: "mutual reproach and anger." Furthermore, Xia Song’s *Gǔ Wén Sìshēng Yùn*, volume three, cites the ancient *Laozi* with *"zhé"* 谪 written as ○, while the Palace and Suizhou editions render it as *"shì"* 适. All denote flaws in jade.

The *Guanzi*, *Shui Di* chapter, states: "In jade, both *"xiá"* 瑕 and *"shì"* 适 are visible." Gao Heng comments: *"Xiá"* 瑕 signifies refinement. Yin’s annotation: *"Xiá shì"* 瑕适 are jade flaws. The *Xunzi*, *You Zuo* chapter, reads: *"Xiá shì bìng jiàn"* 瑕适并见, meaning "truth." The *Lüshi Chunqiu*, *Ju Nan* chapter, similarly states "without flaw," as *"xiá"* 瑕 and *"shì"* 适 were interchangeable in antiquity; *"tì"* 瓋 is a later specialized character. The *Wu Xia* chapter states: "Even a jade inch long must have *"tì xiá"* 瓋瑕," where *"shì"* 适 and *"cī"* 疵 are synonymous with flaws or defects.

"Good reckoning requires no counting rods." Yan Kejun notes: *"Shàn jì"* 善计 appears as *"shàn shǔ"* 善数 in Wang Bi’s edition. *"Chóu cè"* 筹策 is rendered as *"chóu suàn"* 筹算 in the *Imperial Commentary*. Fan Yingyuan states: *"Shǔ"* 数 is read in the third tone. Wang Bi and Yan Zun follow the ancient text, while Heshang Gong uses *"jì"* 计. Luo Zhenyu observes: The Heshang Gong, Jinglong, *Imperial Commentary*, British, Guangming, and Jingfu editions all use *"jì"* 计. In *"chóu cè"* 筹策, the *Imperial Commentary* and British edition write *"cè"* 策 as *"suàn"* 算. Qian Zhi notes: The *Taiping Yulan*, volume 659, also uses *"suàn"* 算, while the Palace edition writes it as ○.

The *Lunyu*, *Ba Yi* chapter, *Jijie* annotation states: "Excessive drinking is rare," with the *Shiwen* gloss: *"chóu"* 筹 is a counting rod. Zhu Junsheng remarks: *"Suàn"* 算, six inches long, is used for calendrical reckoning. Composed of *zhú* 竹 and *nòng* 弄, it signifies that constant handling prevents errors. The character is also written as *"chóu"* 筹.

The skilled at securing use no bolts nor bars, yet none can open;
Yan Kejun notes: "None can open" — all editions include *"er"* 而 above *"bu"* 不, and the following clause is the same.
Sun Kuang states: *"Jian"* 键 is now written as *"jiàn"* 楗.
Ji Yun observes: The original text had *"jiàn"* 楗 as *"jiàn"* 键.
Qian Zhi notes: *"Guānjiàn"* 关键 is a compound; the Fu Yi edition writes *"jiàn"* 键.
The *Huainanzi*, *Sayings of Mountains*, quotes: "The skilled at securing use no bolts nor bars," and the *Dao and Its Power* chapter also writes *"jiàn"* 键.
Fan Yingyuan says: *"Jiàn"* 楗 is the wooden bar for doors; some add the *"jīn"* 金 radical, which is incorrect. The horizontal is called *"guān"* 关, the vertical *"jiàn"* 楗.
Fu Yi states: The ancient character is written as ○.
Qian Zhi notes: Writing it as ○ is correct. *"Guān"* 关, per the *Shuowen*: "A wooden bar placed horizontally to secure doors and gates, from *mén* 门, with ○ as phonetic." The *Huainanzi*, *Surveying Obscurities*, states: "City gates are not barred," which is the original meaning of *"guān"* 关. Here, it extends to mean the horizontal bar for closing doors. ○ is a Chu dialect term in the *Laozi*, a loan for *"jiàn"* 楗.
The *Fangyan*, volume 5: "Door keys, east of the Pass, in the regions of Chen and Chu, are called *jiàn* 键, and the character is also written as ○." Now, ○ is the ancient form. The *Gǔwén Sìshēng Yùn*, volume 3, by Xia Song, cites the ancient *Laozi* as writing ○.

The skilled at binding use no cords nor knots, yet none can undo.
Qian Zhi notes: *"Shéngyuē"* 绳约 is a compound. The *Shuowen* states: *"Shéng"* 绳 is rope; *"yuē"* 约 is binding. The *Zhuangzi*, *Webbed Toes*, says: "Relying on cords, knots, glue, and lacquer for firmness is an encroachment on virtue." *"Yuē"* 约 also means rope; *"shéngyuē"* 绳约 is akin to modern "cord and rope." The *Zuozhuan*, Duke Ai 11, records Gongsun Hui saying: "People use *xún* 寻 of rope, but Wu people have short hair," with Du Yu’s note: *"Yuē"* 约 is rope. The *Yili*, *Jì Xī Jì*, states: *"Yuē suí yuē pèi"* 约绥约辔, with Zheng Xuan’s note: *"Yuē"* 约 is rope. Old commentaries take *"yuē"* 约 as the *"yuē"* 约 of restraint, which does not align with the ancient meaning of the *Laozi*.

Thus, the sage is ever skilled at saving people, and so discards none;
Ever skilled at saving things, and so discards nothing.
This is called inheriting enlightenment.
Yan Kejun notes: "And so discards none" — all editions write *"gù"* 故 for *"ér"* 而, and the following clause is the same.
Sun Kuang’s *Gǔjīn Běn Kǎozhèng* states: The four lines "Ever skilled at saving people" are absent in one edition. *"Gù"* 故 is written as *"ér"* 而 in one version.
