*"Without levelness, there is no slope; without going, there is no **returning**."*

Thus, **"returning"** is the same as **"reversing."** Hence, *Lǎozǐ* (老子) says:
*"When all things arise together, I observe their **returning**. Things drift like clouds, each **returning** to its root. Returning to the root is called **stillness**; stillness is called **restoring the mandate**."*
He also says:
*"**Returning** to the infant,"*
*"**Returning** to the boundless,"*
*"**Returning** to the uncarved block,"*
—all meaning **reversing and returning**.

*"Great is called **passing**; **passing** is called **distant**; **distant** is called **returning**,"*
—meaning one must first go far before **returning**.

**Returning** is inherently **motion**; without motion, there is no **returning**, hence:
*"The **returning** is the **Dao’s** motion."*

**Returning** is inherently **contrary**; only by being contrary does it become harmonious, hence:
*"The profound **virtue** is deep and far, contrary to things, and only then does it attain the greatest harmony."*

As for *"the weak is the **Dao’s** use,"* this aligns with the *Yì*’s *Kūn* (坤), where *Gān* (干) is hidden within *Kūn*, hence called **weak**. The *Yì* says:
*"The hidden dragon does not act,"*
while *Lǎozǐ* speaks of *"the use of non-action,"*—this is the **Dao’s** use.

*"All things under Heaven are born from existence; existence arises from non-existence."*

**Commentary by Yán Kějūn (严可均):**
The *Héshàng Běn* (河上本) and *Wáng Běn* (王本) render *"tiānxià wànwù"* (天下万物) as *"wànwù"* (万物), while the *Yù Zhù* (御注) reads *"zhī wù"* (之物). **Commentary by Jiānzhī (谦之):**
The *Guāngmíng*, *Jǐngfú*, and *Yù Lǎn* (御览) all cite *"wànwù"* (万物), matching the stone inscription. *Xíng Xuán* (邢玄), *Pánxī* (磻溪), *Lóu Zhèng* (楼正), *Shìtīng* (室町), *Fù* (傅), *Fàn* (范), *Gāo* (高), and *Zhào* (赵) all read *"zhī wù"* (之物), aligning with the *Yù Zhù*. The *Dūnhuáng Běn* (敦煌本) and *Yán Zōng Běn* (严遵本) read *"tiāndì zhī wù"* (天地之物).

Additionally, the *Jǐngfú* and *Fàn Běn* (范本) render *"wú"* (无) as *"wú"* (无). *Mǎ Xùlún* (马叙伦) notes:
*"Wáng Pì’s (王弼) annotation says: ‘All things under Heaven have existence as their source.’ Thus, Wáng (王) also wrote *‘zhī wù’* (之物). Those now writing *‘wànwù’* (万物) later emended it based on the *Héshàng Běn* (河上本)."*

**Commentary by Jiānzhī (谦之):**
In the opening chapter, *"Wúmíng, tiāndì shǐ; yǒumíng, wànwù mǔ"* (无名，天地始；有名，万物母), *"wúmíng"* (无名) opposes *"yǒumíng"* (有名), *"tiāndì"* (天地) opposes *"wànwù"* (万物), and *"shǐ"* (始) opposes *"mǔ"* (母). Here, since it speaks of *"yǒu"* (有) and *"wú"* (无), *"tiānxià wànwù"* (天下万物) should read *"tiāndì wànwù"* (天地万物) for greater coherence.

**[Phonology]**
This chapter is read without rhyme by *Jiāng Shì* (江氏), *Yáo Wéndiàn* (姚文田), and *Xí Dòng* (奚侗). *Dèng Tíngzhēn* (邓廷桢), *Chén Zhù* (陈柱), and *Gāo Běnhàn* (高本汉) note that *"dòng"* (动) and *"yòng"* (用) rhyme, which is correct.

**Note:** *Kǒng Guǎngsēn*’s *Shī Shēnglèi* (诗声类) categorizes *"dòng"* (动) and *"yòng"* (用) under *yángshēng* (阳声) *dōng* (东), *zhōng* (钟), and *jiāng* (江) as one rhyme group, citing *Lǎozǐ*:
*"The **returning** is the **Dao’s** motion; the **weak** is the **Dao’s** use."*

The *Jǐnglóng Bēi* (景龙碑) version contains **21 characters**; the *Dūnhuáng Běn* (敦煌本), *Héshàng Běn* (河上本), *Wáng Běn* (王本), *Fù Běn* (傅本), and *Fàn Běn* (范本) all match this.

The *Héshàng Běn* (河上本) titles this *"Qùyòng dì sìshí"* (去用第四十); the *Wáng Běn* (王本) titles it *"Sìshí zhāng"* (四十章); the *Fàn Běn* (范本) titles it *"Fǎnzhě Dào zhī Dòng zhāng dì sìshí"* (反者道之动章第四十).

---
**Chapter Forty-One**
The superior person, hearing the **Dao**, diligently practices it;
**Commentary by Yán Kějūn (严可均):**
*"Qín ér xíng zhī"* (勤而行之), the *Yù Zhù* (御注) omits *"zhī"* (之), while *Fù Yì* (傅奕) renders it *"ér qín xíng zhī"* (而勤行之).

**Commentary by Jiānzhī (谦之):**
The *Fǎjīng Dūnyǐ Běn* (法京敦乙本) reads *"qín néng xíng"* (懃能行), with *Luǒ Juàn* (罗卷) matching the stone inscription, differing from the *Wǔnèi Běn* (武内本). The *Fàn Běn* (范本) reads *"qín"* (懃), annotated as *"gǔběn"* (古本). **Note:** *Xià Sūn*’s (夏竦) *Gǔwén Sìshēngyùn* (古文四声韵) cites the ancient *Lǎozǐ* as *"qín"* (懃).

The middle person, hearing the **Dao**, holds it as if it exists, as if it does not;
The inferior person, hearing the **Dao**, **derides** it.

**Commentary by Jiānzhī (谦之):**
The various manuscripts read *"xiào"* (笑), the *Suìzhōu Běn* (遂州本) reads *"[missing character]"*, and the *Yù Zhù* (御注) marks it *"○"*. The *Fù* (傅) and *Fàn* (范) versions read *"ér dàxiào zhī"* (而大笑之).

**Commentary by Yú Yuè (俞樾):**
According to *Wáng Shì Niánsūn*’s *Duìshū Zhìzhí* (读书杂志):
*"‘Dàxiào zhī’ (大笑之) was originally ‘dà ér xiào zhī’ (大而笑之), akin to ‘yū ér xiào zhī’ (迂而笑之)."* The *Móu Zǐ* (牟子) cites *Lǎozǐ* as *"dà ér xiào zhī"* (大而笑之). The *Bàopǔ Zǐ*’s *Wéizhǐ Piān* (抱朴子微旨篇) also states:
*"‘Dà ér xiào zhī’ (大而笑之), this has been long so."*

Now, according to *Wáng*’s (王) explanation, this is correct. *"Xiàshì wén dào, dà ér xiào zhī"* (下士闻道，大而笑之) opposes the preceding *"Shàngshì wén dào, qín ér xíng zhī"* (上士闻道，勤而行之).

*Fù Yì* (傅奕) renders:
*"Shàngshì wén dào, ér qín xíng zhī; xiàshì wén dào, ér dàxiào zhī"* (上士闻道，而勤行之；下士闻道，而大笑之),
—mistakenly placing the *"ér"* (而) at the sentence’s beginning. However, the *"ér"* (而) in the latter sentence still allows us to infer the original.

*"Ér qín xíng zhī"* (而勤行之) is a misplacement of *"qín ér xíng zhī"* (勤而行之). Thus, *"ér dàxiào zhī"* (而大笑之) is a misplacement of *"dà ér xiào zhī"* (大而笑之), which can now be confirmed.

**Commentary by Gāo Hēng (高亨):**
*"Wáng"* (亡) is read as *"wàng"* (忘); the two characters were interchangeable in antiquity. The *Shī Jiǎ Yuè* (诗假乐) states *"bù qiān bù wàng"* (不愆不忘), and the *Shuōyuàn Jiànběn Piān* (说苑建本篇) cites *"wàng"* (忘) as *"wáng"* (亡).

Xúnzǐ’s *Effort in Learning* (劝学篇) reads *“yān màn wàng shēn”* (怠慢忘身), while the *Great Rites of Dài* (大戴礼·劝学篇) renders *“wàng”* (忘) as *“wáng”* (亡). In the *Lǚshì Chūnqiū* (吕氏春秋·权勋篇), it states *“shì wàng jīng guó zhī shèjì ér bù xù wú zhòng yě”* (是忘荆国之社稷而不恤吾众也), and similarly, the *Han Feizi* (十过篇) and *Huáinánzǐ* (人间篇) use *“wàng”* (忘) as *“wáng”* (亡). These serve as further evidence.

The *Shī* (诗·绿衣) states *“xīn zhī yōu yǐ, hé wéi qí wáng”* (心之忧矣，曷维其亡), with Zhèng’s annotation *“wáng zhī yán wàng yě”* (亡之言忘也), following the same pattern.

The *Yìjīng Liè Jiě* (周易·略例) declares:
*“Cún yán zhě, fēi dé xiàng zhě yě; cún xiàng zhě, fēi dé yì zhě yě.
Wàng yán zhě, nǎi dé xiàng zhě yě; wàng xiàng zhě, nǎi dé yì zhě yě.”*
(存言者，非得象者也；存象者，非得意者也。
忘言者，乃得象者也；忘象者，乃得意者也.)

Here, *“cún”* (存) and *“wàng”* (忘) are paired opposites, aligning with the passage’s structure. This does not suffice to elucidate the *Dao*.

Lǔ Zhènyù (罗振玉) notes that the *Dūnhuáng* manuscript includes *“zhī”* (之) after *“xiào”* (笑). Thus, the original text reads:
*“Jiàn yán yǒu zhī”* (建言有之).

Yán Kějūn (严可均) observes that the Imperial Commentary lacks the *“gù”* (故) character. My examination reveals that the editions by Xíng Xuán (邢玄), Jǐng Fú (景福), Qìngyáng (庆阳), Pánxī (磻溪), Lóuzhèng (楼正), Gāo Yì (高翿), and Shìmǎchōng (室町本) align with the Imperial Commentary. The *Wǔnèi Dūnyǐ* (武内敦乙本) and Gǔ Huān’s (顾欢) editions insert *“shì yǐ”* (是以) after *“jiàn yán”* (建言). Lǔ Zhènyù states that the *Dūnhuáng* text reads *“shì yǐ jiàn yán yǒu zhī yuē”* (是以建言有之曰). My review confirms that the Fù Yì (傅奕) and Fàn (范) editions also include *“yuē”* (曰).

Fàn Yìngyuán (范应元) notes that Wáng Bì (王弼), Sūn Dēng (孙登), and Ruǎn Xián (阮咸) follow the ancient manuscripts, while the Héshànggōng (河上公) edition omits *“yuē”* (曰). Xí Dòng (奚侗) argues that *“jiàn yán”* (建言) likely refers to an ancient text title.

Gāo Hēng (高亨) suggests *“jiàn yán”* (建言) may be the title of a book referenced by Lǎozǐ.

The *Zhuāngzǐ* (庄子·人间世篇) cites *“fǎ yán”* (法言), the *Hùguānzǐ* (鹖冠子·天权篇) references *“yì yán”* (逸言), and the *Guǐgǔzǐ* (鬼谷子·谋篇) invokes *“yīn yán”* (阴言). The *Hànshū Yìwénzhì* (汉书·艺文志) lists *“huáng yán”* (谰言), with Bān Gu’s annotation *“bù zhī zhǔzhe”* (不知作者), demonstrating that naming texts with *“yán”* (言) was a common ancient practice.

---
明道若昧，进道若退，
Yán Kějūn (严可均) notes that *“ruò lèi”* (若类) is rendered *“ruò chǎn”* (若颣) in the Imperial Commentary and Wáng Bì’s (王弼) edition.

My examination reveals:
- *“Jìn dào ruò tuì”* (进道若退) has *“tuì”* (退) marked *“○”* in the Imperial Commentary.
- Fù Yì (傅奕), Péng Zhì (彭耜), Lín Xīyì (林希逸), and Zhào Mèngfǔ (赵孟俯) place this sentence after *“yí dào ruò lèi”* (夷道若类).
- The *“lèi”* (类) character appears in the *Shìwén* (释文), *Héshànggōng* (河上公), *Dūnhuáng* (敦煌), *Jǐngfú* (景福), *Nǎijuàn* (柰卷), and *Gǔ Huān* (顾欢) editions, while Fù (傅) and Fàn (范) use *“chǎn”* (颣).

Fàn (范) states:
*“Chǎn”* (颣), in ancient manuscripts, is pronounced *“lěi”* (耒), referring to a silk node. The *Héshànggōng* (河上公) edition uses *“lèi”* (类). I follow the ancient manuscript here.

My review confirms *“chǎn”* (颣) and *“lèi”* (类) were interchangeable in antiquity. The *Guǎngyǎ* (广雅·释言) defines *“chǎn”* (颣) as *“jié”* (节), and the *Tōngsúwén* (通俗文) states *“duō jié yuē chǎn”* (多节曰颣). The *Jiǎnwén Zhù* (简文注) for *“yí dào ruò chǎn”* (夷道若颣) explains *“cī”* (疵, flaw). The *Huáinánzǐ Fànlùn* (淮南子·泛论) describes *“míngyuè zhī zhū, bùnéng wú chǎn”* (明月之珠，不能无颣), with the annotation *“chǎn, pán ruò sī zhī jié chǎn yě”* (颣，盘若丝之结颣也). Borrowed as *“lì”* (戾), the *Zuǒzhuàn Zhāoshí* (左传·昭十六) uses *“xíng zhī pō chǎn”* (刑之颇颣), with Shì Zhù (服注) defining it as *“bù píng”* (不平, unevenness). Since *“píng”* (平) and *“bù píng”* (不平) are opposites, *“yí dào ruò chǎn”* (夷道若颣) signifies *“the Way of uniformity appears flawed.”*

---
上德若谷，大白若辱，
Wǔnèi Yìxióng (武内义雄) notes that the *Dūn* (敦) and *Suì* (遂) manuscripts render *“gǔ”* (谷) as *“sú”* (俗). Lǔ Zhènyù (罗振玉) observes that *“dà bái ruò rǔ”* (大白若辱) appears before *“shàng dé ruò gǔ”* (上德若谷) in the *Dūnhuáng* text.

My examination of the *Lǔjuàn Dūnwù* (罗卷敦戊本) confirms *“gǔ”* (谷) is not written as *“sú”* (俗), differing from the *Fǎjīng Dūnyǐ* (法京敦乙本). Chéng Xuányīng (成玄英) explains:
*“Gǔ”* (谷) was also written as *“sú”* (俗), meaning *“even one who embodies virtue can forget it, indistinguishable from the vulgar.”*

Mǎ Xùlún (马叙伦) states:
*“All editions render it ‘gǔ’ (谷), a shorthand for ‘sú’ (俗). High virtue appears as the common crowd—embodying the meaning of blending with the world.”*

Additionally, the *Dàozàng Wángběn* (道藏王本) writes *“tài”* (太) instead of *“dà”* (大). The *“rǔ”* (辱) character is marked *“○”* in Fù (傅) and Fàn (范) editions.

Fàn (范) explains:
*“○”* is pronounced *“rǔ”* (辱), meaning *“black filth.”* Ancient manuscripts follow this, while the *Héshànggōng* (河上公) edition uses *“rǔ”* (辱).

Bì Yàn (毕沅) notes:
*“○”* is rendered *“rǔ”* (辱) in the *Héshànggōng* (河上公) and Wáng Bì (王弼) editions. Those writing *“○”* follow the principle of *“yǐ bái zào zī”* (以白造缁, transforming white into black). The *Shuōwén Jiězì* (说文解字) does not list *“○”*.

My review confirms the *Yùpiàn* (玉篇) defines *“○”* as *“gòuhēi”* (垢黑, filth and blackness), an ancient form of *“rǔ”* (辱). The *Guǎngyǎ Shìgǔ* (广雅·释诂三) states *“rǔ, wū yě, yòu è yě”* (辱, 污也, 又恶也, defilement and evil). The *Yílì Shìhūn Lǐ* (仪礼·士昏礼) annotates *“jīn wú zǐ rǔ”* (今吾子辱) as *“yǐ bái zào zī yuē rǔ”* (以白造缁曰辱). The *Sūwèn Qìjiāo Biàn Dàlùn* (素问·气交变大论) states *“hēi qì nǎi rǔ”* (黑气乃辱). Since *“rǔ”* (辱) carries the meaning of blackness, opposing *“bái”* (白), the phrase *“dà bái ruò rǔ”* (大白若辱) follows this contrast.

Yì Shùndǐng (易顺鼎) clarifies:
*“Rǔ”* (辱) in the *Yílì Shìhūn Lǐ* (仪礼·士昏礼) annotation *“yǐ bái zào zī yuē rǔ”* (以白造缁曰辱) aligns with this usage. Transforming white into black—removing traces of defilement—hence *“rǔ”* (辱).

This reflects Lǎozǐ’s original intent, corroborated by the *Shīchuán* (诗传) and *Lǐzhù* (礼注).

---
广德若不足，
My examination of the *Zhuāngzǐ Yùyán Piān* (庄子·寓言篇) reveals:
*“Lǎozǐ yuē: ‘Ér suīsuī xūxū, ér wéi yǔ jū? Dà bái ruò rǔ, shèng dé ruò bùzú.’”* (老子曰：“而睢睢盱盱，而谁与居？ 大白若辱，盛德若不足。”)
The final two sentences match this chapter.

*«Yòu Shǐjì Lǎozǐ běnchuán* (又史记老子本传) further records Lǎozǐ’s original words: *“Liáng jiǎ shēncáng ruò xū, jūnzǐ shèng dé, róngmào ruò yú.”* (良贾深藏若虚，君子盛德，容貌若愚). It is suspected that *“guǎng dé”* (广德) is a corrupted form of *“shèng dé”* (盛德).

Mǎ Xùlún (马叙伦) argues that this passage should follow the *Zhuāngzǐ* (庄子), and *“shèng”* (盛) is the original text, which is correct. Yán Zūn (严遵)’s version as *“shèng dé”* (盛德) should be adopted.

Lǔ Juǎn (罗卷) renders *“ruò bùzú”* (若不足) as *“ruò rú”* (若濡), differing from all other versions.

**Jiàn dé ruò tōu** (建德若偷),
Jìu yě Zhíxǐ (狩野直喜) states: *“Héshàng Gōng běn* (河上公本) and *Wáng Bì běn* (王弼本) originally had differing texts, but later scholars, following *Bùshì Yìxíng* (辅嗣义行), altered the text based on *Wáng Bì*’s version, causing the two to merge indistinguishably. Fortunately, old manuscript copies (*jiùzhāo* 旧钞) suffice to correct the errors in the printed editions.

In Chapter 41, *“jiàn dé ruò tōu, zhì zhēn ruò yú”* (建德若偷，质真若渝), this version (*qiānzhī’ān* 谦之案: referring to Lǔ Juǎn’s text) renders *“tōu”* (偷) as *“ruò yú”* (若揄). The annotation reads: *“Yú”* (揄) is the same as *“yǐn”* (引), as proven by the *Shuōwén Jiězì* (说文手部): *“Yú, yǐn yě”* (揄，引也). The *Hànfēizǐ Dìxié Piān* (韩非子饰邪篇) states: *“Páng yuǎn yú bīng ér nán”* (庞援揄兵而南). The *Hànshū Lǐyuèzhì* (汉书礼乐志) mentions *“shén zhī yú”* (神之揄), with *Yán Shīgǔ* (颜师古) annotating: *“Yú, yǐn yě”* (揄，引也). Thus, the evidence confirms their difference.

It is clear that the two schools’ original texts differ, and their interpretations also vary. Later generations, lacking discernment, arbitrarily changed *“yú”* (揄) to *“tōu”* (偷) to align with *Wáng Bì*’s version, and the annotation was also altered to *“tōu”*, rendering *Héshàng Gōng*’s original meaning entirely obscure.

Moreover, it is noted that the *Táng Jǐnglóng Kèshí* (唐景龙刻石) reads *“jiàn dé ruò tōu”* (建德若偷), … thus proving that *Héshàng Gōng*’s version was corrupted by *Wáng Bì*’s as early as the Tang Dynasty. *Qiānzhī’ān* (谦之案): Indeed, *Héshàng Gōng*’s version was corrupted by *Wáng Bì*’s. Only this sentence—*Dùnhuáng běn* (敦煌本) omits it, while *Héshàng Gōng* and *Wáng Bì* both have *“tōu”* (偷), matching the stone inscription. The *Guǎngmíng běn* (广明本) and *Fù* (傅本) also have *“tōu”*, while *Gāo Yì* (高翿) has *“shū”* (输), and *Nài Juǎn* (柰卷) and *Shìdōng* (室町本) have *“yú”* (揄).

Fàn Yìngyuán (范应元) states: *“Shū”* (输), as *Fù Yì* (傅奕) says, was originally *“shū”* (输), citing *“Guǎngyùn”* (广韵) which defines *“shū”* as *“yú”* (愚). *Héshàng Gōng*’s *“yú”* (揄) is a grass script error (*cǎozì* 草字), substituting *“chē”* (车) for *“shǒu”* (手). *Fù Yì* says: *“Shǒu”* (手) was mistaken in transmission across generations, how much more so *“rǔ”* (辱) missing *“hēi”* (黑)!*”*

*Fù Yì*’s version at the time must have had evidence to support it. *Wáng Bì*’s version has *“tōu”* (偷), while *Dòng Yù* (董遇) has *“yáo”* (摇); now we follow the ancient version (*gǔběn* 古本).

The *Shuōwén* (说文) defines *“tōu”* (偷) as *“qiǎo xiá yě”* (巧黠也), from *“nǚ”* (女), with the sound of *“yú”* (俞声). The character is also written as *“tōu”* (偷). *Zhū Qūnshēng* (朱骏声) explains: *“Tōu”* (偷) is borrowed as *“yú”* (愉), in the *Hànshū Shíhuòzhì* (汉书食货志): *“Mín tōu gānshí hào yī”* (民偷甘食好衣). The *Lù Wēnshū zhuàn* (路温舒传) uses *“tōu wéi yīqiè”* (偷为一切), with the annotation *“gǒuqiě yě”* (苟且也). The *Lǐjì Biǎojì* (礼记表记) states *“ān sì yuē tōu”* (安肆曰偷). The *Zuǒ Wén shíqī zhuàn* (左文十七传) mentions *“Qí jūn zhī yǔ tōu”* (齐君之语偷), with the annotation *“gǒuqiě”* (苟且). Additionally, the *Dōngjīng fù* (东京赋) says *“jiāo mín yǐ tōu lè”* (剿民以偷乐), with the annotation *“yú jiùxìng yě”* (犹侥幸也). The *Hòuhàn Zhāng Héng zhuàn* (后汉张衡传) states *“suī àoyóu yǐ tōu lè xī”* (虽遨游以偷乐兮), with the annotation *“huái ān yě”* (怀安也). The *Ěryǎ Shìyán* (尔雅释言) defines *“tiāo”* (佻) as *“tōu yě”* (偷也). *Xúnzǐ Xiūshēn* (荀子修身) and *Fēi Shí’ěr zǐ* (非十二子) both use *“tōu rú”* (偷儒), with the annotation *“dāng wéi shū, gǒu bì yú shì yě”* (当为输，苟避于事也). *“Tōu”* (偷) is also used as *“yú”* (揄).

From the above, *“tōu”* (偷), *“shū”* (输), *“yú”* (揄), and *“shū”* (愉) were interchangeable in ancient usage, and *“tōu”* (偷) is the original text (*gùshū* 故书).

Yú Yì (俞樾) states: *“Tōu”* (偷) in *Héshàng Gōng*’s annotation means *“ruòkě tōu yǐn, shǐ kōngxū yě”* (若可偷引，使空虚也). *Wáng Bì*’s annotation reads: *“Tōu, pǐ yě”* (偷，匹也). *“Jiàn dé zhě tōu”* (建德者偷), meaning one who upholds **Dao**/**Way** and **Virtue/Power** acts like a simple, unassuming matchmaker (*pǐ* 匹), neither imposing nor contriving, thus resembling *“tōu”* (偷) as *“pǐ”* (匹).

However, the meaning of *“tōu pǐ”* (偷匹) is unattested in antiquity, and its interpretation is difficult to grasp.

Now, *“jiàn”* (建) should be read as *“jiàn”* (健). The *Shìmíng Shìyányǔ* (释名释言语) states: *“Jiàn, jiàn yě, néng yǒu suǒ jiànwéi yě”* (健，建也，能有所建为也). Thus, *“jiàn”* (建) and *“jiàn”* (健) share the same pronunciation, and the meaning also becomes clear. *“Jiàn dé zhě tōu”* (健德若偷) means that **Virtue/Power** that is robust and vigorous (*jiàn* 健) paradoxically appears as lazy and indolent (*tōu* 偷).

This aligns perfectly with the preceding sentence *“guǎng dé ruò bùzú”* (广德若不足).

**Zhì zhēn ruò yú** (质真若渝),
*Qiānzhī’ān* (谦之案): *Fù Yì*’s version reads *“zhì zhí ruò shū”* (质直若输), and *Nài Juǎn* (柰卷) also renders *“zhēn”* (真) as *“zhí”* (直). *“Yú”* (渝) and *“shū”* (输) are interchangeable in ancient script.

Bì Qián (毕沅) states: *“Héshàng Gōng* and *Wáng Bì* both have *“yú”* (渝), which aligns with ancient usage, such as *“yú píng”* (渝平) in the *Chūnqiū* (春秋) being *“shū píng”* (输平).

*“Shū”* (输) is borrowed as *“yú”* (愉), carrying the sense of *“gǒuqiě huái ān”* (苟且怀安), and is also used as *“yú”* (渝). The *“zhēn”* (真) in *“zhì zhēn”* (质真) is a corrupted form of *“zhí”* (直). *“Zhì ruò yú”* (质若渝) refers to the sincere and unadorned (*zhì* 质) individual whose actions are sluggish and weak (*yú* 渝), resembling one who is dull and foolish (*shū* 输).

「Liu Shīpèi states: Examining the passage above, *“Guǎngdé ruò bùzú, Jiàndé ruò tōu”* (广德若不足，建德若偷), this parallels the earlier paired phrases, and it is suspected that *“zhēn”* (真) should also be read as *“dé”* (德). Indeed, the character *“dé”* (德) in the original text is written as *“”* (a variant of 德), resembling *“zhēn”* (真).

*“Zhìdé”* (质德) aligns with *“Guǎngdé”* (广德) and *“Jiàndé”* (建德) in structure. *“Guǎngdé”* (广德) signifies broad and expansive **virtue** (德), contrasting with *“bùzú”* (不足); *“Jiàndé”* (建德) denotes firm and resolute **virtue** (德), opposing *“tōu”* (偷) (following Yu’s interpretation); *“Zhìdé”* (质德) represents unadorned **virtue** (德), countering *“yú”* (渝). These three **virtues** (德) are thus paired in meaning.

大方无隅,
大器晚成,
大音希声,
大象无形.

**Dao** (道) is subtle and nameless.
**Qiānzhī’ān** (谦之案): The *Fǎjīng* (法京) edition reads *“wú”* (无) as *“wú”* (无), while the *Luójuàn* (罗卷) consistently renders it as *“wú”* (无).

Yì Shùndǐng (易顺鼎) remarks: *“Dàfāng wúhuán”* (大方无隅) is recorded in *Moral Reflections on the Way* (道德指归论) as *“Dàfāng bùjǔ”* (大方不矩).

Gù Guǎngqì (顾广圻) notes: *“Dàyīn xīshēng”* (大音希声), the *Fù* (傅) edition renders *“xī”* (希) as *“xī”* (稀), which is the same character.

Wáng Xiānshèn (王先慎) observes: The *Fù* (傅) edition reads *“yīn”* (音) as *“yán”* (言), differing entirely from all other versions.

Lǐ Qiào (李翘) states: *“Lǜshì Chūnyǒu Lèchéng Piān”* (吕氏春秋乐成篇) begins with *“Dàzhì bùxíng, dàqì wǎnchéng, dàyīn xīshēng”* (大智不形，大器晚成，大音希声), which does not cite **Laozi** (老子).

It is only **Dao** (道) that is both generous and good.
Yán Kějūn (严可均) notes: *“Shàn yú qiě shàn”* (善贷且善) is rendered *“qiěchéng”* (且成) in other editions.

Luó Zhènyù (罗振玉) states: The *Dūnhuáng* (敦煌) version reads *“dài”* (贷) as *“shǐ”* (始).

**Qiānzhī’ān** (谦之案): The *Lùoluó* (譣罗) and *Dūnhuáng Yǐběn* (敦煌乙本) omit the *“wúmíng”* (无名) clause; thus, *“dài”* (贷) being read as *“shǐ”* (始) aligns with **Laozi**’s *Yìběn* (义本). The *Fù* (傅) edition, along with the *Zhūrōng* (诸王本) and *Shìzhōngdīng* (室町本), reads *“shànyú qiěchéng”* (善贷且成), while the *Fàn* (范) edition renders *“shàn huò qiě shànchéng”* (善货且善成). It is said: *“Yán Zūn* (严遵) and *Wáng Bì* (王弼) follow the ancient version; *Héshàng Gōng* (河上公) reads *“shànyú qiěchéng”* (善贷且成), and now we follow the ancient version.” However, the *Yílántáng Yánběn* (怡兰堂严本) also reads *“shànyú qiěchéng”* (善贷且成), differing from the *Fàn* (范) edition, which likely omits one *“shàn”* (善) character, while the stele version omits *“chéng”* (成) at the end of the sentence. It is proper to augment according to the *Fàn* (范) edition.

*“Chéng”* (成) rhymes with *“chéng”* (成), *“shēng”* (声), *“xíng”* (形), *“míng”* (名).
*“Dài”* (贷) shares meaning with **Zhuangzi**’s *“Huàdài wànwù ér mín fùshì”* (化贷万物而民弗恃) in *Yìngdìwáng Piān* (应帝王篇), where it describes **Laozi**’s words.

*“Dàoxuàn wúmíng”* (道隐无名) also echoes **Zhuangzi**’s *“Yǒu mòjǔ míng, shǐ wù zìxǐ”* (有莫举名，使物自喜), meaning the attainment of **dharma** (功) without claiming fame, standing in the incomprehensible, and wandering in the boundless.

Yú Shěngwú (于省吾) states: The *Jǐnglóng* (景龙) edition reads *“Fūwéidào, shànyú qiěshàn”* (夫唯道，善贷且善), likely omitting *“chéng”* (成). The *Dūnhuáng* (敦煌) version reads *“shǐ”* (始) for *“dài”* (贷), which is a phonetic transformation.

From the *Zhōuyǔ* (周语): *“Chúnmíng zé zhōng”* (纯明则终), commentary: *“Zhōng”* (终) means *“chéng”* (成).
Again, *“Gù gāomíng lìngzhōng”* (故高明令终), commentary: *“Zhōng”* (终) is synonymous with *“chéng”* (成).
From the *Shū* (书), *“Xiāosháo jiǔchéng”* (箫韶九成), *Zhèng Zhù* (郑注) states: *“Chéng”* (成) is equivalent to *“zhōng”* (终).
Thus, *“chéng”* (成) and *“zhōng”* (终) are interchangeable, with the same meaning.

Then *“shànyú qiěchéng”* (善贷且成) is equivalent to *“shànyú qièzhōng”* (善贷且终).
Chapter Sixty-Four reads *“shèngzhōng rúshǐ”* (慎终如始), where *“zhōng”* (终) and *“shǐ”* (始) are paired in meaning.

【Sound and Rhyme】Jiāngshì (江氏) reads this chapter in the following rhyme scheme:
- *“Xíng, wáng”* (行、亡) in the *Yángbù* (阳部) rhyme.
- *“Xiào, dào”* (笑、道) in the *Yōuxiào tōngyùn* (幽、宵通韵) rhyme, with *“dào”* (道) rhyming with *“dào”* (盗).

- *“Mèi, tuì, lèi”* (昧、退、类) in the *Zhǐbù* (脂部) rhyme, *“mèi”* (昧) pronounced *“mèi”* (寐), *“tuì”* (退) as *“tùi”* (吐位反).

- *“Gǔ, rǔ, zú, tōu, yú, huán”* (谷、辱、足、偷、渝、隅) in the *Hòubù* (侯部) rhyme, *“yú”* (渝) as *“yù”* (喻蓲反), *“huán”* (隅) as *“é”* (俄蓲反).

- *“Chéng, shēng, xíng, míng, chéng”* (成、声、形、名、成) in the *Gēngbù* (耕部) rhyme.

**Qiānzhī’ān** (谦之案): *“Xiào”* (笑) belongs to the *Xiàobù* (宵部), *“dào”* (道) to the *Yōubù* (幽部), with *Yōu* (幽) and *Xiào* (宵) being interchangeable. *“Wéidào”* (惟道) should rhyme with *“dào”* (盗), which seems incorrect. *“Dào”* (道) is *“túhào”* (徒皓切), while *“dào”* (道) in ancient times was *“túgǔ”* (徒苟切). *“Dào”* (道) is an initial sound, rhyming with *“shǒu”* (守), *“jiù”* (咎) in Chapter Nine; with *“yǒu”* (有) in Chapter Ten; and with *“yǒu”* (牖), *“shào”* (少) in Chapter Forty-Seven. These are the proofs of its usage.

Furthermore, *“gǔ, rǔ, zú, tōu, yú, huán”* (谷、辱、足、偷、渝、隅) belong to one rhyme, with *Yáo Wéntián* (姚文田) and *Dèng Tíngzhēn* (邓廷桢) dividing them into *“gǔ, rǔ, zú”* (谷、辱、足) in the *Liùxià rùshēng* (六屋入声) rhyme, and *“tōu, yú, huán”* (偷、渝、隅) in the *Shísān hòu píngshēng* (十三侯平声) rhyme.

Additionally, the *“tōu”* (偷) in *“Jiàndé ruò tōu”* (建德若偷) is rendered *“tōu”* (偷) in the *Gāoběn* (高本) and *“shū”* (输) in the *Hànběn* (汉本), both of which rhyme.

Gù Yánwú (顾炎武) states: *“Xíng”* (行), in ancient pronunciation, was *“háng”* (杭). Referring to **Laozi**’s words: *“Shàngshì wéndào, qín ér xíngzhī; zhōngshì wéndào, ruòcún ruòwáng”* (上士闻道，勤而行之；中士闻道，若存若亡). Again, *“Gù ruòzhī shèngqiáng, róuzhī shènggāng”* (故弱之胜强，柔之胜刚) reads *“tōu”* (偷) as *“tú”* (俞) in the *Tángyùn zhèng* (唐韵正卷五十二庚). He also notes: The four sentences follow a two-rhyme pattern, with the particle *“zhī”* (之) sometimes present and sometimes absent, as seen in other poems.»

**Laozi** states: *“Shàngshì wéndào, qín ér xíngzhī; zhōngshì wéndào, ruòcún ruòwáng”* (上士闻道，勤而行之；中士闻道，若存若亡), where *“xíng”* (行) rhymes with *“wáng”* (亡).
Again, in the *Tángyùn zhèng* (唐韵正卷十七), under *“Shísān mò”* (十三末): *“Mèi”* (昧), in examining ancient texts, is sometimes pronounced with a departing tone and sometimes with an entering tone. With a departing tone, it is *“mòpèi”* (莫佩反). In **Laozi**’s *“Míngdào ruò mèi, yídào ruò lèi, jìndào ruò tuì”* (明道若昧，夷道若类，进道若退).
Again, in the *Hòubù* (侯部) of *Tángyùn zhèng* (卷六十九侯): *“Tōu”* (偷), in ancient pronunciation, was *“tú”* (俞). In **Laozi**’s *“Jiàndé ruò tōu, zhìzhí ruò yú, dàfāng wúhuán”* (建德若偷，质直若渝，大方无隅).

Deng Tingzhen states: *“Tōu, yú, yú”* (偷、渝、隅) form a rhyme. *“Yú”* (渝), in ancient pronunciation, was read as *“yú”* (羭). In the *Shījīng* (詩經), *“Zhōu liú”* (羔裘), *“shěmìng bù yú”* (舍命不渝), rhymes with *“hóu”* (侯).

*“Yú”* (隅), in ancient pronunciation, was read as *“gài”* (盖) with a level tone akin to *“ǒu”* (耦). In the *Shījīng* (詩經), *“Chóu miù”* (绸缪), *“sān xīng zài yú”* (三星在隅), rhymes with *“xiù”* (逅).

Both *“tōu”* (偷), *“yú”* (渝), and *“yú”* (隅) are ancient *Hòu* (侯) department characters.

He also states: *“Yú”* (俞) and *“yú”* (禺) share the same modern pronunciation as *“yú”* (鱼) and *“yú”* (虞), yet in ancient times both belonged to the *Hòu* (侯) department. Thus, words derived from *“yú”* (俞) or *“yú”* (禺) should all be classified under *Hòu*.

**Laozi** states: *“Shàngdé ruò gǔ, dàbái ruò rǔ, guǎngdé ruò bùzú, jiàndé ruò tōu, zhìzhí ruò yú, dàfāng ruò yú”* (上德若谷，大白若辱，广德若不足，建德若偷，质直若渝，大方若隅).

*“Gǔ”* (谷), *“rǔ”* (辱), and *“zú”* (足) are all *Hòu* (侯) department entering-tone characters, while *“tōu”* (偷) and *“yú”* (渝) are *Hòu* (侯) department level-tone characters. Since *“yú”* (隅) rhymes with them, all words derived from *“yú”* (禺) belong to the same category as *“yú”* (隅), not merely those like *“ǒu”* (偶), *“ǒu”* (耦), *“ǒu”* (藕) collected in the *Hòu* (厚) department of *Tángyùn zhèng* (唐韵正).

The *Jǐnglóng* (景龙) stele version contains **95 characters**, while the *Dūnhuáng* (敦煌), *Hé* (河), and *Wáng* (王) versions match it. The *Fù* (傅) version contains **97 characters**, and the *Fàn* (范) version has **98 characters**.

The *Héshàng* (河上) version is titled *“Tóngyì dì sìshíyī”* (同异第四十一), the *Wáng* (王) version *“Sìshíyī zhāng”* (四十一章), and the *Fàn* (范) version *“Shàngshì wéndào zhāng dì sìshíyī”* (上士闻道章第四十一).

**Chapter 42**
Dao/Way generates One (一), One generates Two (二), Two generates Three (三), and Three generates all things.

Deng Tingzhen’s annotation: The *Huáinánzǐ Tiānwén Trùn* (淮南子天文训) states: *“Dào rì guī, shǐ yú yī”* (道日规，始于一). Wang Pennisun (王念孙) remarks: *“Rì guī”* (日规) does not align with the meaning of the surrounding text; it is a mistaken interpolation from *“gù shuō guī shēng jǔ shāi”* (故曰规生矣杀) above.

The *Sòngshū Lǜshū* (宋书律书) reads: *“Dào shǐ yú yī”* (道始于一), without *“rì guī”* (日规).

Today’s annotation confirms Wang’s explanation. The *Huáinán Yì* (淮南义) cites **Laozi**’s chapter, thus the following passage states: *“Yī ér bù shēng, gù fēn ér wéi yīnyáng, yīnyáng hé hé ér wànwù shēng. Gù shuō yī shēng èr, èr shēng sān, sān shēng wànwù”* (一而不生，故分而为阴阳，阴阳合和万物生。 故曰一生二，二生三，三生万物).

The *Zhuāngzǐ Tiāndì Piān* (庄子天地篇) states: *“Tàichū yǒu wúwú, yǒu wúmíng, yī zhī suǒ qǐ, yǒu yī ér wèi xíng”* (泰初有无无，有无名，一之所起，有一而未形), which echoes **Laozi**’s *“Wúmíng, tiāndì shǐ”* (无名，天地始) and *“Dào shēng yī”* (道生一).

The *Huángdì Nèijīng Tàisū Juàn shíjiǔ Zhīzhēnshí Piān Yángshàngshàn Zhù* (黄帝内经太素卷十九知针石篇杨上善注) also states: *“Cóng Dào shēng yī, wèi zhī pǔ yě; yī fēn wéi èr, wèi zhī tiāndì yě; cóng èr shēng sān, wèi zhī yīnyáng hé qì yě; cóng sān yǐ shēng wànwù, fēn wéi jiǔ yě, sì shí, rìyuè nǎiwéi wànwù”* (从道生一，谓之朴也； 一分为二，谓天地也； 从二生三，谓阴阳和气也； 从三以生万物，分为九野、四时、日月乃至万物). These words are also derived from here.

Deng further notes: *“Dào shēng yī”* (道生一), where *“yī”* (一) refers to *qì* (气). The *Zhuāngzǐ Zhīběi Yóu Piān* (庄子知北游篇) states: *“Tōng tiānxià yī qì ér, shèngrén gù guì yī”* (通天下一气耳，圣人故贵一). Li Daochun (李道纯) remarks: *“Dào shēng yī”* (道生一) means *“vacuity and nothingness generate One *qì* (气)”; *“yī shēng èr”* (一生二) means *“One *qì* (气) differentiates into Yin and Yang”*.

Zhao Zhijiàn (赵志坚) states: *“Yī”* (一) is *“yuánqì”* (元气), the beginning of Dao/Way. *“In ancient times, all things under heaven, including Yin and Yang, received One *qì* (气) and thus came to life”*.

Dàtiān Qíngxuān (大田晴轩) states: *“Yī èr sān”* (一二三) has been interpreted in various ways by scholars. *“I examine the *Huáinánzǐ Tiānwén Trùn*: ‘*Guī shēng jǔ shāi, héng zhǎng quán cáng, shéng jū zhōngyāng, wéi sìshí gēn* (规生矩杀，衡长权藏，绳居中央，为四时根). *Dào rì guī, shǐ yú yī, yī ér bù shēng, gù fēn ér wéi yīnyáng, yīnyáng hé hé ér wànwù shēng. Gù shuō Dào shēng yī, yī shēng èr, èr shēng sān, sān shēng wànwù* (道日规，始于一，一而不生，故分而为阴阳，阴阳合和而万物生。 故曰道生一，一生二，二生三，三生万物).’ Here, *“yī”* (一) refers to *“One *qì* (气)”, *“èr”* (二) to *“Yin and Yang”,* and *“sān”* (三) to *“the harmonious interaction of Yin and Yang *qì* (气)”*. This interpretation is most fitting.

He also states: *“Dào”* (道) is *“principle”*; *“yī”* (一) is *“One *qì* (气)”*. As *Zhuāng Zhōu* (庄周) says: *“Yī zhī suǒ qǐ, yǒu yī ér wèi xíng”* (一之所起，有一而未形). *“Èr”* (二) is *“Yin and Yang”*; *“sān”* (三) is *“the initial emergence of form, *qì* (气), and substance”*.

In **Chapter 14**, it states: *“Cǐ sān zhě bùkě zhì jié, gù hùn ér wéi yī”* (此三者不可致诘，故混而为一). This refers to the aforementioned three.

The meaning is: *“Dao/Way generates One *qì* (气); One *qì* (气) differentiates into Yin and Yang; *qì* (气) flows and transforms between heaven and earth, taking form and substance, and then all things are born. Hence, it is said: ‘Three generates all things.’”* (万物负阴而抱阳，冲气以为和).

Deng Tingzhen’s annotation: The *Huáinánzǐ Jīngshén Trùn* (淮南子精神训) quotes: *“Wànwù bèi yīn ér bào yáng, chōng qì yǐ wéi hé”* (万物背阴而抱阳，冲气以为和). Gāo Yù (高诱) annotates: *“Wànwù yǐ bèi wéi yīn, yǐ fù wéi yáng”* (万物以背为阴，以腹为阳). The *Hànshū Gāodì Jì Zhù* (汉书高帝纪注) cites it as *“xiàng yīn ér bào yáng”* (向阴而负阳).

The *Lièzǐ Tiānruì Piān* (列子天瑞篇) states: *“Chōng hé qì zhě wéi rén”* (冲和气者为人). The *Huángdì Nèijīng Tàisū Juàn shíjiǔ Zhīzhēnshí Piān Yángshàngshàn Zhù* (黄帝内经太素卷十九知针石篇杨上善注) states: *“Wànwù bào yīn bào yáng, chōng qì yǐ wéi hé, wànwù jìn cóng sān qì ér shēng, gù rén zhī xíng bù lí yīnyáng yě”* (万物负阴抱阳，冲气以为和，万物尽从三气而生，故人之形不离阴阳也). These words all derive from here.

*“Bào”* (抱) is written as *“bào”* (袌) in the *Fù* (傅) version.

「Chōng」 (冲), as rendered by Fàn Yìngyuán (范应元) and Gāo Xiè (高翿), is written as **«zhōng»** (盅); the character **«qì»** (气) is absent in Zhāng Suìchéng’s (张嗣成) version.

What people detest are solitude, widowhood, and poverty*—* yet kings and nobles take them as titles.
Yán Kějūn (严可均) notes: *“Bù guǒ”* (不毂) is annotated in the *Gùzhù* (御注) and by Wáng Bì (王弼) as *“bù gǔ”* (不谷).
Wèi Jiàosūn (魏稼孙) remarks: *“Wéi wánggōng wéi chēng”* (而王公以为称) reverses the order of the characters in the *Gùzhù* (御注).
Luó Zhènyù (罗振玉) states: The *Dūnhuáng jǐběn* (敦煌己本) reads *“wéi chēng”* (为称) as *“zì míng”* (自名).
In my annotation: The *Fù* (傅) version reads *“wánghóu yǐ zì chēng yě”* (王侯以自称也), while the *Fàn* (范) version has *“wánghóu yǐ zì wèi yě”* (王侯以自谓也).
Fàn (范) says: *“Wáng Bì (王弼) and Yán Zūn (严遵) follow the ancient text, while Héshàng Gōng (河上公) renders it as ‘而王公以为称’ (wéi wánggōng wéi chēng). Now, we follow the ancient text.”*
According to today’s *Yílán Táng* (怡兰堂) and *Dàozàng* (道藏) editions of the *Yán* (严) version, they both read *“wéi wánggōng yǐ míngchēng”* (而王公以名称), differing from Fàn’s (范) observation.
Láo Jiàn (劳健) states: *“Wéi wánggōng wéi chēng”* (而王公以为称) is the reading in all Tang-era editions and the *Héshàng* (河上) version. Here, *“wánggōng”* (王公) is used for its rhyme with *“chēng”* (称), just as in Chapter 32 *“hóu”* (侯) rhymes with *“shǒu”* (守), and in Chapter 39 *“wáng”* (王) rhymes with *“zhēn”* (贞) and *“chēng”* (称). Thus, it should follow the Tang-era editions.
In my annotation: Following the Tang-era edition is correct; *“gōng”* (公) and *“chēng”* (称) do not rhyme.

Therefore, some things are diminished when increased, and some are increased when diminished.
Yán Kějūn (严可均) notes: *“Yì zhī ér sǔn”* (益之而损) lacks the *“yòu”* (或) in the *Gùzhù* (御注).
Luó Zhènyù (罗振玉) states: The *Gùzhù* (御注) and *Dūnhuáng* (敦煌) versions also lack *“yòu”* (或).
In my annotation: The *Pánxī* (磻溪), *Lóuzhèng* (楼正), *Gǔ Huān* (顾欢), *Péng Zhì* (彭耜), and *Gāo Xiè* (高翿) versions likewise lack the *“yòu”* (或) below, while the *Yán Zūn* (严遵) version omits both *“yòu”* (或) and the first three characters.

What people are taught, I also teach:---
Luó Zhènyù (罗振玉) states: The *Gùzhù* (御注) and *Dūnhuáng* (敦煌) versions both read *“yì wǒ yì jiào zhī”* (亦我义教之).
In my annotation: Xíng Xuán (邢玄), *Pánxī* (磻溪), *Lóuzhèng* (楼正), *Péng Zhì* (彭耜), Zhào (赵), and *Gāo* (高) versions align with the *Dūnhuáng* (敦煌) version. The *Shìtōng* (室町) version reads *“rén zhī suǒ jiào, wǒ yì jiào rén”* (人之所教，我亦教人).
Sūn Shèng’s (孙盛) *Lǎozi Yíwèn Fǎnxùn* (老子疑问反讯) quotes *“yì”* (亦) with an *“yǐ”* (以) character below.
The *Fù* (傅) version reads *“rén zhī suǒ jiào wǒ, yì wǒ zhī suǒ jiào rén”* (人之所教我，亦我之所教人), while the *Fàn* (范) version has *“yì”* (亦) preceded by *“ér”* (而).
Fàn (范) states: *“Wáng Bì (王弼) and Yán Zūn (严遵) follow the ancient text, while Héshàng Gōng (河上公) renders it as ‘人之所教，亦我义教之’ (rén zhī suǒ jiào, yì wǒ yì jiào zhī).”*
In my annotation: The current *Yán* (严) version reads *“rén zhī suǒ jiào, yì wǒ jiào zhī”* (人之所教，亦我教之), differing from Fàn’s (范) observation. The *Zhūwáng* (诸王) and *Guǎngmíng* (广明) versions also follow this *shí* (石) reading.
Mǎ Xùlún (马叙伦) notes: The *Fàn* (范) and *Luó* (罗) versions, along with the *Hóngmíng Jí* (弘明集) *Liù Shì Huìtōng Bó Gǔ Dàoshì Yíxià Lùn* (六释慧通驳顾道士夷夏论), all render it as *“jiàofù”* (教父).
Chéng’s (成) *cúshū* (疏) states: *“Brǐng for the foundation of learning the Dao, ‘fù’ (父) also signifies ‘běn’ (本, origin).”*
This indicates that Chéng (成) also renders it as *“jiàofù”* (教父).
Chéng’s (成) *cúshū* (疏) quotes *Gǔ Huān* (顾欢) as *“qí xué zhī běn fù yě”* (其学之本父也), suggesting that *Gǔ* (顾) version uses *“xué”* (学) as *“jiào”* (教) contracted.
The *Shuōwén Jiězì* (说文解字) states: *“Jiào”* (教) means *“to awaken and understand.”*
All versions render it as *“jiàofù”* (教父).
In my annotation: *“Jiàofù”* (教父) is the same as *“xuéfù”* (学父), akin to today’s term *“shīchuán”* (师传, teacher transmission).
The *Fāngyán* (方言) states: *“In general, to honor the elderly, people in the southern regions of Chu call them ‘fù’ (父).”*
The *“jiāng”* (将) here shares the same meaning as in *Zhuāngzǐ Déchōng Fú* (庄子德充符) *“qiū jiāng wéi shī”* (丘将以为师).

**[Sound and Rhyme]** This chapter lacks rhyme in Jiāng’s (江) reading.

The *Yòujǐnglóng Bēi* (右景龙碑) has 73 characters, the *Dūnhuáng* (敦煌), *Hé* (河), and *Wáng* (王) versions match this, while the *Fù* (傅) version has 79 characters and the *Fàn* (范) version has 80 characters.
The *Héshàng* (河上) version is titled *“Dàohuà sìshí'èr zhāng”* (道化第四十二), the *Wáng* (王) version *“sìshí'èr zhāng”* (四十二章), and the *Fàn* (范) version *“Dàoshēng yī zhāng sìshí'èr”* (道生一章第四十二).

**Chapter 43**
The utmost gentleness in the world,
Rides and drives the utmost firmness in the world.

Luó Zhèn-yù said: The *Dūnhuáng* version lacks the character *«cèng»* (骋).

Péng Zhì said: Yè Mèngdé’s version lacks *«cèng»* (骋), and *Dázhēnzǐ* (达真子) renders *«jiān»* (坚) as *«gāng»* (刚).

**Qiánzhī’s annotation:** All *Hé* (河), *Wáng* (王), and *Fù* (傅) versions match this stone inscription.

Fàn Yìngyuán’s version reads: *“Tiānxià zhī zhì róu, chěngcèng yú tiānxià zhī zhì jiān,”* and further states: *“Huáinánzǐ* (淮南子) contains the character *«yú»* (于), aligning with the ancient editions.” It is noted that the extant *Huáinánzǐ* (淮南子) in *Yuándào* (原道) and *Dàoyìng* (道应) both lack *«yú»* (于), differing from Fàn’s version.

Additionally, *Yùlǎn* (御览) under the *Mù* (木) section also cites *«jiān»* (坚) as *«gāng»* (刚). There is no mention of *«wúyǒu rù yú wúwén»* (无有入于无闻).

Yán Kějūn said: The *Yùzhù* (御注), *Héshàng* (河上), and *Wáng Bì* (王弼) versions lack *«yú»* (于), while *Fù Yì* (傅奕) and *Huáinánzǐ* (淮南子) read: *“Chū yú wúyǒu, rù yú wújiàn”* (出于无有，入于无间).

Wèi Jiàosūn said: *«Wúwén»* (无闻) likely stems from a mistake in the inscription. *«Wén»* (闻) is a misinterpretation of *«jiàn»* (间); Yán Kějūn erred in this correction.

Jiāo Jǒng said: The ancient *Huáinánzǐ* (淮南子) versions uniformly read: *“Chū yú wúyǒu, rù yú wújiàn”* (出于无有，入于无间).

Fàn Yìngyuán said: *«Jiàn»* (间) means *«xì»* (隙, gap). *Fù Yì* (傅奕) and *Yán Zūn* (严遵) align with the ancient editions.

It is noted that the current *Yán* (严) version reads: *“Wúyǒu rù yú wújiàn”* (无有入于无间).

Liú Shīpéi said: The *Huáinánzǐ* (淮南子) *Yuándào* (原道) and *Yuántuàn* (原训) cite: *“Chū yú wúyǒu, rù yú wújiàn,”* which reflects the ancient *Lǎozǐ* (老子) text. The *Wáng* (王) version also includes *«chū yú»* (出于) twice. In *Wáng Bì*’s (王弼) preceding annotation, *“Qì wú suǒ bù rù, shuǐ wú suǒ bù chū yú jīng”* (气无所不入，水无所不出于经), the phrase *«wú suǒ bù chū yú jīng»* (无所不出于经) should read *«wú suǒ bù jīng»* (无所不经), paralleling *«wú suǒ bù rù»* (无所不入). The *«chū yú»* (出于) must belong to the main text above *«wúyǒu»* (无有). It appears the *Wáng* (王) version also reads *“Chū yú wúyǒu, rù yú wújiàn,”* with *«chū yú»* (出于) mistakenly placed in the annotation.

*Fù Yì* (傅奕) aligns with *Huáinánzǐ* (淮南子).

Liú Wéntiǎn said: The current *Lǎozǐ* (老子) *Héshànggōng Zhāngjù* (河上公章句) *“Biān yòng dì sìshí sān zhāng”* (偏用第四十三) reads: *“Tiānxià zhī zhì róu, chěngcèng tiānxià zhī zhì jiān, wúyǒu rù wújiàn,”* with *«chū»* (出) omitted before *«wúyǒu»* (无有). This can be supplemented based on the *Huáinánzǐ* (淮南子) citation. The *Dàoyìng* (道应) passage cites *“Chū yú wúyǒu, rù yú wújiàn,”* likely altered by later scholars.

The *Lǎozǐ* (老子) annotation states: *“Wúyǒu, wèi Dào yě. Dào wú xíngzhì, suǒnéng chū rù wújiàn.”* (无有，谓道也。道无形质，故能出入无间.) This suggests the version he consulted still lacked *«chū»* (出).

Wáng Dào said: *«Wújiàn»* (无间) means *«wúxì»* (无隙, no gap). A single *zhàng* (丈) of water can float a ten-thousand *hú* (斛) vessel; a six *chǐ* (尺) rein can guide a thousand-*lǐ* (里) horse. The utmost gentleness riding the utmost firmness—this is the case. The *qi* (气) of Heaven and Earth, though formless, can penetrate metal and stone; the light of the sun and moon, though without substance, can pierce through lattice windows. *«Wúyǒu rù yú wújiàn»* (无有入于无间)—this is the case. Thus, one knows the virtue/power of *wuwei* (无为).

Yán Kějūn said: The *Yùzhù* (御注) reads *“Wú shì yǐ zhī wúwéi zhī yǒuyì yì,”* while *Héshàng* (河上) and *Wáng Bì* (王弼) include *«zhī»* (之), omitting the repeated *«yì»* (益).

Wèi Jiàosūn said: Yán Kějūn incorrectly noted the *«zhī»* (之) and *«yì»* (益) in *Yùzhù* (御注), missing *«wú»* (吾) above *«shì»* (是).

Luó Zhèn-yù said: The *Jǐnglóng* (景龙) and *Dūnhuáng* (敦煌) versions lack *«wú»* (吾) and *«zhī»* (之).

**Qiánzhī’s annotation:** All *Hé* (河) and *Wáng* (王) versions read *“Wú shì yǐ zhī wúwéi zhī yǒuyì,”* with *Jǐngfú* (景福), *Shìmíng* (室町), and *Fàn* (范) versions identical, *«wú»* (无) rendered as *«wú»* (无). *Gù Huān* (顾欢) reads *“Wú shì yǐ zhī wúwéi yǒuyì,”* while Péng Zhì renders *“Shì yǐ zhī wúwéi zhī yǒuyì yě.”*

The teaching of the unsaid, the virtue/power of *wuwei* (无为), few in the world can attain.

**Qiánzhī’s annotation:** The *Fù* (傅) version renders *«xī»* (希) as *«xǐ»* (稀), with *«yǐ»* (矣) appended below. The *Fàn* (范) and *Jǐngfú* (景福) versions render *«wú»* (无) as *«wú»* (无). This reflects the meaning of Chapter 70: *“Wú yán shèn yì zhī, shèn yì xíng; tiānxià mò néng zhī, mò néng xíng.”* (吾言甚易知，甚易行；天下莫能知，莫能行.)

**[Sound and Rhyme]** According to Jiāng Shì’s (江氏) rhyme scheme, this chapter lacks rhyme.

Gāo Běn Hàn and Xí Dòng noted *«jiān»* (坚) and *«jiàn»* (间) as rhyming. *«Jiān»* (坚) belongs to the *Zhēn* (真) rhyme group, *«jiàn»* (间) to *Yuán* (元), indicating *Yuán-Zhēn* (元、真) rhyme interchange.

Xuè Huì said: *«Jiān»* (坚) is akin to *«gāngqiáng»* (刚强, strong), yet it is not called *«gāng»* (刚) or *«qiáng»* (强)—this is a variation in literary rhyme.

The *Yòujǐnglóng Bēi* (右景龙碑) contains 38 characters, the *Dūnhuáng* (敦煌) version 37, the *Hé* (河) and *Wáng* (王) versions 39, the *Fù* (傅) version 44, and the *Fàn* (范) version 42.

The *Héshàng* (河上) version is titled *“Biàn yòng dì sìshísān zhāng”* (遍用第四十三), the *Wáng* (王) version *“Sìshísān zhāng”* (四十三章), and the *Fàn* (范) version *“Tiānxià zhī zhì róu zhāng dì sìshísān”* (天下之至柔章第四十三).

**Chapter 44**

---

**Chapter 44**
Who is dearer—name or self? Which is more plentiful—self or wealth?
Which is more afflicting—gain or loss?

Qián Zhī annotates: *«Shú»* (熟) is rendered *«Shú»* (孰) in other versions. *«Shú»* (孰) and *«shú»* (熟) were interchangeably used in antiquity.
*«Wáng»* (亡) is corrected to *«shī»* (失) by Lǐ Dàochún and Zhāng Sìchéng. Mǎ Xùlún states: *"This is a groundless alteration by later scholars; '亡' and '病' rhyme."*

*«Shú duō»* (孰多) uses *«duō»* (多) in the sense of "重" (*heavy/repeated*).
Xí Dòng remarks: *"The Shūowén (说文) states: '多, repeated also.' Here, it aligns with the '重' in '重迭' (重迭, overlapping), and can be extended to mean '重' (重) in '轻重' (轻重, weighty/light). The Hànshū (汉书) *Biàn Bù* (黥布) passage says: '又多其材' (又多其材, moreover, his talents were abundant), where Shǐ Gǔ (师古) annotates: '多 means repeated/weighty'."*

Thus, excessive love incurs great expenditure, and excessive accumulation invites heavy loss.
Yáo Wéndiàn divides *«zhú»* (足) and *«rǔ»* (辱) as one rhyme (六屋入声), *«zhǐ»* (止) and *«dài»* (殆) and *«jiǔ»* (久) as another (四之上声).

Dèng Tíngzhēn states: *"The character '久' lacks a rhyme; he notes that the preceding seven sentences all exhibit internal rhyme within their five- or four-character lines, akin to the poetic structure of '于嗟乎驺虞' (于嗟乎驺虞) or '日居月诸' (日居月诸)."*
Jiāng Yǒuguì says: *"「货」 is pronounced *huò* (呼卧切). It should be classified under the *Gē* (戈) rhyme group in ancient pronunciation."*
The *Lìjiè* (立戒) passage of the *Lǎozǐ* (老子) reads: *"「身与货孰多」"* (身与货孰多) with *«duō»* (多) as internal rhyme, and *"「不贵难得之货」"* (不贵难得之货) aligns *«guò»* (过) in rhyme (Tángyùn *sìshēngzhèng* (四声正) thirty-ninth *guò* (过)).

Again, he says: *"「病」 is pronounced *bìng* (皮命切). It should be read as *píyáng* (皮羊切) in its ancient tone and classified under the *Yáng* (阳) rhyme group."*
The *Lìjiè* (立戒) passage of the *Lǎozǐ* (老子) reads: *"「得与亡孰病」"* (得与亡孰病) with *«wáng»* (亡) and *«bìng»* (病) as internal rhyme (forty-third *yìng* (映)).

The *Gǔrényìn* (古韵总论) states: *"In antiquity, there were instances where the rhyme shifted within a single sentence, as in the seven sentences of this chapter and the four sentences of '我无为而民自化' (我无为而民自化)."*
Mǎ Xùlún, in the *Máopǐ zhèngyùn* (毛诗正韵) postscript, cites this chapter: *"身、亲、货、多、亡、病、爱、费、藏、亡、足、辱、止、殆、久"* (身、亲、货、多、亡、病、爱、费、藏、亡、足、辱、止、殆、久) all exhibit internal rhyme.

The *Yòujǐnglóng* (右景龙) version contains 40 characters; the *Dūnhuáng* (敦煌) version matches. The *Héshàng* (河上) version has 37 characters, while the *Wáng* (王), *Fù* (傅), and *Fàn* (范) versions each have 39 characters.
The *Héshàng* (河上) version is titled *"Lìjiè dì sìshísì"* (立戒第四十四), the *Wáng* (王) version *"Sìshísì zhāng"* (四十四章), and the *Fàn* (范) version *"Míng yǔ shēn shú qīn zhāng dì sìshísì"* (名与身孰亲章第四十四章).

---

**Chapter 45**
When the Great Dao is complete, its use is inexhaustible.

Qián Zhī annotates: *«鈌»* (鈌) is rendered *«quē»* (缺) in other versions; the *Yìlín* (意林) volume one, the scripture, and the *Héshànggōng* (河上公) annotations all read *«鈌»* (鈌), while the Song-printed *Héshàng* (河上) version renders *«鈌»* (鈌).
Mǎ Xùlún states: *"「鈌」 and 「鈌」 are both corrupt forms of 「缺」 (缺). In Six Dynasties vernacular texts, the radical for '缶' (fū) and '垂' (chuí) was often confused. '缶' was mistakenly written as '○', and then further misread as '金' (jīn)."*
*«Bì»* (弊) is rendered *«bì»* (敝) in the versions of Fù Yì (傅奕), Péng (彭), Zhào (赵), and the *Hánshī wàichuán* (韩诗外传) volume nine.
The *Yùnhuì xiǎobǔ* (韵会小补) states: *"「敝」 is pronounced *bì* (笔别切), as in the *Lǎozǐ* (老子) passage."*
This aligns with the *suǒjiàn* (所见) version of Yáo Wéndiàn (姚文田).
Bì Qián (毕沅) states: *"「敝」 is rendered '○' by *Héshànggōng* (河上公) and *Wáng Bì* (王弼)."*
This aligns with the *Hé* (河) and *Wáng* (王) versions as seen by Bì (毕). Now, all *Hé* (河) and *Wáng* (王) versions render *«bì»* (弊), matching this stone.

The Great fullness, like overflowing, its use is never-ending.
Qián Zhī annotates: The *Dūnhuáng* (敦煌), *Suìzhōu* (遂州), *Fù* (傅), and *Fàn* (范) versions, as well as the *Wénxuǎn* (文选) *Wèidū* (魏都) annotations, *Zèng Lùjī* (赠陆机) as *Wúwáng* (吴王) *Lángzhōnglìng* (郎中令) poem annotations, and *Yīqièjīng yìnyì* (一切经音义) volume five all render *«yíng»* (盈) as *«mǎn»* (满).

「傅、范」 versions render *«chōng»* (冲) as *«zhōng»* (盅).
Fàn Yìngyuán (范应元) states: *"「大满若盅」 (大盈若冲), Guō Yún (郭云) and Wáng Bì (王弼) align with the ancient texts."* This confirms that the Wáng (王) version seen by Fàn (范) also renders it as *«mǎn»* (满).
As annotated, the correct rendering is *«yíng»* (盈).
The character *«mǎn»* (满) was altered to avoid the taboo of Emperor Huì of Hàn (汉惠帝讳).
All other versions render it as *«yíng»* (盈), and *«yíng»* (盈) is the original text (Mǎ Xùlún [马叙伦] says).
*«Chōng»* (冲), following the Fù (傅) and Fàn (范) versions, should be rendered as *«zhōng»* (盅).
It is also written as *«chōng»* (冲).
The *Chūnqiū Fàn* (准南原道) states: *"Chōng while xū yíng"* (冲而徐盈), with the annotation: *"Empty."* This *«dàyíng ruò chōng»* (大盈若冲) is thus *«dàyíng ruò xū»* (大盈若虚).
Additionally, *«dàyíng»* (大盈) corresponds with *«dàchéng»* (大成) from above, where *«chéng»* (成) is the abbreviated form of *«shèng»* (盛).
Shèng (盛) and yíng (盈) both derive from *«mǐn»* (皿), referring to ancient vessels used for food and drink.
Mǎ Xùlún (马叙伦) states: *"「chéng」 (成) is the abbreviated form of 「shèng」 (盛)."* The *Shuōwén Jiězì* (说文解字) says: *"Shèng (盛), to fill the millet and sorghum in vessels for sacrificial offerings."* This is extended to mean vessels as shèng (盛), as seen in *Tàishǐ Gōngshì Dàntán* (太史公司马谈) *Dàjì* (大记): *"Shí zhōu yú shèng"* (食粥于盛).
In this passage, *«shèng»* (盛) and *«quē»* (缺) are paired.
The *Shuōwén Jiězì* (说文解字) states: *"Quē (缺), a broken vessel."* (缺, 器破也.)
As annotated, *«yíng»* (盈) also refers to vessels.
The *Shuōwén Jiězì* (说文解字) says: *"○ (盈), a full vessel, from皿○ (mǐn盈)."* This is extended to mean *«full and stored»* as yíng (盈).
*«Dàyíng ruò chōng»* (大盈若冲), *«chōng»* (冲) should be rendered as *«zhōng»* (盅).
The *Shuōwén Jiězì* (说文解字), under the *«mǐn»* (皿) section, states: *"○ (盅), an empty vessel, from皿○ (mǐn盅), with the middle tone."* Lǎozǐ (老子) says: *"Dào zhōng ér yòng zhī"* (道盅而用之).
Empty vessels correspond to full vessels, illustrating that vessels of great fullness are like those emptied—thus, their use is never-ending.

**Great straightness is like bending,**
As annotated, all *Hé* (河) and *Wáng* (王) versions agree, while Fù (傅) and Fàn (范) render *«qū»* (屈) as *«qū»* (诎).
Luó Juǎn (罗振玉) mistakenly renders *«zhí»* (直) as *«zhēn»* (真).
Fàn Yìngyuán (范应元) states: *"Qū"* (诎) is pronounced like *«qū»* (屈), meaning to bend or curve.
Tàishǐ Gōngshì (太史公司马) aligns with the ancient texts.
Mǎ Xùlún (马叙伦) states: All versions, as well as annotations from *Huáinán Dàoyīng Juàn* (淮南道应训) and *Hòushǐ Xuànshuō Zhì* (后汉书荀爽传注), render it as *«qū»* (屈).
The *Shuōwén Jiězì* (说文解字) says:
*"Qū (屈), without a tail."* (屈, 无尾也.)
*"Qū (诎), to question and bend."* (诎, 诘诎也.)
*"Yǐ (颉), head bent."* (颉, 头颉也.)
*"○ (蛣), to bend."* (蛣○, 蛣○也.)
Thus, *«qū»* (诎) conveys the meaning of bending or curving.
Ancient texts often use *«qū»* (诎) in the phrase *«qūshēn»* (屈申).
It is further annotated that the following sentence should include *«qí yòng bù qū»* (其用不屈).
Sūn Yǐràng (孙诒让) states: In *Hánshī Wàichuán* (韩诗外传) volume nine, the citation of Lǎozǐ (老子) renders *«qū»* (屈) as *«qū»* (诎), matching the Fù (傅) version.
The phrase *«dàqiǎo ruò zhuō»* (大巧若拙) follows *«dàbiàn ruò nè»* (大辩若讷), and there should be *«qí yòng bù qū»* (其用不屈) beneath it.
Following the parallel structure of the previous sentences *«qí yòng bù bì»* (其用不弊) and *«qí yòng bù qióng»* (其用不穷), this confirms the presence of the omitted phrase.
Hán (韩) relies on texts from the *Xiānqín* (先秦) and *Xīhàn* (西汉) periods, hence its completeness.
All versions from *Wèi* (魏) and *Jìn* (晋) onward omit this sentence.

**Great skill is like clumsiness,**
**Great eloquence is like stammering.**

Luó Zhènyù (罗振玉) states: *«Nè»* (讷) is rendered *«náo»* (吶) in the *Dūnhuáng* (敦煌) version.
As annotated, Lǐ Dàochún (李道纯) and Lóu Zhèng (楼正) versions render *«biàn»* (辩) as *«biàn»* (辨).
The *Zhuāngzǐ* (庄子) passage in *Qùqiè* (胠箧) and *Huáinán Dàoyīng Juàn* (淮南道应训) both cite the same.
*Hánshī Wàichuán* (韩诗外传) volume nine renders it as: *«Dàbiàn ruò nè, dàqiǎo ruò zhuō, qí yòng bù qū»* (大辩若讷, 大巧若拙, 其用不屈), while *Móuzǐ Lǐhuò Lùn* (牟子理惑论) renders it as: *«Dàbiàn ruò nè, dàqiǎo ruò zhuō»* (大辩若讷, 大巧若拙), inverting the order of the two phrases.
Yì Shùndǐng (易顺鼎) suggests that in *Dàchéng Ruò Quē* (大成若缺) of *Dàodé Zhǐguī Lùn* (道德指归论), the phrase *«dàqiǎo ruò zhuō»* (大巧若拙) is followed by *«yíng ér ruò qū»* (赢而若诎), indicating that the version he consulted may have included *«dàyíng ruò qū»* (大赢若诎) but lacked *«dàbiàn ruò nè»* (大辩若讷).

**Agitation overcomes cold,**
**Calmness overcomes heat.**

Wèi Jiàosūn (魏稼孙) states: *«Zào shèng sāi»* (躁胜塞) should have *«sāi»* (塞) rendered as *«hán»* (寒) in the annotation, as corrected by Yán Shī (严失).
As annotated, *«sāi»* (塞) is rendered *«hán»* (寒) in all versions; this is a mistaken character.
*«Jìng»* (静) is rendered *«jìng»* (靖) in the Fù (傅) version, and similarly below.
Additionally, the character *«zào»* (躁), Mǎ Xùlún (马叙伦) states: *"「Zào」 (躁), the *Shuōwén Jiězì* (说文) renders as 「zào」 (躁), meaning swiftness; it is now commonly written as 「zào」 (躁)."* Here, it should be rendered as *«zào»* (燥).
As annotated, Mǎ (马) is correct.
The *Shīmíng* (释名) states: *"Zào (躁), dryness; things dry and move, flying and scattering."* (躁, 燥也, 物燥乃动而飞扬也.)
The *Shīyán Yǔ* (释言语) states: *"Zào (燥), scorched."* (燥, 焦也.)
The *Shuōwén Jiězì* (说文解字) states: *"Zào (燥), dry."* (燥, 干也.)
Yán Zūn (严遵) in *Dàodé Zhǐguī Lùn* (道德指归论) *Dàchéng Ruò Quē* (大成若缺) says:
*"Thus, when yīn (阴) reaches its peak, the earth cracks and ice solidifies, cold winds blow fiercely, frost and snow congeal rigidly, fish and turtles hibernate, and all things curl up tightly.
At this time, even a single warm room, facing a furnace, layered with fox and badger skins, wrapped in fluffy wool, still cannot resist the cold.
But when one's spirit is settled and mind is at ease, when the body moves and exerts itself, then the essence flows and sweat pours, shedding clothes and stepping outside, warmth remains in excess on the body."*

「Thus, the explanation of *zào* (躁) as *"dòngtǐ láo xíng"* (动体劳形) is insightful, yet it fails to account for the fact that even in a warm room, beside a furnace, layered with fox and badger skins, wrapped in fluffy wool, one still cannot resist the cold—this contradicts common experience. The error stems from interpreting *zào* (躁) as *zào* (燥) in the common sense.

In truth, *zào* (躁) is *zào* (燥), but *zào* (燥) is the楚方言 (Chu dialect) used in *Lǎozǐ*’s (老子) book, specifically referring to *furnace flames*. The *Shīyán Yǔ* (释言语) states: *"The Chu (楚) call fire *zào* (燥), the Qi (齐) call it *huǐ* (毁), and the Wu (吴) call it *tāo* (焚)."* Since *Lǎozǐ* (老子) was a Chu (楚) man, he used *zào* (躁). *"Zào (躁) overcomes cold"* is paired with *"jìng (静) overcomes heat"* (静胜热).

The character *jìng* (静) shares its meaning with *jìng* (寂). In the *Chūcí* (楚辞) *Lǚfén Shìwén* (汝坟释文), it is noted: *"The Chu (楚) call stillness *jìng* (寂), and the Qi (齐) call it *jìng* (静)."* The *Shuōwén Jiězì* (说文解字) states: *"寂 (jìng), from 水 (shuǐ, water), the sound of 静 (jìng)."* This implies that clear, still water can overcome heat, while furnace flames can repel cold. The phrase *"clearing and stillness as the Dao/Way (正) for all under heaven"* (清静以为天下正) is found in the *Dàchéng Ruò Quē* (大成若缺) chapter, though some editions omit the *"yǐ"* (以) character. My examination shows that the editions of *Jǐngfú* (景福), *Xíng Xuán* (邢玄), *Shìmáng* (室町), *Gù Huān* (顾欢), *Fù* (傅), and *Fàn* (范) all include *"yǐ"* (以). The *Fàn* (范) edition further adds *"zhī"* (知) before *"qīng"* (清), stating: *"The ancient edition has the characters '知以' (zhī yǐ)."* The term *"qīngjìng"* (清静) in *Yán Zūn*’s (严遵) text and in *Yáng Xióng*’s (扬雄) *Jiě Jiào* (解嘲) annotation aligns with *"néng qīng néng jìng"* (能清能静).

The *Shìjì* (史记) *Lǎozǐ Zhuàn* (老子传) states: *"Lǐ Ěr (李耳) transforms himself through *wúwéi* (无为), and his *qīngjìng* (清静) brings *zhèng* (正) to himself."* This is an abbreviated passage. The *Chéngshū* (成疏) commentary explains: *"Clear, still, and tranquil, one can benefit oneself and others, and correct what is deviant—thus, it is the Dao/Way (正) for all under heaven."* The *Dūnghuáng* (敦煌) and *Jǐngfú* (景福) editions, as well as the *Suìzhōu* (遂州) edition, read *"zhèng"* (正), not *"zhèng"* (政). *Wǔnèi* (武内) mistakenly corrected it to *"zhèng"* (政), claiming: *"The Dūnghuáng (敦), Jǐngfú (景), and Suìzhōu (遂) editions all read '政' (zhèng)."* *Jǐng Héshàng* (警河上) annotated: *"If one can clear and still, then one becomes the eternal ruler for all under heaven."* Thus, *Héshàng* (河上) rendered it as *"néng qīng néng jìng, wéi tiānxià zhèng"* (能清能静，为天下正).

The *Lǎozǐ* (老子) states:
*"Great completion resembles deficiency; its use is inexhaustible.
Great fullness resembles emptiness; its use is boundless."*

【Rhymes and Tones】 In this chapter, *Jiāng Shì* (江氏) rhyme readings are as follows:
- *Quē* (缺) and *Bì* (敝) rhyme (祭部, *bì* pronounced as *biě* (蹩)),
- *Chōng* (冲) and *Qióng* (穷) rhyme (中部),
- *Qū* (屈), *Zhuō* (拙), *Nè* (讷), and *Rè* (热) rhyme (脂、祭通韵, *qū* pronounced as *quē* (缺), *zhuō* co-rhyming with *zé* (棁), *nè* co-rhyming with *nǚ* (奴, as in *nuè* 月反)).

- *Jìng* (静) and *Zhèng* (正) rhyme (耕部).

*Dèng Tíngzhēn* (邓廷桢) notes:
- *Quē* (缺) and *Bì* (弊) rhyme, stating: *"'弊' (bì) is in the 祭部 (zhài bù) rhyme category, while '缺' (quē) is its 入声 (rù shēng, entering tone)."*

My examination shows that *Yáo Wéntián* (姚文田) aligns with *Jiāng* (江), while *Dèng Tíngzhēn* (邓廷桢), *Gāo Běnhàn* (高本汉), *Xí Dòng* (奚侗), and *Chén Zhù* (陈柱) do not consider *"rè"* (热) as part of the rhyme scheme. *Lǐ Dàochún* (李道纯) suggests *"bì"* (弊) be co-rhymed as *"biē"* (鳖). *Gù Yànwǔ* (顾炎武) in his *Táng Yùn* (唐韵) *Zhèng Shíliù* (正十六屑) states that *"quē"* (缺) in the *去声 (qù shēng, departing tone)* is pronounced as *"kǔhuì"* (苦惠反), also written as *"缺"* (quē).

「To the right, the *Jǐnglóng* (景龙) stele version has **forty-one characters**, the *Dūnhuáng* (敦煌) version and the *Héshàng* (河上) version have **forty characters**, while the *Fù* (傅) and *Fàn* (范) versions have **forty-two characters**. The *Héshàng* (河上) version is titled *"Hóngdé dì sìshíwǔ"* (洪德第四十五), the *Wáng* (王) version *"Sìshíwǔ zhāng"* (四十五章), and the *Fàn* (范) version *"Dàchéng ruò quē zhāng sìshíwǔ"* (大成若缺章第四十五).

**Chapter Forty-Six:**
When the **Dao/Way** prevails in the world, the warhorses are turned back to till the fields;
When the **Dao/Way** does not prevail in the world, warhorses are born in the suburbs.

*Luó Zhènyù* (罗振玉) states: *"Fèn"* (粪), in the *Dūnhuáng* (敦煌) version, is written as *"○"*, a variant form of *"fèn"* (粪).*
**My examination:** The stele version matches this.

*Luó* (罗) mistakenly wrote *"róng"* (戎) as *"wǒ"* (我) in his notes—an error in verification.

*"Fèn"* (粪), in the *Fù* (傅) version, is written as *"bō"* (播).
*Bì Yàn* (毕沅) notes: *"Fèn"* (粪) and *"bō"* (播) are ancient characters used interchangeably.*
The *Yùpiàn* (玉篇) defines: *"Bō"* (播) means *to sow*.
Perhaps the *Dàodéjīng* (道德经) here carries the meaning of *sowing*.

*Péng Zhé* (彭耜) states: *"Zhū Wén Gōng"* (朱文公) version has *"chē"* (车) after *"fèn"* (粪), suggesting that the warhorses are turned back to clear the dung from the fields.
Recently, in Jiangxi, I saw what is called a *fèn chē* (粪车), and only then did I understand this.

*Wú Chéng* (吴澄) states: *"Fèn"* (粪) under has no *"chē"* (车) in other versions, only in *Zhūzǐ* (朱子) *Lùjì* (语录) is it mentioned, yet no one knows its source.
Now, examining *Zhāng Héng* (张衡) *Dōngjīng fù* (东京赋), it reads *"却走马以粪车"* (turn back the warhorses to clear the dung from the fields), which uses the full phrase of the *Dàodéjīng* (道德经). Yet by the end of the Eastern Han Dynasty, the *"chē"* (车) character was already missing, and *Wèi* (魏) scholar *Wáng Bì* (王弼)'s annotation, though not far from *Zhāng Héng* (张衡), already omitted it.
It seems that initially, one character was accidentally dropped, and later scholars, unaware of the error, did not restore it.
*"Chē"* (车) and *"jiāo"* (郊) rhyme, but omitting *"chē"* (车) leaves no rhyme.
**My examination:** *"Chē"* (车) and *"jiāo"* (郊) do not rhyme; further explanation follows below.

*Yì Shùndǐng* (易顺鼎) states: According to *Wénzǐ* (文子) *Jīngchéng piān* (精诚篇), it says:
*"Only those who travel at night can achieve this, hence the warhorses are turned back to till the fields, and the tracks of chariots do not extend beyond distant lands."*

Some read *"chē"* (车) as connected to the previous sentence, which also supports *Wú Chéng* (吴澄)'s interpretation.
However, the *Huáinán Lǎn* (淮南览) *Míngxùn* (冥训) states:
*"Hence the warhorses are turned back to till the fields, and the tracks of chariots do not extend beyond distant lands."*
Here, *"fèn"* (粪) is followed by *"ér"* (而), so *"chēguǐ"* (车轨) should be read as a connected phrase.

*Gāo* (高)'s annotation states:
*"'却走马以粪' (turn back the warhorses to till the fields) is a phrase from the *Dàodéjīng* (道德经). It means stopping the warhorses from running and using them to till the fields instead.
Another interpretation: When a ruler lacks **virtue/power**, warhorses are born in the suburbs, and the warhorses are used to till the fields, hence the tracks of chariots do not extend beyond distant lands."*

In the *Huáinán Lǎn* (淮南览), there are annotations by *Xǔ Shèng* (许慎) and *Gāo Yòu* (高诱). This second interpretation is likely *Xǔ Shèng* (许慎)'s, yet it aligns with *Gāo* (高)'s meaning.
The annotation by *Xuē Jiōng* (薛综) in *Dōngjīng fù* (东京赋) also cites the *Dàodéjīng* (道德经) phrase *"却走马以粪"* (turn back the warhorses to till the fields), indicating that by the end of the Han Dynasty, those transmitting the *Dàodéjīng* (道德经) had no *"chē"* (车) character, and *Zhāng Héng* (张衡) likely misread *Wénzǐ* (文子)!
*Wáng Bì* (王弼)'s *"yǐ fèn tián"* (以粪田) correctly uses the original meaning.
The pronunciation of *"chē"* (车) and *"jiāo"* (郊) also does not align closely, and *Wú* (吴) assumes they rhyme, which is unclear.

Again, according to *Wénzǐ* (文子) *Zìrán piān* (自然篇), it states:
*"The footprints do not reach the borders of the neighboring states, and the chariot tracks do not extend beyond a thousand miles."*
This clearly shows *"chēguǐ"* (车轨) as a connected phrase.
*He Shìzhào* (何氏焯) *Dúshū jì* (读书记) cites *Wénzǐ* (文子) as *"fèn chē"* (粪车), but *Lǐ* (李)'s annotation missed this and is incorrect.
**My examination:** The annotations by *Zhāng Jǐngyáng* (张景阳) *Qī Mìng zhù* (七命注) cite *Wáng Bì* (王弼) as saying:
*"When the **Dao/Way** prevails in the world, cultivation of the fields is all that is needed, hence the warhorses are turned back to till the fields."*
The annotation by *Yán Shìgǔ* (颜师古) in *Hànshū* (汉书) *Xīyù zhuàn* (西域传) states:
*"The *Dàodéjīng* (道德经) says: 'When the **Dao/Way** prevails in the world, the warhorses are turned back to till the fields.'"*
It is likely that *"fèn"* (粪) either has *"wéi"* (为) above it or *"tián"* (田) below it, or else it is a mistaken citation identical to *"fèn chē"* (粪车).

The *Hánfēi* (韩非) *Jiě Lǎozǐ* (解老) and *Yù Lǎozǐ* (喻老) both cite the same text as this stele.
Additionally, according to the *Yánsī Lùn* (盐铁论) *Wèitōng piān* (未通篇), it states:
*"At that time, the warhorses were turned back to till the fields. Later, military expeditions were frequently launched, and the warhorses were insufficient, so even the mares were sent into battle, hence the foals were born on the battlefield."*

This interpretation refers to the scarcity of warhorses in the army, where even mares were sent into battle, aligning with the ancient meaning of the *Dàodéjīng* (道德经).

**The greatest crime is to desire what is not right;**
**The greatest calamity is to not know contentment;**
**The greatest misfortune is to covet what one desires.**

*Yán Kějūn* (严可均) notes: *"The greatest misfortune is to covet what one desires"* is absent in *Wáng Bì* (王弼)'s version.
*Luó Zhènyù* (罗振玉) states: The *Jǐnglóng* (景龙), *Yùzhù* (御注), *Dūnhuáng* (敦煌), and *Jǐngfú* (景福) versions all have the sentence *"The greatest crime is to desire what is not right"*, and the *Shìwén* (释文) *Héshàng* (河上) version also includes it.
The character *"dà"* (大) in the *Dūnhuáng* (敦煌) version is written as *"shèn"* (甚).

**My examination:** The *Guāngmíng* (广明), *Qìngyáng* (庆阳), *Pánxī* (磻溪), *Lóuzhèng* (楼正), *Suìzhōu* (遂州), *Nǎi juàn* (柰卷), *Shìcháng* (室町), *Gāo* (高), *Gù* (顾), *Péng* (彭), *Fù* (傅), and *Fàn* (范) versions all match this stele.
Only the *Fù* (傅) and *Fàn* (范) versions have the third sentence as *"Guì mò cǎn yú yù dé"* (咎莫憯于欲得), while the *Suìzhōu* (遂州) and *Gù Huān* (顾欢) versions write *"dà"* (大) as *"shèn"* (甚).
The *Hánshī wàizhuàn* (韩诗外传) *Jiǔ* (九) cites the first sentence *"kě yù"* (可欲) as *"duō yù"* (多欲), and *Wú Chéng* (吴澄)'s version places the third sentence above the second.

The *"○"* is a variant form of *"jiù"* (咎), identical to the ninth chapter.
*Yú Yì* (俞樾) states: According to the *Héshàng* (河上) version, there is a sentence *"The greatest crime is to desire what is not right"* above this one, and based on the *Hánfēi zǐ* (韩非子) *Jiě Lǎo piān* (解老篇), this sentence should exist.
However, *Hánfēi zǐ* (韩非子) mistakenly writes *"huò mò dà yú kě yù"* (祸莫大于可欲), which is incorrect.
The preceding text states:
*"He who harms the weak ruler above and oppresses the people below commits the greatest crime."*
Thus, it is clear that the original character was *"zuì"* (罪).」

Liu Shipei says: *"Yú’s account is correct. In the *Hánfēi zǐ* *Jiě Lǎo piān* (解老篇), the character ‘祸’ (huò) was mistakenly influenced by the preceding ‘君祸’ (jūn huò). Moreover, the *Yù Lǎo piān* (喻老篇) also cites these three phrases, correctly rendering them as ‘罪莫大于可欲’ (zuì mò dà yú kě yù). Given the preceding context—‘To name and title as crime, to give cities and lands as crime’—it is evident that the original *Lǎozi* text must have read ‘罪’ (zuì).*

However, in both the *Jiě Lǎo* and *Yù Lǎo* chapters of the *Hánfēi zǐ*, the phrase appears as ‘咎莫大于欲得’ (jiù mò dà yú yù dé), where ‘大’ (dà) is uniformly rendered as ‘憯’ (cǎn). In the *Jiě Lǎo piān*, ‘得’ (dé) is further mistakenly written as ‘利’ (lì). The preceding passage in the *Jiě Lǎo piān* reads: ‘When bitter suffering mixes within the intestines, it harms the person—this is *憯* (cǎn), and *憯* leads one to retreat and blame oneself,’ thus explaining the meaning of ‘憯.’ Since ‘憯’ (cǎn) is synonymous with ‘痛’ (tòng), it may be glossed as ‘祸莫痛于欲得’ (huò mò tòng yú yù dé). The ancient *Lǎozi* text must originally have read ‘憯’ (cǎn), as did the *Fù* (傅) edition. The current text renders it as ‘大’ (dà), likely due to later scholars harmonizing it with the preceding ‘大’ (dà) character.

As for the *Jiě Lǎo piān*’s substitution of ‘利’ (lì) for ‘得’ (dé), this was an error influenced by the preceding ‘欲利’ (yù lì). Gu Qianli’s correction—retaining ‘得’ (dé)—is accurate.

In my notes: The rendering of ‘大’ (dà) as ‘憯’ (cǎn) is correct. ‘憯’ (cǎn) is interchangeable with ‘甚’ (shèn). The *Dūn* (敦) and *Suì* (遂) editions read ‘甚’ (shèn), while the *Fù* (傅) and *Fàn* (范) editions read ‘憯’ (cǎn). Fàn (范) explains: ‘憯 (cǎn) is pronounced like *cǎn* (惨), meaning *pain*.’ Bì Yàn (毕沅) states: ‘The *Héshàng* (河上) and *Wáng Bì* (王弼) editions also render ‘憯’ (cǎn) as ‘大’ (dà), while *Hánfēi zǐ* reads ‘咎莫憯于欲利’ (jiù mò cǎn yú yù lì), and Lǐ Yuē (李约) renders ‘憯’ (cǎn) as ‘甚’ (shèn). The *Shuōwén Jiězì* (说文解字) defines ‘憯’ (cǎn) as *pain*, and its ancient pronunciation aligns with ‘甚’ (shèn).’*

「Mǎ Xùlún said: Chéng Shū (成疏) and Luó Juàn (罗卷) render it as *‘shèn’* (甚).
Chéng Shū (成疏) states: *“Its guilt and censure are none more severe than this.”*
Thus, Chéng (成) also uses *‘shèn’* (甚).
*‘Shèn’* (甚) is borrowed for *‘cǎn’* (憯), as they belong to the same phonetic category.

The *Shuōwén Jiězì* (说文解字) notes: *“Replicated characters (○) are written as (○),”* serving as its precedent.

Hence, it is known that *“knowing sufficiency as sufficiency”* (知足之足) means *“sufficient”* (常足).

Yán Kějūn (严可均) said: *“常足”* (常足) is rendered as *“常足矣”* (常足矣) in the *Yùzhù* (御注) and *Wáng Bì* (王弼) editions.
Luó Zhènyù (罗振玉) noted: The *Dūnhuáng* (敦煌) text lacks the *“故”* (故) and *“矣”* (矣) characters.
My annotation: The *Yán Zūn* (严遵) edition also lacks *“故”* (故), while the *Suìzhōu* (遂州) edition lacks *“矣”* (矣), though *Hánfēi wàishuān* (韩诗外传) includes them.

The *Sīmǎ Guāng* (司马光) edition omits *“之足”* (之足).
*Hánfēi yù Lǎo* (韩非喻老) cites *“knowing sufficiency as sufficiency”* (知足之为足矣), while the *Wénxuǎn* (文选) *Dōngjīng fù* (东京赋) annotation cites *“knowing sufficiency is sufficiency”* (知足常足).
My annotation: The character *“足”* (zú) derives from *“止”* (zhǐ), thus its meaning is *“to stop”* (止).
The *Yì* (易) states *“鼎折足”* (dǐng zhé zú, "the tripod's leg broken"), with *Zhèng Zhù* (郑注) explaining: *“‘趾’ (zhǐ) means ‘no matter’ (无事), while ‘足’ (zú) means ‘to set up’ (陈设).”*
The *Hànshū* (汉书) *Wǔxíng zhì* (五行志) states: *“‘足’ (zú) means ‘to stop’ (止).”*
Chapter 28 *“常德乃足”* (cháng dé nǎi zú, "constant virtue is indeed sufficiency"), with *Héshàng* (河上) annotation: *“‘to stop’ (止).”*
Liú Xiànruò (刘咸炘) said: *“Knowing stop is knowing reversal”* (知止即知反).
The *Dàodéjīng* (道德经) repeatedly speaks of *“knowing sufficiency”* (知足), which is *“knowing stop”* (知止), meaning *“to preserve wealth and honor”* (保富贵).
“Constant exchange” (相对往来) cannot endure long, for it must reverse to become constant and thus last.

Constant endurance (常久) is indeed the core principle of Lǎozi (老子).
【Phonology】Jiāng Shì’s (江氏) rhyme reading lacks a rhyme.
Yáo Wéntián (姚文田) states: *“欲”* (yù, “desire”) and *“足”* (zú, “sufficiency”) rhyme (六屋入声).
Dèng Tíngzhēn (邓廷桢) and Xí Zòng (奚侗) agree.
Gāo Běnhàn (高本汉) and Chén Zhù (陈柱) say: *“欲”* (yù), *“足”* (zú), *“得”* (dé, “obtain”) and *“足”* (zú) rhyme.
My annotation: Wú Chéng (吴澄) remarked: *“‘粪’ (fèn, ‘dung’)” below has the character *“车”* (chē, ‘cart’), with *“车”* (chē, *yú* department) and *“郊”* (jiāo, *xiāo* department) rhyming.*
The *Yì* (易) *Shùn Dǐng* (顺鼎) states that *“车”* (chē) and *“郊”* (jiāo) are not close in sound, which is correct.
Wèi Yuán (魏源) in *Lǎozi běnyì* (老子本义) said: *“The three lines ‘静胜寒’ (jìng shèng hán, ‘tranquility overcomes cold’), some say should belong to the next chapter, as ‘正’ (zhèng, ‘upright’) and ‘粪’ (fèn, ‘dung’) form a rhyme, while ‘有道’ (yǒu dào, ‘with the Dao’) and ‘却走马’ (què zǒu mǎ, ‘turns back the horse’) illustrate the effect of ‘clearing and tranquility governing the world’ (清静治天下).*
I tentatively retain this doubt.
My annotation: *“正”* (zhèng) and *“粪”* (fèn) indeed rhyme, but this is something I have not yet fully understood.»

This chapter rhymes *Dao* (道) and *jiāo* (郊).
*Dao* (道) belongs to the *yōu* (幽) department, *jiāo* (郊) to the *xiāo* (霄) department—this is the same *yōu-xiāo* rhyming pattern as in the forty-seventh chapter, where *xiào* (笑) and *dào* (道) rhyme.

Wú Shēn (吴棫) in his *Yùn Bǔ* (韵补) under the *yù* (屋) rhyme (one *yù* department): *“dé”* (得) rhymes with *“shī”* (失).

The *Lǎozi* (老子) states:
*“Zui mò dà yú kě yù, huò mò dà yú yù dé.”*
(*“The greatest crime is to indulge in desires,
The greatest calamity is to covet what one desires.”*)

The *Yì Lín* (易林) says:
*“Rù shì qiú lù, bù jiàn tóu zú;
Zhōng rì zhì yè, jìng wú suǒ dé.”*
(*“Entering the market to seek a deer,
One sees neither its head nor its feet;
From dawn till dusk, one finds nothing at all.”*)

The right-hand side of the *Jǐnglóng* (景龙) stele contains **44 characters**, the *Dūnhuáng* (敦煌) version **43 characters**, the *Héshàng* (河上) version **44 characters**, the *Wáng* (王) version **39 characters**, and the *Fù* (傅) and *Fàn* (范) versions **45 characters**.

The *Héshàng* (河上) version is titled *“Jiǎn yù dì sìshíliù”* (俭欲第四十六, *“Frugality in Desires, Chapter 46”*), the *Wáng* (王) version *“Sìshíliù zhāng”* (四十六章, *“Chapter 46”*), and the *Fàn* (范) version *“Tiānxià yǒu dào zhāng dì sìshíliù”* (天下有道章第四十六, *“Chapter 46: The World Under the Dao”*).

**Chapter 47:**
*“Bù chū hù, zhī tiānxià.”*
(*“Without stepping outside one’s door,
One knows the world.”*)
Luo Zhēnyù (罗振玉) notes: In the *Jǐngfú* (景福) version, *“hù”* (户) and *“yǒu”* (牖) are each followed by *“yǐ”* (以).

**My annotation:**
The *Nài* (柰) roll, *Shìtōng* (室町) version, and *Huáinán Dào Yīng* (淮南道应训), *Wénzǐ Dào Yuán* (文子道原篇), *Zhìyào* (治要), and *Yìlín* (意林) quotations all match the *Jǐngfú* (景福) version.
Moreover, the *Wénzǐ Jīngchéng* (文子精诚篇) and *Xià Dé* (下德篇) cite *“hù”* (户) followed by *“yǐ”* (以), while the *Huáinán Zhǔshù Xuǎn* (淮南主术训), *Hòushǔ Zhāng Héng Zhuàn Zhù* (后汉书张衡传注), *Wénxuǎn Sī Qí Fù Zhù* (文选思齐赋注), and *Hán Fēi Chǎn Wàishuān* (韩诗外传) all three times cite *“ér”* (而).
The *Lǐ Shì Chūnqiū Jūnshǒu* (吕氏春秋君守篇) quotes it as *“bù chū yú hù ér zhī tiānxià”* (不出于户而知天下), while the *Fù* (傅) and *Fàn* (范) versions read *“bù chū hù, kě yǐ zhī tiānxià”* (不出户，可以知天下); the *Hán Fēi Chǎn Yù Lǎo* (韩非子喻老) version reads *“bù chū yú hù, kě yǐ zhī tiānxià”* (不出于户，可以知天下).

Again, the *Huáinán Zhǔshù Xuǎn* (淮南主术训) says:
*“Rén zhǔ zhě, yǐ tiānxià zhī mù shì, yǐ tiānxià zhī ěr tīng, yǐ tiānxià zhī zhì lǜ, yǐ tiānxià zhī lì zhēng.”*
(*“The sovereign rules with the eyes of the world seeing,
The ears of the world hearing,
The wisdom of the world deliberating,
The strength of the world contending.”*)
This is clearly the ancient meaning of *“bù chū hù, zhī tiānxià”* (不出户，知天下).

**“Bù kuī” (不窥):**
*“Jiàn tiān dào.”* (见天道)
Luo Zhēnyù (罗振玉) notes: The *Jǐnglóng* (景龙) version and the *Yùzhù* (御注) version write *“yǒu”* (牖) as *“yǒu”* (𪚥), an alternative form.

**My annotation:**
The *Luo* (罗) roll writes *“kuī”* (窥) as *“kuī”* (窥), omitting *“yǒu”* (牖), and *“jiàn tiān dào”* (见天道) as *“zhī tiān dào”* (知天道).
The *Yùzhù* (御注), *Xíng Xuàn* (邢玄), *Qìngyáng* (庆阳), *Pánxī* (磻溪), *Lóuzhèng* (楼正), *Héshàng* (河上), *Gùhuān* (顾欢), *Péngzǐ* (彭耜), *Fù Yì* (傅奕), and *Gāo Yì* (高翿) versions all write *“kuī”* (窥), matching this stone.
The *Zhū Wáng* (诸王) versions and the *Shìtōng* (室町) version also write *“kuī”* (窥).
Additionally, under *“yǒu”* (牖), the *Gùhuān* (顾欢) and *Shìtōng* (室町) versions have *“yǐ”* (以), while *Lù Xīshēng* (陆希声) has *“ér”* (而).
The *Lǐ Shì Chūnqiū Jūnshǒu* (吕氏春秋君守篇) quotes it as *“bù kuī yú yǒu, ér zhī tiān dào”* (不窥于牖，而知天道), the *Wénzǐ Jīngchéng* (文子精诚篇) as *“bù kuī yú yǒu, yǐ zhī tiān dào”* (不窥于牖，以知天道), and the *Fù* (傅) and *Fàn* (范) versions as *“bù kuī yǒu, kě yǐ zhī tiān dào”* (不窥牖，可以知天道).

The *Shīzǐ Chǔ Dào* (尸子处道篇) cites Zhòngní (仲尼) as saying:
*“Bù chū yú hù ér zhī tiānxià, bù xià qí táng ér zhì sìfāng.”*
(*“Without stepping outside one’s door, one knows the world;
Without descending from one’s hall, one governs the four quarters.”*)

The *Guǐgǔ Zǐ Běn Jīng Yīnfǔ Qī* (鬼谷子本经阴符七篇) quotes:
*“Bù chū hù ér zhī tiānxià, bù kuī yǒu ér zhī tiān dào;
Bù xiàn ér mìng, bù xíng ér zhì.”*
(*“Without stepping outside one’s door, one knows the world;
Without peering through the window, one knows the Dao of Heaven;
Without seeing, one issues commands;
Without moving, one arrives.”*)
The language is also derived from this.

Bì Qián (毕沅) says:
*“An Hàn Fēi Chǎn zuò ‘bù kuī yú yǒu, kě yǐ zhī tiān dào.’”*
(*“The *Hán Fēi Chǎn* (韩非子) version reads: ‘Without peering through the window, one can know the Dao of Heaven.’”*)

The *Shuōwén Jiězì* (说文解字) states:
*“Kuī, xiǎo shì yě.”* (窥，小视也。)
(*“Kuī (窥): to look stealthily.”*)

*“Kuī, shǎn yě.”* (窥，闪也。)
(*“Kuī (窥): to peer through a doorway.”*)

*“Shǎn, kuī tóu mén zhōng yě.”* (闪，窥头门中也。)
(*“Shǎn (闪): to peer through the top of a doorway.”*)

The *Fāngyán* (方言) says:
*“Fán xiàng qiè shì, nán chǔ wèi zhī kuī.”* (凡相窃视，南楚谓之窥。)
(*“To secretly glance at one another,
The southern Chu region calls this *kuī* (窥).”*)

Qián (沅) believes that *kuī* (窥) refers to peering through a hole, while *shǎn* (闪) refers to peering through a doorway—thus, *“kuī”* (窥) should be used here.
The *Lǎozi* (老子) was a Chu person, employing Chu dialect.
*Hán Fēi* (韩非) is correct.

「The *Yīnfǔ Qī Piān* (阴符七篇) quotes:
*“Not stepping outside the door while knowing the world,
Not peering through the window while knowing the Dao of Heaven;
Not seeing yet naming, not acting yet arriving.”*
This language is also derived from here.

Qián Zhī (谦之) notes: The opinion of Bì Yàn (毕沅) is correct.
*The Yù Piān* (玉篇) states:
*“Kuī (窥): to secretly glance at one another, identical to *shǎn* (闪).”*

*The Zì Lín* (字林) says:
*“Kuī (窥): to lean one’s head inside a doorway and look; the character is also written as **○** (窺).”*
Rén Dà Chūn (任大椿) cites *Zì Lín* in his *Kǎo Yì* (考逸), quoting the *Mèng Yù* (孟郁) inscription on the *Yáo Miào* (尧庙) from the Han dynasty:
*“**○** (窺) captures the essentials of the Dao.”*
Thus, it is clear that *kuī* (窥) and **○** (窺) are interchangeable.

Furthermore, *“kuī”* (窥) in the *Shuōwén Jiězì* (说文解字) reads:
*“Kuī (窥): to look stealthily, from *xué* (穴), with the sound of *guī* (规).”*
This aligns closely with the earlier definition of *kuī* (窥).

In the *Yì Guān* (易观):
*“Kuī guān lì nǚ zhēn”* (窥观利女贞) uses *kuī* (窥),
while in the *Fēng* (丰):
*“Kuī qí hù”* (窥其户) also uses *kuī* (窥).
Thus, *kuī* (窥) should be employed here.

The *Dūnhuáng* (敦煌) manuscript reads *“kuī”* (窥),
matching the *Hán Fēi* (韩非) passage *Yù Lǎo* (喻老),
and this should be followed.

Xià Sù (夏竦) records the *Gǔwén Sì Shēng Yùn* (古文四声韵), where *“kuī”* (窥) appears,
and cites the *Lìshān Mù Dàodé Jīng* (厉山木道德经) manuscript as **○** (窺).
The farther one’s search, the closer one’s understanding.

Yán Kějūn (严可均) states:
*“‘Its understanding is *mí jìn* (弥近)’”*
—other editions read *“mí shǎo* (弥少)”.
Qián Zhī (谦之) notes:
*“‘Mí* (弥)’” in Fù’s (傅) edition is written as **○** (弥),
and *“jìn* (近)’” is a mistaken character for *“shǎo* (少)’”,
which Fù’s (傅) and Fàn’s (范) editions correct to *“xiān* (鲜)’”.
Fàn (范) says:
*“The character ‘xiān* (鲜)’ aligns with the ancient editions of *Hán Fēi* (韩非) and *Wáng Bì* (王弼).”*
Additionally, the *Hán Fēi* (韩非) passage *Yù Lǎo* (喻老),
*Huái Nán* (淮南) *Dàoyīng Xuàn* (道应训) and *Jīngshén Xuàn* (精神训),
as well as the *Lǚshì Chūnqiū* (吕氏春秋) *Jūn Shǒu* (君守) passage,
all include *“zhě* (者)’” after *“yuǎn* (远)’”.
The *Huái Nán Jīngshén Xuàn* (淮南精神训) states:
*“Hence it is said: the farther one’s search, the less one’s knowledge.”*
(*“Thus, the spirit cannot be allowed to dissipate externally.”*)
Wáng Niǎnsūn (王念孙) notes:
*“These twelve characters are a quotation from *Lǎozi* (老子) with an explanation;
later scholars mistakenly took them as commentary and thus inserted them into the notes.”*

Again, the *Lǚshì Chūnqiū* (吕氏春秋) *Xiān Jǐ* (先己) passage says:
*“Without stepping outside the door or gate,
yet the world is governed—
could this be because one knows only to reflect upon oneself?”*

The *Lùnrén* (论人) passage states:
*“The highest sage reflects upon himself,
the next seeks in others.
The farther one’s search,
the more distant one’s application;
The more forcefully one seeks,
the farther one strays from the truth.”*
These are all variations of *Lǎozi*’s (老子) words.

The *Jūn Shǒu* (君守) passage reads:
*“Hence it is said: ‘Not stepping outside the door while knowing the world,
Not peering through the window while knowing the Dao of Heaven,
The farther one’s search, the less one’s knowledge.’”*
Though it does not quote *Lǎozi* (老子) directly,
it is evident that this is an interpretation of *Lǎozi*’s (老子) teachings.

Bì Yàn (毕沅) further notes:
*“‘Xiān* (鲜)’ is the ancient form of ‘xiānshǎo* (鲜少)’,
and all editions uniformly write ‘shǎo* (少)’.”
Mǎ Xùlún (马叙伦) states:
*“This should read ‘shǎo* (少)’,
as ‘xiān* (鲜)’ is a vulgarized character,
and ‘shǎo* (少)’ rhymes with ‘dào* (道)’.”*

Thus, the sage does nothing yet knows,
does not see yet names,
does not act yet achieves.

Qián Zhī (谦之) notes:
*“‘Not seeing yet naming* (不见而名)’”,
in *Hán Fēi*’s (韩非) *Yù Lǎo* (喻老) and the editions of *Zhāng Suìchéng* (张嗣成) and *Wēi Dàyǒu* (危大有),
all quote ‘*míng* (明)’ instead of ‘*míng* (名)’.
Wǔnèi Yìxióng (武内义雄) argues:
*“‘Míng* (名)’ is a phonetic loan for ‘*míng* (明)’.”*
Jiǎng Xíchāng (蒋锡昌) states:
*“Though ‘*míng* (名)’ and ‘*míng* (明)’ were used interchangeably in antiquity,
*Lǎozi* (老子) employs only ‘*míng* (明)’.
In Chapter 22: *“Not seeing oneself, hence *míng* (明)”*,
and in Chapter 52: *“Seeing the small, hence *míng* (明)”*,
both use the paired terms ‘*jiàn* (见)’ and ‘*míng* (明)’.
This is further proof, and thus the character should be altered according to *Zhāng*’s (张) edition.”*

Now, considering the *Shì Míng Shì Yán* (释名释言语):
*“Míng (名): to make clear.”*
*“Míng (名)” and *“míng (明)” share both sound and meaning,
so there is no need to alter the character.

Again, *“bù wéi”* (不为),
in *Héshàng* (河上) and *Yáo Mèngfǔ* (姚孟俯) editions,
is written as *“wú wéi”* (无为).
Given the parallel structures *“bù xíng”* (不行) and *“bù jiàn”* (不见)
in the preceding sentences, *“bù wéi”* (不为) is the correct form.

【Phonology and Rhyme】
Jiāng Shì’s (江氏) rhyme readings for this chapter:
*“Hù* (户), *xià* (下) rhyme (鱼部),
*Yǒu* (牖), *dào* (道) rhyme (幽部).”*

Yáo Wéntián (姚文田) and Dèng Tíngzhēn (邓廷桢) read:
*“Zēng* (增), *míng* (名), *chéng* (成) rhyme.”*

Chén Zhù (陈柱) reads:
*“Yǒu* (牖), *dào* (道), *shǎo* (少) rhyme,
*míng* (名), *chéng* (成) rhyme.”*
Gāo Běn Hàn (高本汉) agrees.

Xí Zōng (奚侗) reads:
*“Yuǎn* (远), *wéi* (为) rhyme,
*xíng* (行), *míng* (明), *chéng* (成) rhyme.”*
Indeed, *“shǎo* (少)” was originally *“xiān* (鲜)”,
and *“míng* (名)” was originally *“míng* (明)’.
Xí’s (奚) misreading alters *“bù xíng ér zhī”* (不行而知)
to *“bù zhī ér xíng”* (不知而行),
which is incorrect, as *“xíng* (行)” does not rhyme in this context.

Gù Yànwù (顾炎武) records the *Táng Yùn Zhèng* (唐韵正) Volume 93, Section 35, *Mǎ* (马):
*“The ancient pronunciation of *xià* (下) is *hù* (户).”*
In *Lǎozi* (老子):
*“Not stepping outside the door, knowing the world;
Cultivating it, its virtue becomes universal;
A nine-tiered tower, rising from accumulated earth.”*

「The journey of a thousand *lǐ* (里) begins beneath one’s feet.

Thus, the Sage who wishes to elevate the people must first lower himself to their words, and he who wishes to lead them must first place himself behind them in conduct.

The adept in *shì* (士) does not resort to force, the skilled warrior does not rage, the master of defeating foes does not quarrel, and the wise ruler serves as their foundation.

Chén Dì (陈第) cites Wèi Liǎowēng (魏了翁):
*"In the *Liù Jīng* (六经), every instance of 下 (*xià*) is pronounced *hù* (户), and 舍 (*shě*) is pronounced *shè* (舍). Not only in the *Liù Jīng*, but this holds true for all ancient pronunciations."*

The right-hand text of the *Jǐnglóng* (景龙) stele is undivided into chapters, with thirty-six characters. The *Dūnhuáng* (敦煌) edition, the *Héshàng* (河上) edition, and the *Wáng* (王) edition agree, while the *Fù* (傅) and *Fàn* (范) editions contain forty characters.

The *Héshàng* (河上) edition is titled *"Chapter of *Jiànyuǎn* (鉴远) Forty-Seven"*, the *Wáng* (王) edition *"Chapter Forty-Seven"*, and the *Fàn* (范) edition *"Chapter of *Bùchūhù* (不出户) Forty-Seven"*.

**Chapter Forty-Eight:**
*"The more one learns, the more one gains;
The more one cultivates the Dao/Way, the more one diminishes.*

*(Chén Zhōu’s note:)* The *Fù* (傅) and *Fàn* (范) editions both have the character *zhě* (者) above the second *rì* (日). *Fàn* (范) states: *"Fù Yì (傅奕) and Yán Zūn (严遵) along with the ancient editions have the character *zhě* (者)."*
