According to the modern *Yílán* (怡兰) edition, the *Yán* (严) edition lacks it. *"For learning, one gains daily"* and *"For the Dao/Way, one diminishes daily"* both refer to the study of ritual propriety (*lǐ* 礼).
In the *Zhuāngzi* (庄子) *"Knowing the North"* (知北游) chapter: *"Ritual propriety is the ornament of the Dao/Way and the beginning of disorder, hence it is said: ‘Cultivating the Dao/Way, one diminishes daily.’"*
Again, in the *Hòuhànshū* (后汉书) Volume 66, *Fàn Shēng* (范升) Memorial: *"Yǎn Xuān (颜渊) said: ‘Expand my knowledge with culture, refine me with ritual propriety (*lǐ* 礼).’ Confucius may be said to know teaching, and Yǎn to be adept in learning."*

Below, it cites *Lǎozi* (老子): *"For learning the Dao/Way, one diminishes daily."*
The two characters *"learning the Dao"* (学道) are linked, indicating a likely textual error. Only when *"expanding in culture and refining with ritual"* (博文约礼) is taken as *"learning"* (学), does it align with the ancient meaning of the term.

Diminishing and again diminishing, until one reaches *wúwéi* (无为).
*(Yán Kějūn’s note:)* *"Again diminishing"* (又损之), the *Héshàng* (河上) and *Wáng* (王) editions lack the character *zhī* (之).
*(Chén Zhōu’s note:)* The *Dūnhuáng* (敦煌), *Yùzhù* (御注), *Jǐngfú* (景福), *Qìngyáng* (庆阳), *Pányú* (磻溪), *Shìdōng* (室町), *Gāo* (高), *Gù* (顾), *Fù* (傅), *Fàn* (范) editions, as well as citations in *Zhuāngzi* (庄子) *"Knowing the North"* (知北游), *"Essentials of Administration"* (治要), *"Gleanings of Meaning"* (意林), and *"Literary Selections"* (文选) notes on the *"East Capital Eulogy"* (东京赋注), all include the character *zhī* (之).
*(Luó Zhěnyù’s note:)* The *Luó* (罗) edition lacks the character *yú* (于), omitting the first *sǔn* (损) character.
The *Yán* (严) edition lacks the character *yǐ* (以).

*Wúwéi* (无为) is *wúbùwéi* (无不为).
*(Yán Kějūn’s note:)* *"Without failing to act"* (无不为), all editions have the character *ér* (而) above the first *wú* (无).
*(Luó Zhěnyù’s note:)* The *Jǐnglóng* (景龙) and *Dūnhuáng* (敦煌) editions both lack the character *ér* (而).
*(Chén Zhōu’s note:)* The *Yán* (严) edition omits the first two characters *"无为"* (wúwéi), changing *"不"* (bù) to *"以"* (yǐ).
The *Shuìzhōu* (遂州) edition has the character *"所"* (suǒ) below the second *"无"* (wú), the *Gù* (顾) edition has *"也"* (yě) below the second *"为"* (wéi), and the *Zhào Mèngfǔ* (赵孟俯) edition has *"矣"* (yǐ).
The *Fù* (傅) and *Fàn* (范) editions have the character *"则"* (zé) below *"无为"* (wúwéi).
*Fàn* (范) states: *"The character ‘则’ (zé), Fù Yì (傅奕) and Wáng Bì (王弼) agree with the ancient editions."*

Again, the *Huáinán Dàoyīng* (淮南道应) Training cites it as *"Mòrán wúwéi, ér wúbùwéi yě"* (漠然无为，而无不为也), and explains below:
*"The so-called *wúwéi* (无为) is not acting before things;
The so-called *wúbùwéi* (无不为) is acting according to things’ own nature."*

To take the world under one’s sway, it is best to act with *wúshì* (无事).

「Qiánzhī’s annotation: Gāo Liè (高翿), Zhào Mèngfǔ (赵孟俯), and Péng Zhī (彭耜) have the character *"gù"* (故) above, while *Fàn* (范) has *"jiāng"* (将). Yán Zūn (严遵) and *Fù* (傅) have the two characters *"jiāngyù"* (将欲).

*Fàn* (范) has the character *"yú"* (于) below *"qǔ"* (取), while Yán (严), *Fù* (傅), and Péng (彭) have the character *"zhě"* (者). The *Wénzǐ* (文子) *Zìrán Piān* (自然篇) states: *"Wúwéi gù néng qǔ bǎi chuān, bù qiú gù néng dé, bùxíng gù néng zhì, shǐ yǐ qǔ tiānxià ér wúshì"* (无为故能取百川，不求故能得，不行故能至，是以取天下而无事), which directly elucidates this chapter.

Yú Yì (俞樾) remarks: *"The character ‘常’ (cháng) is likely a corruption of ‘当’ (dāng)."*

Héshàng Gōng’s (河上公) annotation reads: *"Qǔ (取), zhì (治) also. To **treat** the world, one should **act in accordance with** *wúshì* (无事)."* It is suspected that Héshàng Gōng’s original annotation was *"Zhì tiānxià dāng yǐ wúshì"* (治天下当以无事), and later scribes, following the corrupted *"cháng"* (常) in the text, added *"cháng"* (常) into the annotation as well.

When **there arises** *shì* (事), it is insufficient to **take** the world under one’s sway.

Qiánzhī’s annotation: The *Fù* (傅) edition has the character *"yòu"* (又) above *"bù"* (不).

The *Zhūrōng* (诸王) edition’s annotation for Chapter 51 reads: *"The previous chapter states: ‘Those who **take** the world under their sway should **act in accordance with** *wúshì* (无事); when **there arises** *shì* (事), **they are** *bùzú* (不足) **to take** the world under their sway.’"* The *Sòng Zhāng Tàishǒu* (宋张太守) collected edition of the *Dàozàng* (道藏) annotations by the four schools lacks *"yòu"* (又), but upon collation, it is noted: *"In Fù Yì’s (傅奕) edition of Chapter 41, the text reads: ‘**They are** *yòu bùzú* (又不足) **to take** the world under their sway, *yǐ* (矣).’"*

【Phonology】 This chapter has no rhyme in Jiāng’s (江氏) reading, and all other editions agree.

---

Now, this chapter reads: *"The **Sage** has no fixed **Dao/Way** of their own; they take the hearts of the people as their own heart."*

Qiánzhī’s annotation: All editions have the character *"cháng"* (常) below *"wú"* (无), except for the *Dūnhuáng* (敦煌) and *Gùhuān* (顾欢) editions.

Moreover, the *Běicáng Shūzhǎo* (北堂书钞) cites seven instances where the character *"xìng"* (姓) lacks the *"xīn"* (心) beneath it, while the *Yùlǎn* (御览) cites four hundred and one instances where *"xìng"* (姓) has the *"zhī"* (之) character beneath it.

This passage states that the **Sage** does not rely on their own judgment but instead takes the hearts of the people as their own.

As for the virtuous, I **empower them with virtue**; the unvirtuous, I **also empower them with virtue**, and they **attain virtue**.
As for the faithful, I **empower them with trust**; the unfaithful, I **also empower them with trust**, and they **attain trust**.

Yán Kějūn (严可均) notes: *"As for those who attain virtue and trust"*—all editions read *"dé shàn"* (德善) and *"dé xìn"* (德信) for the following sentence as well.
The *Yùzhù* (御注) omits the *"xìn"* (信) character.

Luó Zhènyù (罗振玉) states: *"The 'dé' (德) character"*—both the *Jǐnglóng* (景龙) and *Dūnhuáng* (敦煌) editions read *"dé"* (得).
Qiánzhī’s annotation: The editions of Yán (严), *Fù* (傅), *Suìzhōu* (遂州), and *Gù* (顾) all cite *Jiéshuō* (节解) and *Guāng* (荣) with the *Yùzhù* (御注) text, which reads *"dé"* (得). The editions of Yán (严) and *Fù* (傅) read *"dé shàn yǐ"* (得善矣), consistent with *Jiéshuō* and *Yùlǎn* (御览) 76.

*Dàijuàn* (柰卷), *Shìtáng* (室町), *Gùhuān* (顾欢), *Fàn* (范), *Péng* (彭), and *Zhào* (赵) editions read *"dé shàn yǐ, dé xìn yǐ"* (德善矣，德信矣).
The *Zhìyào* (治要) citation lacks *"dé shàn"* (得善) and *"dé xìn"* (得信).
Lǐ Dàochún (李道纯) states: *"Below 'dé shàn' (德善) and 'dé xìn' (德信), those who add the 'yǐ' (矣) character are incorrect."*

The **Sage** moves through the world under one’s sway, **cautious and vigilant**; **they act in accordance with** the **Dao/Way** of the world, **making their heart pure and undivided**.

Yán Kějūn (严可均) notes: *"Cautious and vigilant"*—the *Yùzhù* (御注) reads *"juànjuàn"* (惵惵), the *Héshàng* (河上) edition reads *"chùchù"* (惔惔), and *Wáng Bì* (王弼) reads *"xīxī"* (歙歙).
*Jiǎnwén* (简文) states: *"The Héshàng (河上) edition reads 'chù' (怵)."*
Gāo Qì (高翿) reads *"zházhá"* (喋喋).
Luó Zhènyù (罗振玉) notes: The *Jǐnglóng* (景龙) and *Jǐngfú* (景福) editions read *"chùchù"* (怵怵), while the *Yùzhù* (御注) and *Dūnhuáng* (敦煌) editions read *"juànjuàn"* (惵惵).
Bì Qián (毕沅) states: The *Héshànggōng* (河上公) edition reads *"chùchù"* (怵怵), *Wáng Bì* (王弼) reads *"xīxī"* (歙歙), and *Sū Língzhī* (苏灵芝) reads *"juànjuàn"* (惵惵) in the *Mínghuáng Zhù* (明皇注).
Lù Dēmíng (陆德明) states: *"One edition reads 'juànjuàn' (惵惵), and the Héshàng (河上) edition reads 'dàndan' (淡淡)."*
*Jiǎnwén* (简文) states: *"The Héshàng (河上) edition reads 'chù' (怵)."*
Now, I note that the *Héshànggōng* (河上公) edition reads *"chùchù"* (怵怵), consistent with the edition *Jiǎnwén* (简文) refers to.
Ancient texts lack the character *"juàn"* (惵), instead reading *"chùchù"* (怵怵). *"Xī"* (歙) and *"chù"* (怵) share similar sounds and meanings.

Qiánzhī’s annotation: The *Shìtáng* (室町), *Dàijuàn* (柰卷), *Gùhuān* (顾欢), and *Fàn* (范) editions read *"chùchù"* (怵怵), consistent with this stone.
The *Fù* (傅) and *Fàn* (范) editions read *"xīxī"* (歙歙), consistent with *Wáng Bì* (王弼).
The *Qìngyáng* (庆阳), *Pánxī* (磻溪), *Lóuzhèng* (楼正), *Péng* (彭), and *Zhào* (赵) editions read *"juànjuàn"* (惵惵), consistent with the *Yùzhù* (御注).
The *Héshàng* (河上) annotation states: *"The **Sage** moves through the world under one’s sway, cautious and vigilant, always fearing the dangers of wealth and nobility, not daring to indulge in arrogance and extravagance."*

Thus, the *Héshàng* (河上) edition reads *"chùchù"* (怵怵), and *Jiǎnwén* (简文) states *"Héshàng edition reads 'chù' (怵)"*, which is correct.
In the *Tángběn* (唐本), *"chù"* (怵) is often written as *"juàn"* (惵), likely following the *Yán Zhùn* (严注).

Yán Jùnpíng (严君平) states: *"Juànjuàn (惵惵) as if huīhuī (恢恢), meaning they embrace all things with an open and receptive heart."*

Péng Zhì (彭耜) interprets: *"Xīxī (歙歙) is without meaning, and juànjuàn (惵惵) is also without reason. I believe 'juànjuàn' (惵惵) should be read as 'chùchù' (○○), a depiction of danger and vigilance. This is likely a scribal error."*

Qiánzhī’s annotation: The *Yùpìan* (玉篇) states: *"Juàn (惵), from 'tú fán' (徒烦), meaning fear and apprehension. Chù (怵), from 'chì lǜ' (耻律), meaning fear."* The *Shuōwén Jiězì* (说文解字) states: *"Chù (怵), fear."* The *Guǎngyǎ Shìgǔ* (广雅释诂) states: *"Chù (怵), fear."* The *Shìshuō* (释训) states: *"Chùtì (怵惕), fear and apprehension."* The *Lǐjì Qìtǒng* (礼记祭统) states: *"The heart, fearful and reverent, serves it with propriety."* The *Mèngzǐ* (孟子) states: *"All have a sense of fear, reverence, and compassion."*

Thus, *"juànjuàn"* (惵惵) and *"chùchù"* (怵怵) both depict fear, their meanings being interchangeable.

Now, regarding *"hún qí xīn"* (浑其心), the editions of *Suìzhōu* (遂州), *Jǐngfú* (景福), *Yùzhù* (御注), *Qìngyáng* (庆阳), *Pánxī* (磻溪), *Lóuzhèng* (楼正), *Dàijuàn* (柰卷), *Shìtáng* (室町), *Héshàng* (河上), *Gùhuān* (顾欢), *Gāo Qì* (高翿), and *Zhào* (赵) all read *"hún qí xīn"* (浑其心).
The editions of *Yán Zūn* (严遵) and *Péng Zhì* (彭耜) lack the *"qí"* (其) character.
The *Fù* (傅) edition reads *"hún hún yān"* (浑浑焉), and the *Fàn* (范) edition reads *"hún xīn yān"* (浑心焉).
*Fàn* (范) states: *"Yán Zūn (严遵) and Wáng Bì (王弼) are consistent with the ancient editions."*

The phrase *"hún qí xīn"* (浑其心) conveys the meaning of *"hún hún dùn dùn"* (浑浑沌沌).
The *Lǘshuō Dàlèpiān* (吕览大乐篇) states: *"Hún hún dùn dùn"* (浑浑沌沌).
The *Wénxuǎn Jiāngfù Zhù* (文选江赋注) states: *"Hún hún dùn dùn, like undivided chicken eggs."* The *Zhuànshū Wén* (左传文十八) states: *"It is called hún dūn"* (谓之浑敦), with the annotation: *"The appearance of being unopened and impenetrable."*

Liú Shīpèi (刘师培) states: Regarding this passage, the phrase *"shèngrén zài tiānxià"* (圣人在天下), *"xīxī wéi"* (歙歙为), and *"zài"* (在) likely being a scribal error for *"rèn"* (任).
The phrase *"xīxī wéi"* (歙歙为) aligns with Chapter 20, *"dùn dùn xī"* (沌沌兮), which describes the act of **"acting in accordance with"** the **Dao/Way** of the world.

The *Wénxuǎn Dōngjīngfù Lǐzhù* (文选东京赋李注) cites *Lǎozǐ* (老子) as saying: *"The **Sage** moves through the world under one’s sway, **cautious and vigilant**."* Here, *"juànjuàn"* (惵惵) is an alternate reading for *"xīxī"* (歙歙), and *"yān"* (焉) is equivalent to *"wéi"* (为).

This fully confirms that in the ancient text the phrase *"xīxī wéi"* (歙歙为) has *"wéi"* (为) identical to *"yān"* (焉).

Qián Zhī (谦之) notes: Liu’s (刘) interpretation is incorrect. All variants read *"zài"* (在), not *"rèn"* (任). The complete passage should be:

*"The **Sage** moves through the world, **cautious and vigilant**;*
*acts in accordance with the world, **undivided and impenetrable**.*
*The phrase ‘**in the world**’ (在天下) contrasts with ‘**acting in accordance with the world**’ (为天下),*
*and ‘**cautious and vigilant**’ (怵怵) contrasts with ‘**undivided and impenetrable**’ (浑浑).*
*The three characters ‘**undivided heart**’ (浑其心) are a later interpolated annotation inserted into ‘**undivided and impenetrable**’ (浑浑).*

The **Fù** (傅) text reads:
*"The **Sage’s** presence in the world is **cautious and vigilant** (歙歙焉);
his **acting in accordance with** the world is **undivided and impenetrable** (浑浑焉)."*
Here, *"zhī"* (之) and *"yān"* (焉) are both added characters,
but the pairing of *"hún hún"* (浑浑) with *"chù chù"* (怵怵) is beyond doubt.

*The common people **fix their attention on** their ears and eyes;*
*The **Sage** **nurtures them like infants**.*

Luó Zhènyù (罗振玉) states:
*"The common people **fix their attention on** their ears and eyes"* (百姓皆注其耳目),
is omitted in the **Wáng** (王) and current editions,
but preserved in the **Jǐnglóng** (景龙), **Yùzhù** (御注), and **Dūnhuáng** (敦煌) texts.

Jì Yǔn (纪昀) notes:
Regarding *"hái"* (孩),
the annotation reads:
*"Wáng Bìo (王弼) renders it as ‘**cough**’ (咳)."*
Yet the original reading should remain *"hái"* (孩).

Takesuchi Yoshio (武内义雄) observes:
The **Dūn** (敦) and **Suì** (遂) texts render *"hái"* (孩) as *"○"* (an empty space).

The annotation states:
*"‘**Cough**’ (咳), originally sometimes written as ‘**nurture**’ (孩)."*

Qián Zhī (谦之) notes:
The current **Fù** (傅) and **Fàn** (范) texts read *"hái"* (咳),
while **Yán Zhēn** (严遵) renders it as *"hài"* (骇).

Fàn (范) explains:
*"‘**Cough**’ (咳), pronounced ‘hé lái’ (何来), depicts the appearance of an infant’s laughter.*
*Old editions and annotations uniformly read ‘**cough**’ (咳).*

「Yú Yè (俞樾) states:
By examining the passage *"For the world, make it one with your heart"* (为天下，浑其心), the **Héshàng** (河上) text includes the seven characters *"All the common people focus their ears and eyes upon it"* (百姓皆注其耳目). The **Wáng Bìo** (王弼) text should also originally have contained them, as evidenced by his annotation:
*"Thus, those who speak do so according to their knowledge, those who act do so according to their ability; all the common people focus their ears and eyes upon it, and I merely nurture them in their simplicity."* (如此则言者言其所知，行者行其所能，百姓各皆注其耳目焉，吾皆孩之而已。)

The annotation further contains the four characters *"each use their innate wisdom"* (各用聪明), placed beneath the sentence *"For the world, make it one with your heart"* (为天下，浑其心), which correctly elucidates the meaning of *"All the common people focus their ears and eyes upon it"* (百姓皆注其耳目). Since the canonical text omits this sentence, it should be restored according to the **Héshànggōng** (河上公) edition.

Qián Zhī (谦之) notes:
The restoration as above is correct. All the **Wáng** (王) editions mistakenly omit this sentence, but the Daoist Canon **Wáng** (王) edition retains it.

Moreover, *"注"* (zhu) means *"to gather"* (聚). The **Zhōu Lǐ** (周礼) commentary on *"shòurén"* (兽人) and the empty space *"○"* (○) in *"tiánshù"* (田疏) states:
*"注 means to gather."* (注犹聚也。) To *"register"* (注) their ears and eyes is to *"gather"* (聚) their ears and eyes.

The **Gù** (顾) edition’s commentary states:
*"Héshànggōng (河上公) renders it as ‘**注**’ (zhu), while other editions read ‘**浮**’ (fú). ‘浮’ implies stagnation and entanglement—those who are wayward, lost in worldly illusions, indulge their ears and eyes in sensory pleasures, becoming ensnared by sounds and colors, eventually drifting aimlessly like a long river, accumulating faults through self-indulgence."* (河上作『注』，诸本作『浮』，浮者染滞也，颠倒之徒，迷没世境，纵恣耳目，滞着声色，既而漂浪长流，愆非自积) This is incorrect; *"浮"* (fú) is a baseless alteration by later scholars to align with Buddhist teachings, which does not appear in the original **Lǎozǐ** (老子).

Gāo Hēng (高亨) remarks:
Regarding *"孩"* (hái), it is a borrowed character for *"阂"* (hé). The **Shuōwén Jiězì** (说文解字) states:
*"阂, external closure."* (阂, 外闭也。) The **Hànshū Lǜlì Zhì** (汉书律历志) says:
*"阂 conceals all things"* (阂藏万物), and **Yán Zhù** (颜注) cites **Jìn Sháo** (晋灼) as stating:
*"External closure is called 阂."* (外闭曰阂。) When the **Sage** (圣人) *"nurtures"* (孩) them, it means the **Sage** externally closes the common people’s ears and eyes.

The preceding passage states:
*"Gathering, gathering, for the world, make it one with your heart"* (歙歙为天下浑其心), meaning to make all under heaven’s hearts uniformly muddled and ignorant, without knowledge or awareness. This passage says:
*"All the common people focus their ears and eyes upon it, and the **Sage** externally closes them"* (百姓皆注其耳目，圣人皆阂之), meaning to externally block the common people’s ears and eyes, rendering them deaf and blind.

This is **Lǎozǐ**’s (老子) policy of keeping the people in simplicity. *"孩"* (hái), *"咳"* (kè), and *"阂"* (hé) are interchangeable as borrowed characters, hence also written as *"骇"* (hài) or *"咳"* (kè). The **Yánzǐ Wàipiān** (晏子外篇) Eighth says:
*"Does the nape of your neck close the heavens and earth?"* (颈尾咳于天地乎！) **Sūn Xīngxiǎn** (孙星衍) notes:
*"咳 (kè) is the same as 阂 (hé)."* (咳与阂同。) Thus, *"咳"* (kè) is also used for *"阂"* (hé).

**[Phonology]**
Jiāng Shì’s (江氏) rhyme readings find no rhyme in this chapter.
**Chén Zhù** (陈柱) suggests:
The *"心"* (xīn) in the second line rhymes, the *"善"* (shàn) in the third line rhymes, and the *"信"* (xìn) in the third line rhymes.

The **Jǐnglóng** (景龙) stele edition contains **63 characters**; the **Dūnhuáng** (敦煌) edition contains **62**; the **Héshàng** (河上) and **Wáng** (王) editions contain **64**; the **Fù** (傅) edition contains **68**; and the **Fàn** (范) edition contains **69**.

The **Héshàng** (河上) edition is titled *"Chapter on Trusting in Virtue"* (任德第四十九), the **Wáng** (王) edition is titled *"Chapter Forty-Nine"* (四十九章), and the **Fàn** (范) edition is titled *"Chapter Forty-Nine on the Sage’s Lack of Fixed Intent"* (圣人无常心章第四十九).

**Chapter Fifty** (五十章)
*Birth and Death* (出生入死).

**Chapter Fifty**
*Birth and Death*

Of those who seek life, there are thirteen;
Of those who court death, there are thirteen.
**Luó Zhèn-yù** notes: The *Dūnhuáng* edition reads *"什"* (shí) for *"十"* (shí), and this is consistent below.
**Mǎ Xù-lún** states: The *Shuōwén Jiězì* contains no *"涂"* (tú) or *"途"* (tú) characters; *"徒"* (tú) is likely their original form. In *Zhuāngzǐ’s* *"Chapter on Perfect Joy"* (至乐篇), *"食于道徒"* means "to eat along the Dao’s path." Here, *"徒"* should be read as it is written.
**Qián Zhī** notes: The phrase *"出生入死"* appears in *Lǚ Shì Chūnqiū’s* *"Chapter on Emotions and Desires"* (情欲篇), as cited by Gāo Hào.

*Zhuāngzǐ* says:
*"All things emerge from the loom, all return to the loom."*
*"Their emergence is not resisted, their return is not rejected."*
*"There is an emergence, there is a return—
returning and emerging, yet no trace of their form is seen."*
All these speak of *birth and death*.

When a person lives, they move toward death—thirteen in ten.
**Yán Kě-jūn** notes: *Wáng Bì* and *Gāo Yì* include *"亦"* (yì) after *"地"* (dì).
**Luó Zhèn-yù** notes: The *Jǐnglóng*, *Yùzhù*, *Jǐngfú*, and *Dūnhuáng* editions lack *"亦"* (yì), while the *Jǐngfú* edition includes *"皆"* (jiē) after *"动"* (dòng).
**Bì Yìn** notes: The *Fù* edition reads, *"而民之生生而动，动皆之死地，亦十有三"* (ér mín zhī shēngshēng ér dòng, dòng jiē zhī sǐdì, yì shíyǒusān); *Héshànggōng* and *Wáng Bì* read, *"人之生，动之死地，亦十有三"* (rén zhī shēng, dòng zhī sǐdì, yì shíyǒusān); *Gǔshénzǐ* reads, *"而民生动之死地，十有三"* (ér mín shēng dòng zhī sǐdì, shíyǒusān).
**Qián Zhī** notes: The *Hán Fēi Zǐ* and *Yù* editions align with this. **Qián Zhī** further notes: The *Yán* and *Suìzhōu* editions, as well as the *Nǎi* scroll, lack *"亦"* (yì), while the *Nǎi* scroll and *Shìmǎchōng* include *"皆"* (jiē).
**Fàn Yìngyuán**’s edition reads, *"民之生生而动之死地，亦十有三"*, and states, *"Hán Fēi and Yán Zhōng align with the ancient editions."*

**Yì Shùndǐng** argues: The *Wáng* edition and *Hán Fēi Zǐ* likely contain errors.
The *Wén Xuǎn*’s annotation on *Bào Zhào’s* *"Substitute for a Gentleman’s Lament"* (代君子有所思行) cites *Lǎozǐ* as:
*"人之生生之厚，动皆之死地，十有三."*
This citation appears reliable.
The six characters *"人之生生之厚"* (rén zhī shēngshēng zhī hòu) likely form a single clause.
*Lǎozǐ*’s intent is that excessive attachment to life leads one to court death.
Thus, the following line clarifies: *"夫何故？以其生生之厚."* (fú héguò? yǐ qí shēngshēng zhī hòu)

Of life, there are thirteen;
Of death, there are thirteen.
Their numbers are originally balanced—
Yet when one clings excessively to life,
Death’s count surpasses that of life.

If read as *"人之生，生而动"* (rén zhī shēng, shēng ér dòng),
the meaning becomes nearly unintelligible.
Even *Wáng Bì*’s annotation states:
*"而民生生之厚，更之无生之地焉."*
This confirms that *"生生之厚"* (shēngshēng zhī hòu) precedes *"动之死地"* (dòng zhī sǐdì).

**Gāo Yán-dì** explains:
*"生之徒"* (shēng zhī tú) refers to those favored by Heaven, who may live long;
*"死之徒"* (sǐ zhī tú) refers to those slighted by Heaven, who perish prematurely;
*"动而之死"* (dòng ér zhī sǐ) refers to those originally favored by Heaven, who might have lived long, yet through neglect court death.
For the vastness of Heaven and Earth, the multitude of beings—
birth and death are manifold, yet they fall into these three categories.

*"生生之厚"* (shēngshēng zhī hòu) refers to the wealthy and noble, who indulge excessively in nourishment, medicines, and elixirs to prolong life—
yet this very indulgence leads them to court death.
People mistakenly believe only violence harms life, while excessive self-nurturing is deemed beneficial—
yet both paths lead to death.
Thus, it is emphasized.

Of all under Heaven, ten in ten are measured:
Those who die young account for three;
Those who court death through excess account for three;
Only those who naturally fulfill life’s course account for the remaining three.
Alas! This is why few attain the full measure of their fate!

**Qián Zhī** notes: The claim of *"thirteen"* has been variously interpreted—
*Hán Fēi Zǐ*, *Héshànggōng*, *Bìxūzǐ*, and *Yè Mèngdé* associate it with the four limbs and nine orifices, an arbitrary association.
Others, like *Dù Guǎngchéng*, link it to the *"ten evils and three offenses"* (十恶三业);
*Fàn Yìngyuán* ties it to the *"five phases’ life-death cycles"* (五行生死之数).
These interpretations are forced and unreliable.

*Sū Shè* posits that the way of life and death comprises nine paths,
while the way of neither life nor death is one—
*Lǎozǐ* speaks of the nine, omitting the one,
leaving it for the seeker to discover.
This seems profound, yet it interprets *Lǎozǐ* through *Buddhist* lenses.

**Jiāo Jǔn** follows this, claiming enlightenment upon reading *"出生入死"* (shēngchū rùsǐ),
yet his *"playful mastery of life and death"* is sheer misinterpretation.
Alas! A grievous error!

Why is this so?

Because of the profound depth of its life-giving principle.

**Mǎ Xùlún** states that *Fàn* originally wrote *"zāi"* (哉) after *"gù"* (故), as evidenced by *Nǎi Juàn* and *Wén Xuǎn*’s *Sǔoshíxíng* annotation, which cites *"gù"* followed by *"zāi."*

**Fàn** wrote: *"Fúhé zāi"* (夫何哉), matching *Hán Fēi* and the ancient texts.

**Qiānzhī** notes: The *Jǐngfú* edition, *Fù*, *Fàn* editions, and *Shìchōng* edition all include *"yě"* (也) after *"hòu"* (厚). **Luó Zhènyù** states: *"In the Jīnglóng edition, after 'hòu' (厚) is 'yě' (也)."* This is a mistaken emendation. **Jiǎng Xīchāng** unknowingly followed this error.

It is said that those skilled in nurturing life
walk upon the land without encountering **tiger and rhino**,
enter the battlefield without bearing armor or weapons.

**Qiānzhī** notes: The **"○○"** is a variant construction of *"zhìhǔ"* (兕虎), which should be *"hǔzhì"* (虎兕).
**Wáng Bì** annotates: *"Tiger and rhino have no place to deploy their claws and horns,"*
while the *Huáinán Jiěyán* explains: *"The tiger has no place to deploy its claws; the rhino has no place to deploy its horn,"*
both placing *"tiger"* before *"rhino,"* confirming the original text was *"hǔzhì"* (虎兕) as a continuous phrase.

The *Dūnhuáng* edition renders *"jiǎ"* (甲) as *"jiǎ"* (钾), a variant of *"jiǎ"* (甲).
*"Yù"* (遇) is corrected to *"bì"* (避) in the *Yán* edition,
while *"bèi"* (被) is also rendered as *"bì"* (避) in the *Héshàng* and *Zhào* editions.
**Yú Yì** states: *"According to Héshànggōng’s annotation, 'bèi' (被) is written as 'bì' (避)."*
Based on *Hán Fēi Zǐ’s* *"Jiě Lǎozǐ"* chapter:
*"When wandering in the world, the sage has no intent to harm others,
and thus none will harm them.
Without harm, they need no defenses,
hence ‘walking upon the land without encountering tiger and rhino.’
Entering the battlefield, they do not rely on armor for protection,
hence ‘entering the army without bearing armor or weapons.’"*
**Gù Qiānlí** mistakenly suggests *"entering the world"* instead of *"entering the army."*

The ancient edition of *Lǎozǐ* should have *"bèi"* (备) instead of *"bèi"* (被),
meaning they do not rely on armor as defense.
*"Bèi"* (备) and *"bèi"* (被) are homophonous;
later scribes altered *"bèi"* (备) to *"bèi"* (被), deviating from the original text.
**Yú Yì’s** argument is incorrect.

**Qiānzhī** confirms: *"Bèi"* (被) is correct.
The *Hán Fēi Jiě Lǎo* edition also uses *"bèi"* (被).
**Lú Wénpián** notes: *"Zhāng Líng’s edition uses 'bèi' (被)."*
**Gù Guǎngqì** states: *"The hidden edition uses 'bèi' (被); 'bèi' (备) and 'bèi' (被) share the same meaning."*
**Wáng Xiānshèn** explains:
*"Guāngyǎ Shìgǔ* defines *‘bèi’* (备) as *‘jù’* (具, complete).
*The Shǐjì Zhàohóu Shìjiā Jiéshū* cites *Zhāng Yì’s* annotation: *‘bèi’* (被) also means *‘jù’* (具).
Thus, the original text uses *‘bèi’* (备),
while *Wáng Bì’s* edition uses *‘bèi’* (被).
Since *‘jiǎbīng’* (甲兵) refers to what is possessed by oneself,
it is clear that both *‘bèi’* (备) and *‘bèi’* (被) are acceptable.
The *Héshàng* edition uses *‘bì’* (避), a phonetic error."*

---
**○** Without a place to lodge its horn, **Qiānzhī** confirms: *"Yú"* (兕), a beast’s name, is the female **rhinoceros**. The *Ěryǎ* states: *"Its form resembles that of a wild cow, with a single horn weighing a thousand *jīn* (斤)."* In the *Huáinánzǐ*’s *"Dìxíng Trùn"* (地形训), it reads: *"In the southern lands, there are the rhinoceros and elephants of Liángshān."* High Yù (高诱) annotates: *"Liángshān lies in Kuàijī (会稽). The rhinoceros horns and elephant tusks of Chángshā (长沙) and Xiāngnán (湘南) are all treasures."* The *Shānhǎijīng* (山海经) records: *"The **yú** (兕) emerges from the southern banks of Xiāngshuǐ (湘水), with a blackish hue."* As **Lǎozǐ** (老子) was a **Chǔ** (楚) native, he used the **yú** as a metaphor. **"Without a place to lodge its horn,"** the **Dūn** (敦) and **Suì** (遂) editions render *"tóu"* (投) as *"zhù"* (驻). **Gù** (顾) annotates in his *Chéngshū* (成疏): *"All editions say *‘zhù’* (驻), meaning *‘to stand’*."* Thus, this is what **Chéng** (成) observed in his original text. In the *Huáinánzǐ*’s *"Quán Yán Trùn"* (诠言训), it cites: *"The tiger has no place to deploy its claws, the **yú** has no place to deploy its horn"*—both rendered as *"cuò"* (措). Jiǎng Xíchāng (蒋锡昌) states: *"‘Zhù’ (驻) likely shares the same pronunciation as ‘zhù’ (注)."* In **Zhuāngzǐ**’s *"Dá Shēng"* (达生), it reads: *"He who strikes with a tile is skilled"*—the *Shìwén* (释文) cites **Lǐ** (李) as saying: *"‘Zhù’ (注) means ‘to strike’."* Both *"zhù"* (驻) and *"zhù"* (注) are phonetic variants of *"tóu"* (投). The *Shuōwén Jiězì* (说文解字) defines *"tóu"* (投) as *"to thrust"* (擿). **"Without a place to lodge its horn"** means that the adept at nurturing life, having avoided encountering the **yú**, thus the **yú** finds no place to thrust its horn. **Qiānzhī** confirms: Jiǎng’s explanation is correct. The *Yán Tiě Lún* (盐铁论) in *"Shìwù Piān"* (世务篇) renders it as **"Without a place to use its horn"**—*"yòng"* (用) also being a phonetic variant. **Lǎozǐ**’s *"Bǎixìng jiē zhù qí ěrmù"* (百姓皆注其耳目) uses *"zhù"* (注) in the sense of *"use"* (用).

**○** Without a place to sheath its claws, weapons have no room to wield their blades. **Yán Kějūn** (严可均) notes: *"‘Sheath its claws’"* is rendered as *"cuò"* (措) in **Gù** (顾)’s annotation, **Héshàng** (河上), and **Wáng Bì** (王弼)’s text, while the *Shìwén* (释文) uses *"cuò"* (错). **Wǔnèi Yìxióng** (武内义雄) observes: The **Dūn** (敦) and **Suì** (遂) editions render *"‘cuò’* (措) as *"‘cuò’* (错)"; the *Shìwén* (释文) edition aligns with this. **Qiānzhī** confirms: **Luǒ Juàn** (罗卷) renders *"‘zhuǎ’* (爪) as *"‘○’*"* (○), an error. The *Bēiběn* (碑本) renders *"‘cuò’* (措) as *"‘kāi’* (揩)"*, also incorrect. *"‘Kāi’* (揩)"* is a mistaken character for *"‘cuò’* (措)."* Both the *Hán Fēi Jiě Lǎo* (韩非解老) and *Shìwén* (释文), as well as the **Suìzhōu** (遂州) and **Fàn** (范) editions, render it as *"‘cuò’* (错)"; while the *Jǐngfú* (景福), *Fénxī* (磻溪), *Shìtáng* (室町), **Nǎi Juàn** (柰卷), and **Fù Yì** (傅奕) editions all use *"‘cuò’* (措)"*.*"‘Cuò’* (措) and *"‘cuò’* (错)"* were anciently interchangeable. *"‘Cuò’* (措)"* means *"to place"*—*"without a place to sheath its claws"* implies *"without a place to rest its claws."* *"‘Zhuǎ’* (爪)"* in **Luǒ Juàn** (罗卷) is rendered as *"‘○’*"* (○), resembling *"‘zhuā’* (抓)"* in form. **Xià Shēn** (夏竦) in his *Gǔwén Sìshēng Yùn* (古文四声韵) includes the character *"‘zhuā’* (抓)"*, citing the ancient *Lǎozǐ* (老子) text as *"‘○’*"* (○). Why so? It is because there is **no place of death**. **Liú Shīpèi** (刘师培) states: *"In the *Hán Fēizǐ Jiě Lǎo* (韩非子解老篇), it reads: ‘Embodying the Dao of Heaven and Earth, it is said: *“Without a place of death.”*’ Thus, the character *"‘yě’*"* (也) in this passage is a corruption of *"‘dì’*"* (地). **Wáng** (王) explains it as *"‘What place of death is there?’"*—so **Wáng**’s (王) edition also renders it as *"‘dì’*"* (地). Now, the *Héshàng* (河上) edition uses *"‘dì’*"* (地), while **Wáng**’s (王) edition uses *"‘yě’*"* (也), likely due to scribal errors. **Qiānzhī** confirms: All **Wáng** (王) editions uniformly render it as *"‘dì’*"* (地), not *"‘yě’*"* (也); **Liú**’s (刘) source was an erroneous edition. Among all **Wáng** (王) editions, only the **Zhèjú** (浙局) edition, based on the **Huátíng Zhāng** (华亭张) original, renders it as *"‘sǐ yě’*"* (死也), which lacks meaning. All the *Shíběn* (石本) and *Shǐxiěběn* (写本) editions align with this *Shí* (石) text, except the **Suìzhōu** (遂州) edition, which renders *"‘hé’*"* (何) as *"‘qí’*"* (其). The **Fàn** (范) edition renders *"‘gù’*"* (故) as *"‘zāi’*"* (哉). The **Fù** (傅) and **Nǎi Juàn** (柰卷) editions have *"‘yě’*"* (也) after *"‘gù’*"* (故), while the **Yán** (严) and **Shìtáng** (室町) editions use *"‘zāi’*"* (哉). The *Hán Fēi Jiě Lǎo* (韩非解老) and **Wáng Xīnzhī** (王羲之) editions, along with the **Fù** (傅) edition, include *"‘yān’*"* (焉) after *"‘dì’*"* (地)—this is an added character for rhetorical effect, unrelated to the core meaning. **Gāo Yán’dì** (高延第) states: This chapter instructs those navigating turbulent times that the **yú** and tiger, as well as weapons and blades, are all ominous and violent, metaphorically illustrating the treacherous paths of the world and the deceitful nature of human affairs. Reading **Zhuāngzǐ**’s *"Yǎngshēng Zhǔ"* (养生主) and *"Rénjiān Shì"* (人间世) suffices to grasp the intent of this chapter—it does not truly advocate following a hungry tiger. The followers of **Gě Hóng** (葛洪) fail to understand this meaning, fabricating talismans and spells to ward off evil, claiming one can enter mountains and subdue spirits—utterly absurd.

**[Yīnyùn]** This chapter lacks rhyme in **Jiāng**’s (江) pronunciation. **Chén Zhù** (陈柱) suggests: *"‘sān’*"* (三) rhymes with *"‘sān’*"* (三). **Qiānzhī** confirms: *"‘Sān’*"* (三) in ancient pronunciation was akin to *"‘sēn’*"* (森). The *"Pí Biàn"* (摽) of the *"Shī"* (诗) reads: *"Its fruit is threefold (三), seeking my commoners (庶士), until now (今兮)"*—harmonizing with the modern rhyme. Additionally, *"‘hòu’*"* (厚) and *"‘jiǎo’*"* (角) form a rhyme. **Fāng Yǐzhì** (方以智) in his *Tōng Yǎ* (通雅) states: *"‘Jiǎo’*"* (角) in ancient pronunciation was *"‘lù’*"* (禄); in the *"Shī"* (诗), it rhymes with *"‘wū’*"* (屋), while **Dōng Fāng Shào** (东方朔) and **Zhòng Chángtǒng** (仲长统) used it to rhyme with *"‘zú’*"* (足) and *"‘sú’*"* (俗), respectively. Now, *"‘lù’*"* (禄), *"‘hòu’*"* (厚), *"‘zú’*"* (足), and *"‘wū’*"* (屋) are all classified under the *"Hóu"* (侯) phonetic department by **Wáng Niànsūn** (王念孙), so *"‘jiǎo’*"* (角) and *"‘hòu’*"* (厚) belong to the same department and rhyme.

The **Jǐnglóng Bēiběn** (景龙碑本) contains **79 characters**; the **Dūnhuáng** (敦煌) edition matches this, as does the **Héshàng Gōng Shìdétáng** (河上公世德堂本) edition. **Wáng**’s (王) edition has **80 characters**; the **Fù** (傅) edition has **87 characters**; the **Fàn** (范) edition has **83 characters**. The **Héshàng** (河上) edition is titled *"Guìshēng Dìwǔshí"* (贵生第五十); **Wáng**’s (王) edition is titled *"Wǔshí Zhāng"* (五十章); the **Fàn** (范) edition is titled *"Shēngshēng Rùsǐ Zhāng Dìwǔshí"* (出生入死章第五十). The **Sòngkān** (宋刊) edition of the **Héshàng** (河上) text has **77 characters**, with omissions and errors.

---
**Chapter 51**
The **Dao/Way** gives birth to it,
**Virtue/Power** nourishes it,
Things shape it,
**Circumstances** (势) bring it to fulfillment.
Thus, all things do not fail to revere the **Dao/Way** and hold **Virtue/Power** in high esteem.

**Yán Kějūn** (严可均) notes: *"‘Thus, all things’*"* is rendered as *"‘Thus, the sage’*"* in **Gù**’s (顾) annotation.
**Wèi Jiàosūn** (魏稼孙) states: *"‘**Virtue/Power** nourishes it’*"* lacks the character *"‘**Virtue/Power**’*"* (德) in **Gù**’s (顾) annotation.

**Chapter 51**

The **Dao/Way** gives birth to it,
**Virtue/Power** nurtures it,
Things take form through it,
**Circumstances** (势) bring it to fulfillment.
Thus, the **Dao/Way** is held in reverence, and **Virtue/Power** is esteemed.

**Luó Zhènyù** (罗振玉) notes: The Dunhuang edition lacks the characters *"‘none do not’"* (莫不), while the Jingfu edition lacks the character *"‘and’"* (而).
**Wǔnèi Yìxióng** (武内义雄) states: In the Dunhuang edition, *"‘**Circumstances**’"* (势) is rendered as *"‘heat’"* (热), which is likely an error.
**Qiānzhī** (谦之) examines: The Suizhou edition reads *"‘**Circumstances** bring it to maturity’"* (熟成之), but *"‘maturity’"* (熟) is also erroneous.
*"‘**Virtue/Power** nurtures it’"* (德畜之), the Guangming edition reads *"‘**Virtue/Power** stores it’"* (蓄之); *"‘esteem **Virtue/Power**’"* (贵德), Gù Huān (顾欢) reads *"‘**Virtue/Power** is chief’"* (首德).
Moreover, the **Yán** (严) edition lacks *"‘none do not’"* (莫不), while the *Hou Han Shu* (后汉书) *Fèng Yǎn* (冯衍) transmission omits *"‘thus’"* (是以).

**Dàtián Qíngxuān** (大田晴轩) explains: The **Dao/Way** is principle (理); **Virtue/Power** is the vital **qi** (一气).
*"‘Gives birth to it’"* (生之) means to initiate it;
*"‘**Virtue/Power** nurtures it’"* (畜之) means to endow it with **qi** (气).
However, upon close examination of **Lǎo** (老) and **Zhuāng** (庄) texts, beyond the vital **qi**, there is no other **Dao/Way**. The **Dao/Way** is none other than this vital **qi**.
Hence, **Zhuāng Zhōu** (庄周) refers to the **Dao/Way** as the robust and vigorous **qi** of the heavens and earth (知北游).
*"‘Robust and vigorous’"* (强阳) means ceaseless motion (本郭象).
*"‘Ceaseless motion’"* (强阳) also appears in the *Yùyán Piān* (寓言篇) (as per **Gù**’s (郭) annotation).
Later scholars speak of *"‘lively and effervescent’"* (活泼泼地), likely referring to this.
*"‘Things take form through it, **Circumstances** bring it to fulfillment’"* (物形之，势成之):
*"‘Form’"* (形) means to define form, to give shape to all things.
**Zhuāng Zhōu** (庄周) states: *"‘Things take form through it’"* (物生成理谓之形).
The **Dao/Way**’s reverence and **Virtue/Power**’s esteem are such that none command them, yet they ever arise naturally.
**Luó Zhènyù** (罗振玉) notes: *"‘The **Dao/Way** is held in reverence, **Virtue/Power** is esteemed’"* (道之尊，德之贵) reads *"‘The **Dao/Way** is revered, **Virtue/Power** is noble’"* (道尊、德贵) in the Dunhuang edition.
*"‘None command them’"* (莫之命), the **Jìnglóng** (景龙) and Dunhuang editions both render as *"‘none bestow rank upon them’"* (爵).
**Yán Kějūn** (严可均) states: *"‘None command them’"* (夫莫之命) is rendered as *"‘none bestow rank upon them’"* (之爵) in **Gù**’s (顾) and **Fèi Yì** (傅奕) annotations.
**Qiānzhī** (谦之) examines: The Suizhou, **Yán Zhūn** (严遵), and **Gù Huān** (顾欢) editions also render as *"‘rank’"* (爵).
Moreover, the **Dàocháng** (道藏) edition by **Sòng Zhāng Tàishǒu** (宋张太守) collates the four families’ (四家) annotations, noting: *"‘The **Dao/Way** is held in reverence, **Virtue/Power** is esteemed’"* (道之尊，德之贵) in the **Mínghuáng** (明皇) and **Wáng Bì** (王弼) editions both render *"‘rank’"* (爵) for *"‘command’"* (命).
All **Wáng** (王) family editions mistakenly record this as **Bì**’s (弼) annotation, as does the **Diànběn** (殿本) edition.
**Jì Yǔn** (纪昀) states: *"‘I examine this sentence, suspecting that the original annotation beneath *"‘command’"* (命) was mistakenly recorded as **Bì**’s (弼) note.’"* The examination of **Jì**’s (纪) explanation is correct.
The **Dàocháng** (道藏) edition by **Zhāng** (张) shows that **Wáng Bì**’s (王弼) original reads *"‘rank’"* (爵), consistent with the ancient editions of **Yán Zhūn** (严遵) and **Fèi Yì** (傅奕); the Dunhuang edition also renders as *"‘rank’"* (爵), which harmonizes in meaning.
Thus, the **Dao/Way** gives birth to it,
**Virtue/Power** nurtures it,
It lengthens and fosters it,
It brings to fulfillment and matures it,
It nourishes and covers it.

**Yán Kějūn** (严可均) notes: *"‘It brings to fulfillment and matures it’"* (成之熟之) is rendered as *"‘It steadies and poisons it’"* (亭之毒之) in **Wáng Bì**’s (王弼) edition.
**Luó Zhènyù** (罗振玉) states: The **Jìnglóng** (景龙), **Jìngfú** (景福), Dunhuang, and **Yìngfú** (御注) editions all read *"‘It brings to fulfillment and matures it’"* (成之熟之).
Moreover, *"‘**Virtue/Power** nurtures it’"* (德畜之) is omitted in **Luó**’s (罗) edition, and the Dunhuang edition lacks the character *"‘**Virtue/Power**’"* (德).
**Qiānzhī** (谦之) examines: The **Yìngfú** (御注), **Qìngyáng** (庆阳), **Pánxī** (磻溪), **Lóuzhèng** (楼正), **Gù** (顾), **Péng** (彭), **Zhào** (赵), **Gāo** (高), **Fàn** (范), and **Shìzhōng** (室町) editions all lack *"‘**Virtue/Power**’"* (德); **Fàn** (范) renders *"‘nurtures’"* (畜) as *"‘stores’"* (蓄).
*"‘It brings to fulfillment and matures it’"* (成之熟之), the **Qìngyáng** (庆阳), **Lóuzhèng** (楼正), **Pánxī** (磻溪), **Zhào** (赵), **Gù** (顾), **Péng** (彭), **Gāo** (高), **Nài** (柰) editions, as well as the **Shìzhōng** (室町), **Héshàng** (河上), and **Wáng Xīzhī** (王羲之) editions all read *"‘fulfillment’"* (成) and *"‘maturity’"* (熟).
*"‘It nourishes and covers it’"* (养之覆之), the **Fèi** (傅) and **Fàn** (范) editions, along with the *Wénxuǎn* (文选) *Biànmìng Lùn* (辨命论) *Lǐ Zhù* (李注), read *"‘It shelters and covers it’"* (盖之覆之).
*"‘It brings to fulfillment and matures it’"* (成之熟之), the **Fèi** (傅) and **Fàn** (范) editions render as *"‘It steadies and poisons it’"* (亭之毒之).
**Fàn** (范) states: *"‘**Steady** (亭) and **poison** (毒)’"* are as per **Wáng Bì** (王弼) and **Lǐ Qí** (李奇), matching the ancient editions.
**Fèi Yì** (傅奕) cites the *Shǐjì* (史记): *"‘**Steady** (亭) means congealing or solidifying.’"* The *Guǎngyǎ* (广雅) states: *"‘**Poison** (毒) means to settle or rest.’"*
**Bì Yùn** (毕沅) states: The *Shuōwén Jiězì* (说文解字) says: *"‘**Poison** (毒) means thick or dense.’"* The *Shìmíng* (释名) says: *"‘**Steady** (亭) means to stop.’"*
According to this, the meanings of *"‘**steady** (亭), **fulfillment** (成), **poison** (毒), **maturity** (熟)’"* are all closely related.

It is born yet not possessed,
It is done yet not relied upon,
It is lengthened yet not controlled—
This is called the **Mysterious Virtue/Power** (玄德).

**Xí Zhòng** (奚侗) notes: The four sentences already appear in Chapter 10; they are repeated here.
**Qiānzhī** (谦之) examines: **Luó**’s (罗) edition mistakenly renders *"‘relied upon’"* (恃) as *"‘disappointed’"* (怅), and the **Yán** (严) edition renders *"‘called’"* (谓) as *"‘done’"* (为).
Moreover, the **Lǐ Yuē** (李约) edition from the **Táng** (唐) dynasty lacks the sentence *"‘It is lengthened yet not controlled’"* (长而不宰).

**[Phonetics]**
Jiāng (江) pronunciation: *"‘nurtures’"* (畜), *"‘fosters’"* (育), *"‘matures’"* (熟), *"‘covers’"* (覆) rhyme (幽部), *"‘possessed’"* (有), *"‘relied upon’"* (恃), *"‘controlled’"* (宰) rhyme (之部).
**Wǔnèi Yìxióng** (武内义雄) and **Chén Zhù** (陈柱): *"‘possessed’"* (有), *"‘relied upon’"* (恃), *"‘controlled’"* (宰), *"‘**Virtue/Power**’"* (德) rhyme.
**Dèng Tíngzhēn** (邓廷桢) states: *"‘**Possessed** (有), **relied upon** (恃), **controlled** (宰)’"* are all from the *zhī* (之) and *kǎo* (咍) rhyme groups; *"‘**Virtue/Power**’"* (德) is a *zhī* (之) and *kǎo* (咍) rhyme group character with an entering tone.
**Yáo Wéntián** (姚文田): *"‘Born’"* (生), *"‘form’"* (形), *"‘fulfillment’"* (成) rhyme (十青平声), *"‘nurtures’"* (畜), *"‘fosters’"* (育), *"‘poison’"* (毒), *"‘covers’"* (覆) rhyme (七匊入声).
*"‘It brings to fulfillment and matures it’"* (成之熟之) is also rendered as *"‘It steadies and poisons it’"* (亭之毒之); *"‘matures’"* (熟) and *"‘poison’"* (毒) share the same rhyme.
In the *Lièzǐ* (列子) *Huángdì Piān* (黄帝篇): *"‘He who plays with you, none shall you tell; his petty words, all men find **poisonous**; none perceive, none understand—what **maturity** (孰) do you seek in each other!’"* (与汝游者，莫汝告也；彼所小言，尽人毒也；莫觉莫悟，何相孰也！)
*"‘Tell’"* (告), *"‘**poisonous**’"* (毒), *"‘**maturity**’"* (孰) form a rhyme, which serves as precedent.
Moreover, the **Gāoběn Hàn** (高本汉) edition rhymes *"‘born’"* (生), *"‘nurtures’"* (畜), *"‘lengthened’"* (长), *"‘fosters’"* (育) in alternation.
**Gù Yànwǔ** (顾炎武) in *Tángyùn Zhèng* (唐韵正) Volume 14 states: *"‘**Maturity**’"* (熟) is pronounced *shūliú* (殊六切), with a departing tone as *shūliú* (殊溜反).
The *Lǎozǐ* (老子) reads: *"‘Thus, the **Dao/Way** gives birth to it, nurtures it, lengthens it, fosters it, brings to fulfillment and matures it, nourishes and covers it.’"* (故道生之畜之，长之育之，成之熟之，养之覆之。)
Moreover, *"‘fosters’"* (育) is pronounced *yù* (余六切), with a departing tone as *yù* (柚).
As seen in the *Lǎozǐ* (老子) above.
The **Jìnglóng** (景龙) edition has **72 characters** (实七十二字), the Dunhuang edition has **68 characters** (实六十六字) in its annotation, while the **Hé** (河), **Wáng** (王), and **Fèi** (傅) editions have **72 characters**, and the **Fàn** (范) edition has **71 characters**.

「The **Hé** (河) edition titles this as *"Nurturing Virtue/Power, Chapter 51"* (养德第五十一), the **Wáng** (王) edition as *"Chapter 51"* (五十一章), and the **Fàn** (范) edition as *"Chapter of the Dao/Way Giving Birth, Chapter 51"* (道生之章第五十一).

**Chapter 52**: The world has a beginning, which is taken as the **mother of all things** (天下母).
**Qiánzhī** (谦之) notes: The **Fèi Yì** (傅奕) text reads *"It can be taken as the **mother of all things**"* (可以为天下母), but all other editions omit *"can"* (可). Only the **Wáng** (王) edition in the **Daozàng** (道藏) provides an annotation below this sentence: *"If one begins well, one can also nurture and foster well. Thus, the world has a beginning, and it can be taken as the **mother of all things**."* (善始之，则善养畜之矣，故天下有始，则可以为天下母矣。) The **Sòng** (宋) edition of **Zhāng Tàishǒu** (张太守) collated with the **Daozàng** (道藏) editions is identical, while the **Diànběn** (殿本) mistakenly omits these twenty-two characters.
The annotation *"It can be taken as the **mother of all things**"* (可以为天下母) aligns with the **Fèi Yì** (傅奕) text.

Having known its **mother** (母), one also knows its **child** (子).
**Yán Kějūn** (严可均) states: *"Also knows its **child**"* (又知其子) reads as *"repeatedly knows"* (复知) in the **Hé** (河) edition, while **Wáng Bì** (王弼) and **Gāo Yì** (高翿) render it as *"then knows"* (以知).
**Qiánzhī** (谦之) notes: *"Having known its **mother**"* (既知其母), the **Wáng** (王) edition in the **Daozàng** (道藏) matches this, while other **Wáng** (王) editions, **Dūnhuáng** (敦煌) editions, **Suì** (遂) editions, **Wáng Xīzhī** (王羲之) editions, **Fèi** (傅) editions, and **Fàn** (范) editions all read *"knows"* (知) as *"obtains"* (得). The **Jǐngfú** (景福), **Guǎngmíng** (广明), **Hé** (河) editions, **Nài** (柰) volumes, **Shìtóng** (室町) editions, **Gù Huān** (顾欢) editions, and the annotation of the **Sīcháng** (思玄赋) in *Wénxuǎn* (文选) all quote this stone text identically.
*"Also knows its **child**"* (又知其子), the **Shìtóng** (室町) edition has *"also"* (又) followed by *"then"* (以) below. The **Dūnhuáng** (敦煌) and **Suì** (遂) editions both read *"then knows"* (以知), while the **Nài** (柰) volume reads *"repeatedly knows"* (复知).
**Lǐ Dàochún** (李道纯) remarks: *"Having obtained its **mother**, then knows its **child**"* (既得其母，以知其子) and *"Having known its **mother**, repeatedly knows its **child**"* (既知其母，复知其子) are both incorrect.

Having known its **child** (子), one again protects its **mother** (母).
Thus, one’s **life** (身) remains unharmed.
**Qiánzhī** (谦之) notes: The character *"its"* (其) below *"knows"* (知) is missing and should be restored according to other editions.
*"Again protects its **mother**"* (复守其母), the **Jǐngfú** (景福) edition mistakenly reads *"again knows its **mother**"* (复知其母), likely due to confusion with the two *"knows"* (知) above.
Moreover, the **Lǐ Dàochún** (李道纯) edition reads *"returns"* (归) instead of *"protects"* (守), while **Xíng Xuán** (邢玄), **Nài** (柰) volumes, **Fèi** (傅), and **Fàn** (范) editions render *"dies"* (没) as *"deceases"* (殁).
This chapter’s meaning is the same as that of **Chapter 25**’s *"Circulate without ceasing"* (周行而不殆).
*"Circulate without ceasing, it can be taken as the **mother of all things**"* (周行而不殆，可以为天下母) corresponds to this chapter’s *"The world has a beginning, which is taken as the **mother of all things**"* (天下有始，以为天下母).
*"Having known its **mother**, also knowing its **child**, having known its **child**, again protecting its **mother**"* (既知其母，又知其子，既知其子，复守其母), the **child** and **mother** (子母) mutually sustain each other without interruption, which is the meaning of *"without ceasing"* (不殆). *"Without ceasing"* (不殆) is akin to *"without end"* (不止); further explanation is in **Chapter 25**.

Block its **orifice** (兑), close its **gates** (门).
Thus, one’s **life** (身) remains without **toil** (勤).
**Luó Zhènyù** (罗振玉) notes: *"Orifice"* (兑) has the annotation: *"The **Hé** (河) edition reads ‘**sharp**’"* (河上本作「锐」).
The **Jǐngfú** (景福) edition also reads *"sharp"* (锐), as does the text below.
**Wǔnèi Yìxióng** (武内义雄) states: The **Dūnhuáng** (敦煌) edition reads *"earnest"* (懃) instead of *"toil"* (勤).
**Qiánzhī** (谦之) notes: The **Luó** (罗) volume reads *"toil"* (勤).
*"Orifice"* (兑), in all current **Hé** (河) editions, is also rendered as *"orifice"* (兑), matching the citation in *Huáinán Dàoyīng Xuàn* (淮南道应训).
**Yú Yì** (俞樾) remarks: *"Orifice"* (兑) should be read as *"hole"* (穴).
In *Wénxuǎn* (文选), the *Fēngfù* (风赋) states *"The empty **hole** brings wind"* (空穴来风), and its annotation cites *Zhuāngzǐ* (庄子): *"The empty **orifice** brings wind"* (空阅来风).
*"Orifice"* (阅) is phonetically derived from *"orifice"* (兑), and *"hole"* (穴) can be used as a substitute for *"orifice"* (兑) as well. *"Block its **hole**"* (塞其穴) aligns perfectly with *"close its **gates**"* (闭其门) in meaning.
**Sūn Yìràng** (孙诒让) remarks: *"Orifice"* (兑) should be read as *"tunnel"* (隧), as these two characters were used interchangeably in ancient times.
In *Zhuàn Èrshísān Nián Zuǒzhuan* (左传襄二十三年), it states *"Qǐ Zhí (杞植) and Huá Huán (华还) carried armor and secretly entered the **tunnel** of Yǔ (于)"* (载甲夜入且于之隧), and in *Lǐjì Dàn Gǒng* (礼记檀弓), the *Zhòng Zhù* (郑注) cites it as *"**tunnel** sometimes written as **orifice**"* (隧或为兑).
*The Spring and Autumn Annals of Yànzǐ* (晏子春秋内篇问下篇) also renders it as *"**orifice** of Yǔ"* (兹于兑), confirming this usage.
*Guǎngyǎ* (广雅) explains *"**tunnel**"* (隧) as *"**path**"* (道).
In *Zuǒzhuan* (左传) *Wén Yīnián* (文元年), the *Dù Zhù* (杜注) states: *"**Tunnel**"* (隧) means *"**narrow way**"* (径).
*"Block its **orifice**"* (塞其兑) also means *"to block its **path**"* (塞其道径).
**Qiánzhī** (谦之) notes: **Yú Yì**’s (俞樾) interpretation is correct.
*"Orifice"* (兑) refers to the **passages** (通之处), and *"orifice"* (兑) is borrowed as *"**orifice**"* (阅), actually meaning *"**hole**"* (穴) or *"**opening**"* (窍), such as the ears, eyes, nose, and mouth.
*Yìshuō* (易说) on the *Guà* (卦) states: *"**Orifice** is the mouth"* (兑为口).
In the *Lǎozǐ* (老子), *"Block its **orifice**"* (塞其兑) is annotated in the **Hé** (河) edition: *"**Orifice** refers to the eyes"* (兑，目也).
In *Zhuāngzǐ* (庄子) *Dé Chōngfú* (德充符), *"**Orifice** without loss"* (通而不失于兑) also refers to the ears and eyes.
*Huáinán Dàoyīng Xuàn* (淮南道应训) states *"Tàigōng (太公) said: ‘**Block the people at their **orifice**’*"* (塞民于兑), and **Gāo Yòu** (高诱) annotates: *"**Orifice** refers to the ears, eyes, nose, and mouth"* (兑，耳目鼻口也). The *Lǎozǐ* (老子) also says *"**Block its **orifice**’"* (塞其兑), confirming this.

Open its **orifice** (兑), and it will **complete its affairs** (济其事).
Thus, one’s **life** (身) remains without **salvation** (救).
**Qiánzhī** (谦之) notes: *"Open its **orifice**"* (开其兑), the **Suìzhōu** (遂州) edition reads *"**gates**"* (门) instead of *"**orifice**"* (兑), while the **Jǐngfú** (景福) edition reads *"**sharp**"* (锐).
The phrases *"Thus, one’s **life** remains without **salvation**"* (终身不救) and *"Thus, one’s **life** remains without **toil**"* (终身不勤) form a parallel structure with opposing intentions.
*"Toil"* (勤) is borrowed as *"**illness**"* (瘽).
*Shuōwén Jiězì* (说文解字) states: *"**Illness**"* (瘽) means *"**sickness**"* (病).
(According to **Mǎ Xùlún** (马叙伦))
*"Salvation"* (救) is borrowed as *"**plunder**"* (逑).
*Shuōwén Jiězì* (说文解字) states: *"**Plunder**"* (逑) means *"**extortion**"* (聚敛).
(According to **Luó Yùnxián** (罗运贤), *"without **salvation**"* (无得) means *"without gain"* (不逑))

Block its **orifice** (兑), close its **gates** (门).
Thus, one’s **life** remains without **sickness** (病).
Open its **orifice** (兑), **complete its affairs** (济其事), and one’s **life** is plagued by **desire for gain** (欲得).
Thus, one’s **life** remains without **gain** (得).

Seeing the **small** (小) is **clarity** (明), holding to the **soft** (柔) is **strength** (强).
**Qiánzhī** (谦之) notes: The **Luó** (罗) volume mistakenly includes *"is"* (是) below *"**small**"* (小).
The **Jǐngfú** (景福) and **Wú Chéng** (吴澄) editions both render *"**say**"* (曰) as *"**sun**"* (日), and the **Nài** (柰) volume and **Hé** (河) editions below the sentence also render *"**say**"* (曰) as *"**sun**"* (日).

「Wu [Zhōu] said: *"Sun"* (日) is sometimes written as *"say"* (曰), an error in transmission.*」 The text follows the same pattern as Chapter 52, where *"say"* (曰) should be retained, and all editions of the **Wáng** (王) family, as well as the **Huáinán Dàoyīng** (淮南道应训) commentary, correctly render it as *"say"* (曰). The reading as *"sun"* (日) is erroneous.

**Takuchi Yoshio** (武内义雄) argues that the *"small"* (小) in *"Seeing the small is clarity"* (见小曰明) is a corrupted form of *"constant/everlasting"* (常), citing Chapter 52’s *"Knowing the constant is clarity"* (知常曰明) as evidence. This interpretation is highly persuasive.

Yet, the **Huáinán Bīnglüè** (淮南兵略) states: *"Seeing what people cannot see is called clarity"* (见人之所不可见谓之明), making the reading *"Seeing the small is clarity"* (见小曰明) even more plausible.

Again, *"Holding to the soft is strength"* (守柔曰强) is rendered as *"Using the soft is strength"* (用柔曰强) in the **Dūnhuáng** (敦煌) edition, and the **Róng** (荣) commentary in the **Qiáng** (强) edition also cites the text as *"Using the soft is strength"* (用柔曰强). This appears to be a mistake influenced by the *"use"* (用) in the following line.

*"Use its light"* (用其光), *"restore its clarity"* (复归其明),
**Qiánzhī** (谦之) notes: The **Huáinán Dàoyīng** (淮南道应训) commentary includes *"Therefore"* (是故) before these two lines, while **Móu Zǐ Lǐhuò** (牟子理惑论) cites three lines: *"Use its light"* (用其光), *"restore its clarity"* (复其明), *"without leaving the body to calamity"* (无遗身殃), omitting *"its"* (其) and *"return"* (归). Moreover, **Gāo Yè** (高翿) renders *"restore its clarity"* (复归其明) as *"in clarity"* (于明).

*"Without leaving the body to calamity"* (无遗身殃) is called *"adhere to the constant"* (习常).
**Yán Kějūn** (严可均) says: *"Adhere to the constant"* (习常) is rendered as *"assail the constant"* (袭常) in the **Yùzhòng** (御注) and **Gāo Yè** (高翿) editions.
**Takuchi Yoshio** (武内义雄) states: The **Dūn** (敦) and **Suì** (遂) editions render it as *"assail the constant"* (袭常), with *"adhere"* (习) and *"assail"* (袭) being homophones and interchangeable.

**Qiánzhī** (谦之) notes: The **Jǐngfú** (景福), **Nài** (柰) editions, **Gùhuān** (顾欢), the **Zhū Héshàng** (诸河上) editions, and the **Wáng** (王) editions all render it as *"adhere to the constant"* (习常). **Xíng Xuán** (邢玄), **Lóu Zhèng** (楼正), **Pánxī** (磻溪), **Yán** (严), **Péng** (彭), **Fù** (傅), **Fàn** (范), **Wáng Xǔzhēn** (王羲之), and **Zhào Mèngfǔ** (赵孟俯) render it as *"assail the constant"* (袭常), with *"assail"* (袭) and *"adhere"* (习) being anciently interchangeable. The **Wénxuǎn** (文选) commentary by **Rèn Yànshēng** (任彦升) on *"Shàngshū Jīnténg"* (尚书金滕) states: *"Adhere"* (习) and *"assail"* (袭) are interchangeable, and *"Cloth"* (裳) is the ancient form of *"constant"* (常). The **Shūmíng** (释名) explains: *"Cloth"* (裳), *"barrier"* (障); it is what one uses to shield oneself.*」 The phrase *"assail the constant"* (袭常) in this chapter shares the same meaning as *"conceal the light"* (袭明) in Chapter 27—both imply the **Daoist** practice of preserving and concealing one’s brilliance.

The **Yùpiàn** (玉篇) defines *"assail"* (袭): *"Left-lapelled robe"* (左衽袍), *"to enter"* (入), *"layered garment"* (重衣).*」 Its meaning aligns with layered garments shielding one’s brilliance. The **Yè Mèngdé** (叶梦得) edition correctly renders *"adhere to the constant"* (习常) as *"cloth"* (裳).

However, in the **Lǎozǐ** (老子) text, *"light"* (光) and *"clarity"* (明) carry distinct meanings (as **Dàtián Qíngxuān** (大田晴轩) explains). In Chapter 16: *"Returning to the **Way** is called the constant, knowing the constant is called clarity"* (复命曰常，知常曰明); in Chapter 52: *"Knowing harmony is called the constant, knowing the constant is called clarity"* (知和曰常，知常曰明); in Chapter 33: *"Knowing others is wisdom, self-knowing is clarity"* (知人者智，自知者明); and in Chapter 22: *"Seeing the small is clarity"* (见小曰明), all instances of *"clarity"* (明) refer to **inner wisdom** (内在之智慧). In Chapter 58: *"Light without dazzling"* (光而不耀); in Chapters 4 and 52: *"Harmonizing its light"* (和其光); and in Chapter 24: *"Using its light, returning to its clarity"* (用其光，复归其明), all instances of *"light"* (光) refer to **outer expression** (外表之智慧).*」 This implies blending with the mundane, not dazzling, thus concealing one’s light—akin to **Zhuāngzǐ**’s *"Qíwùlùn"* (齐物论) *"Bǎoguāng"* (葆光), which is here termed *"assail the cloth"* (袭裳).

*"Seeing the small is clarity"* (见小曰明) and *"Not seeing oneself is clarity"* (不自见故明) in Chapter 41, *"The **Way** of clarity is like darkness"* (明道若昧) in Chapter 41, all suggest concealing one’s clarity—*"This is called subtle clarity"* (是谓微明) in Chapter 36 and *"This is called assailing clarity"* (是谓袭明) in Chapter 27. Thus, *"assail the constant"* (袭常) and *"assail the clarity"* (袭明) seem similar yet differ in meaning.

【**Phonology**】 Jiāng’s rhyme reading for this chapter: *shǐ* (始), *mǔ* (母), *mǔ* (母), *zǐ* (子), *mǔ* (母), *dài* (殆) (韵部 *zhī*), *mén* (门), *qín* (勤) (韵部 *wén*), *shì* (事), *jiù* (救) (韵部 *zhī* and *yōu*通韵, *shì*协*shǐ* 去声 *shòu*反), *míng* (明), *qiáng* (强), *guāng* (光), *míng* (明), *yāng* (殃), *cháng* (常) (韵部 *yáng*).
**Qiánzhī** (谦之) notes: *"Affairs"* (事) belongs to the *zhī* (之) rhyme, *"salvation"* (救) to the *yōu* (幽) rhyme, with *zhī* (之) and *yōu* (幽) being interchangeable. **Xí Zòng** (奚侗) agrees. **Xí** (奚) states: *"Mother"* (母) is read as *"each"* (每). *"Affairs"* (事) and *"salvation"* (救) form a rhyme. The *"Shìguānzǐ Shìbīng"* (鹖冠子世兵篇) uses the *zhī* (之) rhyme with *"game"* (游), *"post"* (邮), following the same pattern.

**Gù Yànwǔ** (顾炎武) in *"Tángyùn zhèng"* (唐韵正) Volume 14, under *"Fifty-two, thick"* (十五厚), notes: *"Mother"* (母) has an ancient pronunciation of *mǎn yǐ* (满以)反, as seen in this chapter of **Lǎozǐ** (老子) and *"The nameless is the **beginning** of heaven and earth, the named is the **mother** of ten thousand things"* (无名天地之始，有名万物之母). *"Sudden as the sea, drifting as if without end"* (忽兮若海，漂兮若无所止), *"All people have their own ends, yet I alone am stubborn and coarse"* (众人皆有以，而我独顽以鄙), *"I alone differ from others, thus valuing the **mother**"* (我独异于人而贵食母). *"Standing alone yet unchanging, revolving yet without peril"* (独立而不改，周行而不殆), *"It can be the **mother** of all under heaven"* (可以为天下母). *"The **mother** of a state, which can endure long"* (有国之母，可以长久). **Dèng Tíngzhēn** (邓廷桢) states: *"Affairs"* (事) and *"salvation"* (救) form a rhyme, with *"affairs"* (事) being *zhī* (之) rhyme, *qùshēng* (去声), and *"salvation"* (救) being *yōu* (幽) rhyme, *qùshēng* (去声). To consider them as rhyming despite differing rhyme groups is like the *"Shīyī"* (诗翼) rhyming *"clothing"* (俅) with *"○"* (基), *"cow"* (牛), and *"mole"* (鼒).

The **Jīnglóngbēi** (景龙碑) edition contains **72 characters**; the **Dūnhuáng** (敦煌), **Héshàng** (河上), and **Wáng** (王) editions match this; the **Fù** (傅) edition has **73 characters**; the **Fàn** (范) edition has **72 characters**. The **Héshàng** (河上) edition is titled *"Returning to the **Way** of the **Way**"* (归元第五十二), the **Wáng** (王) edition *"Chapter 52"* (五十二章), and the **Fàn** (范) edition *"Chapter 52: The **Way** of the **Beginning** of All Under Heaven"* (天下有始章第五十二).

**Chapter 53**
*"When I am subtly aware, walking the Great Dao,
I fear only the crooked."*

**Ding Zhongxu** says: *"Jié"* (介) means *"slight"*—*Yīqīng Yìyì* (一切經音義) Volume 15 cites Liu Zhan’s (劉瓛) commentary on the *Yì* (易), and the *Lìzǐ* (列子) *Yángzhū* (楊朱) chapter’s *Shìwén* (釋文) explains *"those without subtle concerns"* (無介然之慮者). In the *Lìzǐ* *Zhòngní* (仲尼) chapter:
*"If there is even the slightest awareness,
and the sound of ‘yes’—
whether distant in the eight desolations beyond,
or near in the hairs of my brows—
if anything approaches me,
I shall surely know it."*

**Song Lin Xíyì** (宋林希逸) says: *"Subtle awareness"* (介然之有) refers to the faintest visible trace.

Again, *"jié"* (介) also means *"firm and unyielding"*—as in the *Xúnzǐ* (荀子) *Xiūshēn* (修身) chapter’s note: *"Virtue in the body is firm, and one must surely take pride in it."*

Zhang Chong’s (張充) letter to Wang Jian (王俭):
*"Firm resolve stands like a towering cliff,
unyielding resolve cuts across the sea’s edge."*

**Wang Renxun** (王念孙) says: Wang Bi (王弼) interprets *"I fear only the crooked"* (唯施是畏) as *"I fear only deeds"* (唯施為之是畏), and the *Heshang Gong* (河上公) annotation is similarly brief. Renxun notes that both scholars take *"shī"* (施) to mean *"deeds"* (施為), which is incorrect. *"Shī"* (施) should be read as *"yí"* (迤), meaning *"crooked."* Walking the Great Dao, one fears only straying into crooked paths.

Later, it states: *"The Great Dao is most smooth, yet people prefer byways"* (大道甚夷，而民好径). The *Heshang Gong* annotation explains: *"Byways are crooked and unorthodox."* This confirms the meaning.

*(Note: The "byways" here are the same as the "crooked" above. Crooked paths easily mislead people, hence "I fear only the crooked." Wang Bi’s note says: "The Great Dao is vast and straight, yet people still abandon it, preferring crooked byways—how much more so when deeds obstruct the Great Dao’s path!" This adds an extra layer of meaning beyond the text, which is incorrect.)*

The *Shuōwén Jiězì* (說文解字) defines *"yí"* (迤) as *"crooked movement,"* citing the *Yǔgōng* (禹貢): *"Eastward it curves northward, converging at Huì."* In the *Mèngzǐ* (孟子) *Líliú* (離娄) chapter, *"Shī from the virtuous man’s path"* (施從良人之所之), Zhao’s (趙) note says: *"Shī means to stray crookedly."*

Ding Gong (丁公) pronounces it *"yí"* (迤). In the *Huáinánzǐ* (淮南子) *Qísú* (齊俗) chapter: *"Abandoning vice is not merely rejecting crooked paths"* (去非者，非批邪施也), Gao’s (高) note says: *"Shī means slight deviation."* In the *Yàoliào* (要略) chapter: *"Meeting straight and crooked paths"* (接径直施), Gao’s note says: *"Shī means crooked."*

This proves *"shī"* (施) and *"yí"* (迤) are interchangeable. In the *Shǐjì* (史記) *Jiǎ Shēng* (賈生) transmission: *"On the day of *gēngzǐ*, it slants"* (庚子日施兮), the *Hànshū* (漢書) renders *"shī"* (施) as *"xié"* (斜), which also means *"crooked."*

**Hán Fēi** (韓非) in the *Xiělǎo* (解老) chapter explains this passage’s meaning:
*"The so-called Great Dao is the straight path.
The so-called ‘crooked’ is the crooked path.
The so-called ‘byways’ are the ornate.
Ornate is the division of the crooked path."*

This is further clear evidence.

**Liu Shīpèi** (劉師培) notes: Wang Bi’s interpretation is correct.

The *Hán Fēi Zǐ* in the *Xiělǎo* chapter states:
*"The *Dàodéjīng*’s so-called ‘Great Dao’ is the *duāndào* [straight path].
The so-called ‘*mào shī*’ is the crooked path.
The so-called ‘*jìng dà*’ is ornate.
Ornate is the division of the crooked path."*

From this passage, it is evident that the original reading of *"wéi shī"* was *"mào shī"*, or that *"mào"* was prefixed with *"wéi"* above. The *Guóyǔ* under *Jìn* states:
*"Mào is the adornment of emotion."* The *Guǎngyà* under *Shìgǔ* explains:
*"Mào means artifice."* Thus, the meaning of *"mào"* aligns with embellishment, making it synonymous with *"shī"* as a crooked path.

The Great Dao is most straightforward, yet people delight in ornateness.
**Yán Kějūn** notes: *"While people delight in ornateness"*—the *Yùzhù* and *Gāoxī* versions read *"mín qǐ hào jìng"*, while the *Héshàng* and *Wáng Bì* versions read *"ér mín"*. **Luó Zhènyù** states: *"‘While’ (ér), in the Dunhuang text, is ‘qí’."*

**Qiān Zhī** examines:
*"Yí"* is rendered as *"○"* in the *Fàn* text. **Fàn** says: *"○ was the original reading; the *Shuōwén* states: ‘To walk with ease.’"* Additionally, the character *"jìng"* is written as *"jìng"* in **Yán Kějūn**’s version, while the *Jìnglóng*, *Yùzhù*, and *Sòngkān Héshàng* versions all render it as *"xì"*. The *Yìlín* (卷一) cites the *Jīng* as *"ér mín hào xì"*, with the annotation from *Héshànggōng*: *"Xì means crooked and unstraight."* Thus, the text **Mǎ Zǒng** saw was *"xì"*. The *Yùpiàn* under the *Rén* department states:
*"Xì (急也), niú gēng, niú yàn liè"*—likely incorrect.

The phrase *"ér rén"* is rendered as *"mín shèn"* in the *Gāoxī*, *Pánxī*, *Lóuzhèng*, *Fàn*, and *Zhào* versions.

**Liú Shīpèi** argues: *"Xì"* should be followed by *"dà"* (大). In Chapter 41 (*"Dà xiào zhī"*), **Wáng Yìxún** posits it should read *"dà ér xiào zhī"*. *"Dà"* is cognate with *"yú"* (迂); though **Wáng Bì** interprets *"yú"* as circuitous, here *"dà"* truly means *"yú"*. The *Hànshū* *Jiàosì Zhì* states: *"Guài yú"* (怪迂), with **Yán Zhì**’s annotation: *"Yú means circuitous and distant."* Thus, *"yú"* aligns with *"jìng"*, hence the pairing of *"jìng"* and *"dà"* in this passage.

**Qiān Zhī** examines: Though **Liú Shīpèi**’s argument is grounded in the *Hán Fēi Zǐ*, it remains somewhat strained.

**Wáng Xiānshèn** states: *"In the *Dàodéjīng*, ‘The Great Dao is most straightforward, yet people delight in ornateness,’ *Héshànggōng* comments: ‘Jìng means crooked and unstraight.’"* Here, the *"dà"* (大) is superfluous.

The court is most corrupt, the fields lie overgrown,
the granaries stand empty.
**Mǎ Xùlún** says: *"The court is most corrupt"*—*"corrupt"* (除) is borrowed for *"filthy"* (污), just as *"rǔ"* (杇) is written as *"tú"* (涂). The various scholars interpreting *"corrupt"* as *"governed"* are incorrect.

**Takeshi Takauchi** states: The *Dun* and *Sui* manuscripts have *"overgrown"* (芜) as *"sprouts"* (苗).
**Qián Zhī** notes: The *Fǎjīng Dūndīng* manuscript reads *"sprouts"* (苗), while the *Luó* manuscript reads *"overgrown"* (芜).
The *Shuōwén Jiězì* states: *"Sprouts"* (苗), *"grass growing in fields."*
The *Gōngyáng Zhuan* (on Duke Huan’s fourth year) annotation says: *"Sprouts"* (苗), *"hair"* (毛).
This is also a borrowed character for *"overgrown"* (芜).
The *Shuōwén Jiězì* defines *"overgrown"* (芜) as *"filth."*
The *Zhōu Yǔ* says: *"Fields and plots lie overgrown"* (田畴荒芜), annotated as *"filth."*
Thus, *"the fields lie overgrown"* (田甚芜) means the land is filthy and untended.
Again, *"corrupt"* (除) is mistakenly written as *"hold"* (持) in the *Gāo* and *Hàn* manuscripts.

They adorn themselves in fine colors,
wear sharp swords at their sides,
are gluttonous in their feasting,
yet hoard wealth in excess—
**Yán Kějūn** notes: *"Adorn themselves in fine colors"* (服文彩) is annotated as *"colors"* (彩) in the *Yù* and *Gāo Yì* manuscripts.
*"Gluttonous in their feasting"* (厌饮食) is annotated as *"gluttonous"* (厌) in the *Yù*, but as *"sated"* (冒) in the *Gāo Yì*.
**Luó Zhènyù** states: *"Colors"* (彩) is written as *"silk"* (丝) in the *Guǎngmíng* manuscript.
*"Gluttonous"* (厌) is written as *"sated"* (餍) in the *Dūnhuáng* manuscript.
*"Wealth"* (财) is written as *"resources"* (资) in the *Dūnhuáng* manuscript.
**Takeshi Takauchi** notes: The *Dun* and *Sui* manuscripts read *"resource-goods"* (资货), aligning with *Hán Fēi Zǐ*’s *Yù Lǎo*.
**Qián Zhī** examines: *"Colors"* (彩) is written as *"patterns"* (采) in the manuscripts of *Yán*, *Péng*, *Fàn*, *Pánxī*, and *Lóu Zhèng*.
*"Colors"* (彩) and *"patterns"* (采) are the same; the *Shuōwén Jiězì* states: *"From silk, with the phonetic *cǎi*."*
The *Yīqiè Jīng Yīnyì* cites the *Shàngshū*: *"Five colors vividly displayed in five hues."*
The *Kǎozhèng Jì* states: *"Five colors complete is called embroidery."*
Chén Jǐngyuán’s annotation cites *Fù Yì*: *"Patterns"* (采) *"is the ancient form of embroidery"* (绣).
**Yǔ Huì** says: *"Adorn themselves in fine colors"* (服文彩), the *Lín* manuscript writes *"patterns"* (采) as in *Hán Fēi Zǐ*. One manuscript reads *"embroidery"* (绣).
Again, *"resource-goods"* (资货) is written as *"goods-resources"* (货资) in the *Fù* and *Fàn* manuscripts, as *"resource-finance"* (资财) in the *Wáng Xīzhī* and *Zhào* manuscripts, and as *"resources"* (资) in the *Gù* manuscript.
*"Feasting"* (饮食) is written as *"sated-feasting"* (饫食) in the *Diàn* manuscript.
This is called *"robber-loud"* (盗○).
It is not the Dao!

**Yán Kějūn** states: **Wáng Bì**’s *"robber-loud"* (盗夸) has an additional *"robber-loud"* (盗夸) in his annotation, with the *Héshànggōng* manuscript matching this.
**Qián Zhī** examines: The *Dàozàng Sòng Zhāng Tàishǒu Huìkè Sìjiā Zhù* cites **Wáng Bì**’s annotation:
*"To boast without attaining it by the Dao is *robber-loud* (盗夸); to be honored without attaining it by the Dao is *usurping position* (窃位). Thus, the non-Dao is clarified, and all non-Dao is *robber-loud* (盗夸)."*
It is known that **Wáng Bì**’s manuscript read *"loud"* (夸) as *"loud"* (夸).
The *Wǔnèi Dūnyǐ* and *Luó* manuscripts both write *"robber-loud"* (盗夸), with an additional *"robber-loud"* (盗夸) below, suggesting **Wáng Bì**’s manuscript was the same.
Only the *Wǔnèi Dūnyǐ* manuscript includes *"also!"* (也哉), while the *Luó* manuscript does not.
**Yán**, **Péng**, **Wáng Xīzhī**, **Pánxī**, and **Lóu Zhèng** all write *"robber-loud"* (盗夸), while **Fàn** writes *"robber-○"* (盗○).
**Yáng Shèn** says: *"This is called robber-loud"* (是谓盗夸) is written as *"loud"* (夸) in all manuscripts.
**Liú Zǐhóu**’s poetry also rhymes with *"robber-loud"* (盗夸), likely due to the *yù* (豫) rhyme.
Now, following *Hán Fēi Zǐ*’s *Jiě Lǎo Piān*, it is corrected to *"robber-zhu"* (盗竽).
**Fēi**’s interpretation states:
*"The *zhu* leads the ensemble—when one *zhu* plays, the others harmonize. The great thief leads, and the petty thieves follow; hence, it is called *robber-zhu* (盗竽)."*
His explanation is well-supported, rhymes with *"yú"* (余), and since *Hán Fēi* was close to *Lǎo*, it likely preserves the original. Thus, it should be followed, even if *Lǎo Zǐ* were alive to dispute it.

Again, **Liú Zǐhóu**’s rhyme, **Lín Xiāo’ōng**, and **Liú Huìmèng**’s interpretations all treat it as *"loud"* (夸), a failure to investigate.
The *Héshànggōng* annotation also writes *"loud"* (夸), yet how could the gods of immortality be so lowly?
**Yú Yì** states: *"Loud"* (夸) has no meaning.
*Hán Fēi Zǐ*’s *Jiě Lǎo Piān* reads *"robber-zhu"* (盗竽), explaining:
*"The *zhu* is the leader of the five tones. When the *zhu* leads, the bells and strings follow; when the *zhu* plays, all music harmonizes. Now, when great deceivers act, the common people follow; when the common people follow, petty thieves will surely join. Thus, those who adorn themselves in fine colors, wear sharp swords, gluttonously feast, yet hoard wealth in excess—this is called *robber-zhu* (盗竽)."*
This was clearly the ancient text, and it should be followed.

**Gǔ Yánwù** says: *"Loud"* (夸) in ancient times was pronounced *kū*.
In *Lǎo Zǐ*’s *"The court is most corrupt"* to *"this is called robber-loud"* (盗夸), the *Shuōwén Jiězì* states: *"Loud"* (夸), *"from *dà* (大), with the phonetic *yú* (于)."* Again, *wū* (洿), *kū* (刳), and *qū* (刳) all derive their sound from *夸*.
**Yáng Shèn**, basing it on *Hán Fēi Zǐ*, changed *Lǎo Zǐ*’s *"robber-loud"* (盗夸) to *"robber-zhu"* (盗竽), likely incorrectly (*Tángyùn Zhèngjì* Vol. 4).
Again, he says: *"This is called robber-loud"* (是谓盗夸), **Yáng Shèn** changed it to *"robber-zhu"* (盗竽), claiming it was based on *Hán Fēi Zǐ*, yet he did not know that the ancients read *"loud"* (夸) as *"hollow"* (刳), which rhymes with *"corrupt"* (除) (*Dá Lǐ Zǐdé Shū*).

**Yú Shěngwú** states: *"Robber"* (盗) should be read as *"boastful"* (诞), as *dào* (盗) and *dàn* (诞) share the same initial and are both *dìng* (定) finals. The *Dūnhuáng* manuscript writes *"loud"* (夸) as *"loud"* (夸), so *"robber-loud"* (盗夸) is *"boastful-loud"* (诞夸).
The *Shuōwén Jiězì* states: *"Loud"* (夸), *"from *dà* (大), with the phonetic *yú* (于)."*
The *Jǐnglóng* manuscript writes *"loud"* (夸) as *"○"*.
*Hán Fēi Zǐ*’s *Jiě Lǎo* reads *"robber-zhu"* (盗竽), but *"robber-zhu"* (盗竽) is *"boastful-loud"* (诞夸), with *"loud"* (夸), *"zhu"* (竽), and *"loud"* (夸) all as borrowed characters. *Hán Fēi Zǐ*’s interpretation of *zhu* as a musical instrument is incorrect.

The *Lüshi Chunqiu*’s *Běnshēng* states: *"Not named for boastfulness"* (非夸以名也), with the annotation: *"Boastful"* (夸) *"means hollow"* (虚). In the *Xúnzǐ Róngrǔ*: *"Is it not boastful?"* (岂不迂乎哉), with the annotation: *"Boastful"* (迂) *"means corrupt"* (失). The meanings of *"corrupt"* (失) and *"hollow"* (虚) are interrelated.

The *Hànshū Wǔxíng Zhì* records *"Shū Yú, Jì Fá"* (叔迂季伐), annotated as *"Boastful"* (迂) *"means boastful and hollow"* (夸诞). The passage above—*"The morning’s affairs were excessively corrupt"* (朝甚除), *"fields lay overgrown"* (田甚芜), *"granaries were empty"* (仓甚虚), *"adorned in fine silks, girded with sharp blades, gluttonous in drink and food, yet wealth overflowed"* (服文彩，带利剑，厌饮食，财货有余)—all describe boastful excess. The context above and below aligns seamlessly.

The phrases *"boastful and hollow"* (诞夸) and *"boastful and corrupt"* (诞迂) were ancient colloquialisms, also rendered as *"boastful excess"* (夸诞) or *"corrupt boastfulness"* (迂诞). The *Xúnzǐ Bùgǒu* states: *"Boastful excess breeds confusion"* (夸诞生惑). The *Rúxiào* declares: *"Boastful excess is hollow"* (夸诞则虚). The *Bàopǔzǐ Qiàohuò* observes: *"Superficial minds are prone to boastful excess"* (浅薄之徒，率多夸诞). The *Shǐjì Xiàowǔ Běnjì* records: *"Matters were as boastful and corrupt"* (事如迂诞). The *Hànshū Yìwén Zhì* notes: *"Then boastful, deceitful, and fantastical texts proliferated further"* (则诞欺怪迂之文，弥以益多). All usages align.

If *"robber"* (盗) is read literally, the phrase *"robber-boastful"* (盗夸) becomes inscrutable. **Qián Zhēn** concludes: *"It must be read as ‘robber-○’* (盗○). The *Jiǎwén Sìshēng Yùn* cites *Gǔ Lǎozǐ* with *"boastful"* (夸), matching the stele text. The *Yùzhù*, *Zhào Mèngfǔ* edition, and *Fàn* edition concur. The *Fàn* edition renders it as *"○"*, likely conflating with *"○"* (the character). The *Shuōwén Jiězì* defines *"○"* as *"that which startles"* (所以惊人也), composed of *"dà"* (大) and *"○"*. Alternatively: *"Vulgar speech calls relentless theft ‘○’, pronounced like *hú* (瓠)."*

**Phonology:** Jiang Shì’s rhyme reading lacks a rhyme. **Yáo Wéntián** groups *"除、芜、虚、余、竽"* (twelve *Yú* level tone). **Dèng Tíngzhēn** and **Xí Dòng** follow. *"竽"* is read as *"夸"*. **Gāo Běn Hàn** groups *"除、芜、虚、余、竽"* (alternately *"夸"*) with *"cǎi"* (采), *"shí"* (食), *"zāi"* (哉) as rhyming. **Takuchi Yoshio** rhymes *"wèi"* (畏), *"yí"* (夷), *"jìng"* (径). **Qián Zhēn** notes: *"‘畏’ and ‘夷’ belong to the *zhǐ* department; ‘径’ does not rhyme."* Jiang Yǒng’s *Gǔyùn Biāozhǔn* (Vol. 19, *Má* section) cites *Lǎozǐ*’s *"The morning’s affairs were excessively corrupt"* (朝甚除) to *"This is called ‘robber-boastful’"* (是谓盗夸). The *Jǐnglóng* stele text (52 characters), *Dūnhuáng*, *Wáng*, and *Fàn* editions agree. The *Héshàng* edition has 51 characters; the *Fù* edition, 54. The *Héshàng* edition is titled *"Yìzhèng Dìsānshísān"* (益证第五十三), the *Wáng* edition *"Dìsānshísān Zhāng"* (五十三章), and the *Fàn* edition *"Shǐwǒ Jièrán Zhāng Dìsānshísān"* (使我介然章第五十三).

**Chapter 54:**
*"The well-built stands unshaken; the well-embraced is not cast off. Descendants’ sacrifices never cease."*

**Yán Kějùn** notes: *"Descendants’ sacrifices never cease"* (子孙祭祀不辍), where *Wáng Bì* inserts *"yǐ"* (以) after *"zǐsūn"* (子孙), and *Hán Fēizǐ* adds *"yǐqí"* (以其) and *"shìshì"* (世世). **Luó Zhènyù** observes: The *Dūnhuáng* edition lacks *"zhě"* (者), while the *Jǐnglóng* and *Dūnhuáng* editions omit *"yǐ"* (以). *"Sacrifice"* (祀) is rendered *"cí"* (祠) in the *Dūnhuáng* edition. **Qián Zhēn** confirms: The *Gùhuān* edition’s first sentence also lacks *"zhě"* (者). The *Fù* edition writes *"bào"* (抱) as *"guàn"* (袌); the *Fàn* edition, *"tuō"* (脱) as *"jué"* (捝). *Yán Zhūn*, *Héshàng*, *Yùzhù*, *Pánxī*, *Lóuzhèng*, *Gù*, *Zhào*, *Fù*, *Fàn*, and *Gāo* editions all omit *"yǐ"* (以). Additionally, the *Húnnán Zhǔshù Xuányìn*’s *"Lún"* section cites the first sentence identically to this stele text.

The *Huánnán Zhǔshù Xuányìn* annotates *"The well-built stands unshaken"* (善建者不拔) as *"Speaking of the formless nature of building"* (言建之无形也). **Wáng Niǎnsūn** states: *"These six characters are the main text, not annotation. ‘Thus, the well-built stands unshaken’* (故善建者不拔) quotes *Lǎozǐ*, while ‘Speaking of the formless nature of building’* (言建之无形也) elucidates its meaning. The *Wénzǐ* correctly renders it: ‘Thus, the well-built stands unshaken, speaking of the formless nature of building’"* (故善建者不拔，言建之无形也). This aligns with *Lǎozǐ*’s ancient intent. **Hán Fēizǐ**’s *Yùlǎo* cites *"The well-built stands unshaken, the well-embraced is not cast off, descendants with their sacrifices never cease"* (善建不拔，善抱不脱，子孙以其祭祀世世不辍), where **Gù Guǎngqì** notes: *"The *Déjīng* lacks the four characters ‘yǐqí shìshì’* (以其世世)."* Again, the *Jiělǎo* quotes *"unshaken"* (不拔), *"not cast off"* (不脱), *"sacrifices unbroken"* (祭祀不绝), showing *"cease"* (辍) is also written *"absolute"* (绝), with identical meanings. **Takuchi Toshio**’s *Dùn* edition renders *"zhé"* (辍) as *"zuì"* (醊); **Luó Juàn** as *"chuò"* (啜)—both incorrect.

*"Cultivate the self, and virtue becomes genuine;
Cultivate the family, and virtue overflows."*

「Cultivate the self, virtue becomes genuine;
Cultivate the village, its virtue grows enduring;
Cultivate the realm, its virtue becomes abundant;
Cultivate the world, its virtue becomes universal.»

**Yán Kějūn** remarks: *"Cultivate the self"*—Hé Shàng and Wáng Bì insert *"yú"* (于) after *"xiū"* (修) in each instance: *"xiū yú shēn,"* *"xiū yú jiā,"* and *"xiū yú xiāng."* The Imperial Commentary and Gāo Yì omit *"yú"* in all five clauses.

The phrase *"its virtue overflows"* (其德有余) is rendered *"nǎi yú"* (乃余) in most editions, while the Imperial Commentary reads *"qí dé néng yǒu yú,"* matching *Hán Fēizǐ*.

In *"Cultivate the realm"* (修之于国), *Hán Fēizǐ* uses *"yú bāng"* (于邦), harmonizing with *"fēng"* (丰) in rhyme—later editions altered *"bāng"* to *"guó"* to avoid the Han taboo.

**Luó Zhèn-yù** notes: The *Jǐngfú* edition omits *"zhī"* (之) throughout. The *Jǐnglóng*, Imperial Commentary, and *Dūnhuáng* manuscripts likewise lack *"yú"* in all four subsequent clauses. The *Dūnhuáng* text further renders *"nǎi"* (乃) as *"néng"* (能) in each instance.

The Imperial Commentary substitutes *"○"* (a blank) for *"zhēn"* (真). *"Its virtue overflows"* (其德乃余) appears as *"qí dé yǒu yú"* in *Jǐnglóng* and *Jǐngfú*, while the *Dūnhuáng* edition adds *"yǒu"* (有) before *"yú."*

**Takuchi Yoshio** observes: Both *Dūn* and *Suì* manuscripts render *"nǎi"* (乃) as *"néng"* (能).

**Qiānzhī** notes: The *Péng*, *Zhào*, *Fù*, *Fàn*, *Lóuzhèng*, and *Gāo Yì* editions likewise omit the five *"yú"* (于) characters. The *Shìtáng* edition places *"nǎi"* (乃) above *"yǒu"* (有), while omitting the four preceding *"yú"* (于) characters. **Yán’s** edition lacks the clause *"its virtue becomes genuine"* (其德乃真), aligning *"its virtue overflows"* (其德有余) with Hé Shàng and Luó Juàn’s stone text.

Additionally, *Fù* and *Fàn* render *"guó"* (国) as *"bāng"* (邦), with *Fù* further substituting *"pǔ"* (溥) for *"pǔ"* (普). **Fàn** states: *"The character ‘bāng’ aligns with *Hán Fēizǐ* and ancient editions."*

**Gù Guǎngqì** notes: *Fù*’s edition uses *"pǔ"* (溥) instead of *"pǔ"* (普)—both characters are identical in meaning.

**Yì Shùndǐng** cites: According to the *Zhōuyì Jíjiě* (Pei’s Commentary on *Yì*), Pei’s annotation on the *Lǎozǐ* states: *"Cultivate the self, virtue becomes genuine."* The *Shījù Zhèngyì* (Preface to the *Shījìng*) quotes the *Lǎozǐ*: *"Cultivate the family, its virtue overflows; cultivate the realm, its virtue becomes abundant."* Both omit *"yú"* (于), and Pei’s citation further lacks *"qí"* (其).

**Jiāo Jǔn** states: *"Bāng"* (邦) is sometimes written *"guó"* (国)—Han scholars altered it to avoid Emperor Gāozǔ’s taboo, disrupting the rhyme. The modern text follows *Hán Fēizǐ*’s original.

**Hóng Yìxuān** argues: *"Cultivate the realm, its virtue becomes abundant"* (修之于国，其德乃丰) should read *"bāng"* (邦) instead of *"guó"* (国). The parallel structure—*shēn* (身), *zhēn* (真); *jiā* (家), *yú* (余); *xiāng* (乡), *cháng* (长); *xià* (下), *pǔ* (普)—demands *"bāng"* (邦) and *"fēng"* (丰) for rhyme. In *Hán Fēizǐ*’s *Jiělǎo*, *"Cultivate the realm, its virtue becomes abundant"* (修之邦，其德乃丰) and *"observe the realm to govern the realm"* (以邦观邦) retain the original character. Thus, the full progression is:
Observe the self to cultivate the self,
Observe the family to cultivate the family,
Observe the village to cultivate the village,
Observe the realm to cultivate the realm,
Observe the world to cultivate the world.

How do I know the world follows this principle?
By this.

**Yán Kějūn** remarks: *"The world follows this principle"* (天下之然) is rendered *"zhī rán zāi"* (之然哉) by Hé Shàng and *"rán zāi"* (然哉) by Wáng Bì, omitting *"zhī"* (之).

**Luó Zhèn-yù** notes: The *Jǐnglóng*, Imperial Commentary, and *Dūnhuáng* manuscripts uniformly read: *"Wú hé yǐ zhī tiānxià zhī rán? Yǐ cǐ."* (吾何以知天下之然？以此)

**Qiānzhī** observes: The *Jǐngfú*, *Pánxī*, *Lóuzhèng*, *Shìtáng*, *Luó Juàn*, *Gù*, *Péng*, *Fù*, *Fàn*, and *Gāo* editions append *"zāi"* (哉) after *"rán"* (然). **Yán’s** edition replaces *"tiānxià"* (天下) with *"qí"* (其), while *Fù* and *Fàn* substitute *"xí"* (奚) for *"hé"* (何)—*Hán Fēizǐ*’s *Jiělǎo* also uses *"xí."*

**Gù Guǎngqì** states: *"Xí"* (奚) in the modern *Déjīng* should retain its original form—*Fù*’s edition correctly uses *"xí,"* aligning with this passage.

「【Phonology & Rhyme】 In this chapter, **Jiāng Shì**’s rhyme readings are as follows:
- *bá*, *tuō*, *chuò* (rhyming under the *Jì* [祭] department, with *bá* pronounced as *biè*, *tuō* and *tā guì* [他厥] in reverse).
- *shēn*, *zhēn* (rhyming under the *Zhēn* [真] department),
- *jiā*, *yú* (rhyming under the *Yú* [鱼] department, with *jiā* pronounced as *gū*),
- *xiāng*, *zhǎng* (rhyming under the *Yáng* [阳] department),
- *bāng*, *fēng* (rhyming under the *Dōng* [东] department, with *bāng* pronounced as *bó gōng* [博工] in reverse; originally *"xiū zhī guó"* [修之国], now altered to match the citation in *Hán Fēizǐ*’s *Jiělǎo* [解老]).

- *xià*, *pǔ* (rhyming under the *Yú* [鱼] department).

**Dèng Tíngzhēn** remarks: *"Bá, tuō, chuò"* rhyme under the *Jì* department—*"Jì"* is its **入聲** [rùshēng, entering tone].
